     114                 :            : /*
     115                 :            :  * Number of WAL insertion locks to use. A higher value allows more insertions
     116                 :            :  * to happen concurrently, but adds some CPU overhead to flushing the WAL,
     117                 :            :  * which needs to iterate all the locks.
     118                 :            :  */
     119                 :            : #define NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS  8

     125                 :            : int         CheckPointSegments;

     156                 :            : const struct config_enum_entry archive_mode_options[] = {

     176                 :            : /*
     177                 :            :  * Statistics for current checkpoint are collected in this global struct.
     178                 :            :  * Because only the checkpointer or a stand-alone backend can perform
     179                 :            :  * checkpoints, this will be unused in normal backends.
     180                 :            :  */
     181                 :            : CheckpointStatsData CheckpointStats;
     182                 :            : 
     183                 :            : /*
     184                 :            :  * ThisTimeLineID will be same in all backends --- it identifies current
     185                 :            :  * WAL timeline for the database system.
     186                 :            :  */
     187                 :            : TimeLineID  ThisTimeLineID = 0;
     188                 :            : 
     189                 :            : /*
     190                 :            :  * Are we doing recovery from XLOG?
     191                 :            :  *
     192                 :            :  * This is only ever true in the startup process; it should be read as meaning
     193                 :            :  * "this process is replaying WAL records", rather than "the system is in
     194                 :            :  * recovery mode".  It should be examined primarily by functions that need
     195                 :            :  * to act differently when called from a WAL redo function (e.g., to skip WAL
     196                 :            :  * logging).  To check whether the system is in recovery regardless of which
     197                 :            :  * process you're running in, use RecoveryInProgress() but only after shared
     198                 :            :  * memory startup and lock initialization.
     199                 :            :  */
     200                 :            : bool        InRecovery = false;
     201                 :            : 
     202                 :            : /* Are we in Hot Standby mode? Only valid in startup process, see xlog.h */
     203                 :            : HotStandbyState standbyState = STANDBY_DISABLED;
     204                 :            : 
     205                 :            : static XLogRecPtr LastRec;
     206                 :            : 
     207                 :            : /* Local copy of WalRcv->receivedUpto */
     208                 :            : static XLogRecPtr receivedUpto = 0;
     209                 :            : static TimeLineID receiveTLI = 0;
     210                 :            : 
     211                 :            : /*
     212                 :            :  * During recovery, lastFullPageWrites keeps track of full_page_writes that
     213                 :            :  * the replayed WAL records indicate. It's initialized with full_page_writes
     214                 :            :  * that the recovery starting checkpoint record indicates, and then updated
     215                 :            :  * each time XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record is replayed.
     216                 :            :  */
     217                 :            : static bool lastFullPageWrites;
     218                 :            : 
     219                 :            : /*
     220                 :            :  * Local copy of the state tracked by SharedRecoveryState in shared memory,
     221                 :            :  * It is false if SharedRecoveryState is RECOVERY_STATE_DONE.  True actually
     222                 :            :  * means "not known, need to check the shared state".
     223                 :            :  */
     224                 :            : static bool LocalRecoveryInProgress = true;
     225                 :            : 
     226                 :            : /*
     227                 :            :  * Local copy of SharedHotStandbyActive variable. False actually means "not
     228                 :            :  * known, need to check the shared state".
     229                 :            :  */
     230                 :            : static bool LocalHotStandbyActive = false;
     231                 :            : 
     232                 :            : /*
     233                 :            :  * Local state for XLogInsertAllowed():
     234                 :            :  *      1: unconditionally allowed to insert XLOG
     235                 :            :  *      0: unconditionally not allowed to insert XLOG
     236                 :            :  *      -1: must check RecoveryInProgress(); disallow until it is false
     237                 :            :  * Most processes start with -1 and transition to 1 after seeing that recovery
     238                 :            :  * is not in progress.  But we can also force the value for special cases.
     239                 :            :  * The coding in XLogInsertAllowed() depends on the first two of these states
     240                 :            :  * being numerically the same as bool true and false.
     241                 :            :  */
     242                 :            : static int  LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;
     243                 :            : 
     244                 :            : /*
     245                 :            :  * When ArchiveRecoveryRequested is set, archive recovery was requested,
     246                 :            :  * ie. signal files were present. When InArchiveRecovery is set, we are
     247                 :            :  * currently recovering using offline XLOG archives. These variables are only
     248                 :            :  * valid in the startup process.
     249                 :            :  *
     250                 :            :  * When ArchiveRecoveryRequested is true, but InArchiveRecovery is false, we're
     251                 :            :  * currently performing crash recovery using only XLOG files in pg_wal, but
     252                 :            :  * will switch to using offline XLOG archives as soon as we reach the end of
     253                 :            :  * WAL in pg_wal.
     254                 :            : */
     255                 :            : bool        ArchiveRecoveryRequested = false;
     256                 :            : bool        InArchiveRecovery = false;
     257                 :            : 
     258                 :            : static bool standby_signal_file_found = false;
     259                 :            : static bool recovery_signal_file_found = false;
     260                 :            : 
     261                 :            : /* Was the last xlog file restored from archive, or local? */
     262                 :            : static bool restoredFromArchive = false;
     263                 :            : 
     264                 :            : /* Buffers dedicated to consistency checks of size BLCKSZ */
     265                 :            : static char *replay_image_masked = NULL;
     266                 :            : static char *master_image_masked = NULL;
     267                 :            : 
     268                 :            : /* options formerly taken from recovery.conf for archive recovery */
     269                 :            : char       *recoveryRestoreCommand = NULL;
     270                 :            : char       *recoveryEndCommand = NULL;
     271                 :            : char       *archiveCleanupCommand = NULL;
     272                 :            : RecoveryTargetType recoveryTarget = RECOVERY_TARGET_UNSET;
     273                 :            : bool        recoveryTargetInclusive = true;
     274                 :            : int         recoveryTargetAction = RECOVERY_TARGET_ACTION_PAUSE;
     275                 :            : TransactionId recoveryTargetXid;
     276                 :            : char       *recovery_target_time_string;
     277                 :            : static TimestampTz recoveryTargetTime;
     278                 :            : const char *recoveryTargetName;
     279                 :            : XLogRecPtr  recoveryTargetLSN;
     280                 :            : int         recovery_min_apply_delay = 0;
     281                 :            : TimestampTz recoveryDelayUntilTime;
     282                 :            : 
     283                 :            : /* options formerly taken from recovery.conf for XLOG streaming */
     284                 :            : bool        StandbyModeRequested = false;
     285                 :            : char       *PrimaryConnInfo = NULL;
     286                 :            : char       *PrimarySlotName = NULL;
     287                 :            : char       *PromoteTriggerFile = NULL;
     288                 :            : 
     289                 :            : /* are we currently in standby mode? */
     290                 :            : bool        StandbyMode = false;
     291                 :            : 
     292                 :            : /* whether request for fast promotion has been made yet */
     293                 :            : static bool fast_promote = false;
     294                 :            : 
     295                 :            : /*
     296                 :            :  * if recoveryStopsBefore/After returns true, it saves information of the stop
     297                 :            :  * point here
     298                 :            :  */
     299                 :            : static TransactionId recoveryStopXid;
     300                 :            : static TimestampTz recoveryStopTime;
     301                 :            : static XLogRecPtr recoveryStopLSN;
     302                 :            : static char recoveryStopName[MAXFNAMELEN];
     303                 :            : static bool recoveryStopAfter;
     304                 :            : 
     305                 :            : /*
     306                 :            :  * During normal operation, the only timeline we care about is ThisTimeLineID.
     307                 :            :  * During recovery, however, things are more complicated.  To simplify life
     308                 :            :  * for rmgr code, we keep ThisTimeLineID set to the "current" timeline as we
     309                 :            :  * scan through the WAL history (that is, it is the line that was active when
     310                 :            :  * the currently-scanned WAL record was generated).  We also need these
     311                 :            :  * timeline values:
     312                 :            :  *
     313                 :            :  * recoveryTargetTimeLineGoal: what the user requested, if any
     314                 :            :  *
     315                 :            :  * recoveryTargetTLIRequested: numeric value of requested timeline, if constant
     316                 :            :  *
     317                 :            :  * recoveryTargetTLI: the currently understood target timeline; changes
     318                 :            :  *
     319                 :            :  * expectedTLEs: a list of TimeLineHistoryEntries for recoveryTargetTLI and the timelines of
     320                 :            :  * its known parents, newest first (so recoveryTargetTLI is always the
     321                 :            :  * first list member).  Only these TLIs are expected to be seen in the WAL
     322                 :            :  * segments we read, and indeed only these TLIs will be considered as
     323                 :            :  * candidate WAL files to open at all.
     324                 :            :  *
     325                 :            :  * curFileTLI: the TLI appearing in the name of the current input WAL file.
     326                 :            :  * (This is not necessarily the same as ThisTimeLineID, because we could
     327                 :            :  * be scanning data that was copied from an ancestor timeline when the current
     328                 :            :  * file was created.)  During a sequential scan we do not allow this value
     329                 :            :  * to decrease.
     330                 :            :  */
     331                 :            : RecoveryTargetTimeLineGoal recoveryTargetTimeLineGoal = RECOVERY_TARGET_TIMELINE_LATEST;
     332                 :            : TimeLineID  recoveryTargetTLIRequested = 0;
     333                 :            : TimeLineID  recoveryTargetTLI = 0;
     334                 :            : static List *expectedTLEs;
     335                 :            : static TimeLineID curFileTLI;
     336                 :            : 
     337                 :            : /*
     338                 :            :  * ProcLastRecPtr points to the start of the last XLOG record inserted by the
     339                 :            :  * current backend.  It is updated for all inserts.  XactLastRecEnd points to
     340                 :            :  * end+1 of the last record, and is reset when we end a top-level transaction,
     341                 :            :  * or start a new one; so it can be used to tell if the current transaction has
     342                 :            :  * created any XLOG records.
     343                 :            :  *
     344                 :            :  * While in parallel mode, this may not be fully up to date.  When committing,
     345                 :            :  * a transaction can assume this covers all xlog records written either by the
     346                 :            :  * user backend or by any parallel worker which was present at any point during
     347                 :            :  * the transaction.  But when aborting, or when still in parallel mode, other
     348                 :            :  * parallel backends may have written WAL records at later LSNs than the value
     349                 :            :  * stored here.  The parallel leader advances its own copy, when necessary,
     350                 :            :  * in WaitForParallelWorkersToFinish.
     351                 :            :  */
     352                 :            : XLogRecPtr  ProcLastRecPtr = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     353                 :            : XLogRecPtr  XactLastRecEnd = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     354                 :            : XLogRecPtr  XactLastCommitEnd = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     355                 :            : 
     356                 :            : /*
     357                 :            :  * RedoRecPtr is this backend's local copy of the REDO record pointer
     358                 :            :  * (which is almost but not quite the same as a pointer to the most recent
     359                 :            :  * CHECKPOINT record).  We update this from the shared-memory copy,
     360                 :            :  * XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr, whenever we can safely do so (ie, when we
     361                 :            :  * hold an insertion lock).  See XLogInsertRecord for details.  We are also
     362                 :            :  * allowed to update from XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr if we hold the info_lck;
     363                 :            :  * see GetRedoRecPtr.  A freshly spawned backend obtains the value during
     364                 :            :  * InitXLOGAccess.
     365                 :            :  */
     366                 :            : static XLogRecPtr RedoRecPtr;
     367                 :            : 
     368                 :            : /*
     369                 :            :  * doPageWrites is this backend's local copy of (forcePageWrites ||
     370                 :            :  * fullPageWrites).  It is used together with RedoRecPtr to decide whether
     371                 :            :  * a full-page image of a page need to be taken.
     372                 :            :  */
     373                 :            : static bool doPageWrites;
     374                 :            : 
     375                 :            : /* Has the recovery code requested a walreceiver wakeup? */
     376                 :            : static bool doRequestWalReceiverReply;
     377                 :            : 
     378                 :            : /*
     379                 :            :  * RedoStartLSN points to the checkpoint's REDO location which is specified
     380                 :            :  * in a backup label file, backup history file or control file. In standby
     381                 :            :  * mode, XLOG streaming usually starts from the position where an invalid
     382                 :            :  * record was found. But if we fail to read even the initial checkpoint
     383                 :            :  * record, we use the REDO location instead of the checkpoint location as
     384                 :            :  * the start position of XLOG streaming. Otherwise we would have to jump
     385                 :            :  * backwards to the REDO location after reading the checkpoint record,
     386                 :            :  * because the REDO record can precede the checkpoint record.
     387                 :            :  */
     388                 :            : static XLogRecPtr RedoStartLSN = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
     389                 :            : 
     390                 :            : /*----------
     391                 :            :  * Shared-memory data structures for XLOG control
     392                 :            :  *
     393                 :            :  * LogwrtRqst indicates a byte position that we need to write and/or fsync
     394                 :            :  * the log up to (all records before that point must be written or fsynced).
     395                 :            :  * LogwrtResult indicates the byte positions we have already written/fsynced.
     396                 :            :  * These structs are identical but are declared separately to indicate their
     397                 :            :  * slightly different functions.
     398                 :            :  *
     399                 :            :  * To read XLogCtl->LogwrtResult, you must hold either info_lck or
     400                 :            :  * WALWriteLock.  To update it, you need to hold both locks.  The point of
     401                 :            :  * this arrangement is that the value can be examined by code that already
     402                 :            :  * holds WALWriteLock without needing to grab info_lck as well.  In addition
     403                 :            :  * to the shared variable, each backend has a private copy of LogwrtResult,
     404                 :            :  * which is updated when convenient.
     405                 :            :  *
     406                 :            :  * The request bookkeeping is simpler: there is a shared XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst
     407                 :            :  * (protected by info_lck), but we don't need to cache any copies of it.
     408                 :            :  *
     409                 :            :  * info_lck is only held long enough to read/update the protected variables,
     410                 :            :  * so it's a plain spinlock.  The other locks are held longer (potentially
     411                 :            :  * over I/O operations), so we use LWLocks for them.  These locks are:
     412                 :            :  *
     413                 :            :  * WALBufMappingLock: must be held to replace a page in the WAL buffer cache.
     414                 :            :  * It is only held while initializing and changing the mapping.  If the
     415                 :            :  * contents of the buffer being replaced haven't been written yet, the mapping
     416                 :            :  * lock is released while the write is done, and reacquired afterwards.
     417                 :            :  *
     418                 :            :  * WALWriteLock: must be held to write WAL buffers to disk (XLogWrite or
     419                 :            :  * XLogFlush).
     420                 :            :  *
     421                 :            :  * ControlFileLock: must be held to read/update control file or create
     422                 :            :  * new log file.
     423                 :            :  *
     424                 :            :  * CheckpointLock: must be held to do a checkpoint or restartpoint (ensures
     425                 :            :  * only one checkpointer at a time; currently, with all checkpoints done by
     426                 :            :  * the checkpointer, this is just pro forma).
     427                 :            :  *
     428                 :            :  *----------
     429                 :            :  */
     430                 :            : 
     431                 :            : typedef struct XLogwrtRqst
     432                 :            : {
     433                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  Write;          /* last byte + 1 to write out */
     434                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  Flush;          /* last byte + 1 to flush */
     435                 :            : } XLogwrtRqst;
     436                 :            : 
     437                 :            : typedef struct XLogwrtResult
     438                 :            : {
     439                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  Write;          /* last byte + 1 written out */
     440                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  Flush;          /* last byte + 1 flushed */
     441                 :            : } XLogwrtResult;
     442                 :            : 
     443                 :            : /*
     444                 :            :  * Inserting to WAL is protected by a small fixed number of WAL insertion
     445                 :            :  * locks. To insert to the WAL, you must hold one of the locks - it doesn't
     446                 :            :  * matter which one. To lock out other concurrent insertions, you must hold
     447                 :            :  * of them. Each WAL insertion lock consists of a lightweight lock, plus an
     448                 :            :  * indicator of how far the insertion has progressed (insertingAt).
     449                 :            :  *
     450                 :            :  * The insertingAt values are read when a process wants to flush WAL from
     451                 :            :  * the in-memory buffers to disk, to check that all the insertions to the
     452                 :            :  * region the process is about to write out have finished. You could simply
     453                 :            :  * wait for all currently in-progress insertions to finish, but the
     454                 :            :  * insertingAt indicator allows you to ignore insertions to later in the WAL,
     455                 :            :  * so that you only wait for the insertions that are modifying the buffers
     456                 :            :  * you're about to write out.
     457                 :            :  *
     458                 :            :  * This isn't just an optimization. If all the WAL buffers are dirty, an
     459                 :            :  * inserter that's holding a WAL insert lock might need to evict an old WAL
     460                 :            :  * buffer, which requires flushing the WAL. If it's possible for an inserter
     461                 :            :  * to block on another inserter unnecessarily, deadlock can arise when two
     462                 :            :  * inserters holding a WAL insert lock wait for each other to finish their
     463                 :            :  * insertion.
     464                 :            :  *
     465                 :            :  * Small WAL records that don't cross a page boundary never update the value,
     466                 :            :  * the WAL record is just copied to the page and the lock is released. But
     467                 :            :  * to avoid the deadlock-scenario explained above, the indicator is always
     468                 :            :  * updated before sleeping while holding an insertion lock.
     469                 :            :  *
     470                 :            :  * lastImportantAt contains the LSN of the last important WAL record inserted
     471                 :            :  * using a given lock. This value is used to detect if there has been
     472                 :            :  * important WAL activity since the last time some action, like a checkpoint,
     473                 :            :  * was performed - allowing to not repeat the action if not. The LSN is
     474                 :            :  * updated for all insertions, unless the XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT flag was
     475                 :            :  * set. lastImportantAt is never cleared, only overwritten by the LSN of newer
     476                 :            :  * records.  Tracking the WAL activity directly in WALInsertLock has the
     477                 :            :  * advantage of not needing any additional locks to update the value.
     478                 :            :  */
     479                 :            : typedef struct
     480                 :            : {
     481                 :            :     LWLock      lock;
     482                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  insertingAt;
     483                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastImportantAt;
     484                 :            : } WALInsertLock;
     485                 :            : 
     486                 :            : /*
     487                 :            :  * All the WAL insertion locks are allocated as an array in shared memory. We
     488                 :            :  * force the array stride to be a power of 2, which saves a few cycles in
     489                 :            :  * indexing, but more importantly also ensures that individual slots don't
     490                 :            :  * cross cache line boundaries. (Of course, we have to also ensure that the
     491                 :            :  * array start address is suitably aligned.)
     492                 :            :  */
     493                 :            : typedef union WALInsertLockPadded
     494                 :            : {
     495                 :            :     WALInsertLock l;
     496                 :            :     char        pad[PG_CACHE_LINE_SIZE];
     497                 :            : } WALInsertLockPadded;
     498                 :            : 
     499                 :            : /*
     500                 :            :  * State of an exclusive backup, necessary to control concurrent activities
     501                 :            :  * across sessions when working on exclusive backups.
     502                 :            :  *
     503                 :            :  * EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_NONE means that there is no exclusive backup actually
     504                 :            :  * running, to be more precise pg_start_backup() is not being executed for
     505                 :            :  * an exclusive backup and there is no exclusive backup in progress.
     506                 :            :  * EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_STARTING means that pg_start_backup() is starting an
     507                 :            :  * exclusive backup.
     508                 :            :  * EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_IN_PROGRESS means that pg_start_backup() has finished
     509                 :            :  * running and an exclusive backup is in progress. pg_stop_backup() is
     510                 :            :  * needed to finish it.
     511                 :            :  * EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_STOPPING means that pg_stop_backup() is stopping an
     512                 :            :  * exclusive backup.
     513                 :            :  */
     514                 :            : typedef enum ExclusiveBackupState
     515                 :            : {
     516                 :            :     EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_NONE = 0,
     517                 :            :     EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_STARTING,
     518                 :            :     EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_IN_PROGRESS,
     519                 :            :     EXCLUSIVE_BACKUP_STOPPING
     520                 :            : } ExclusiveBackupState;
     521                 :            : 
     522                 :            : /*
     523                 :            :  * Session status of running backup, used for sanity checks in SQL-callable
     524                 :            :  * functions to start and stop backups.
     525                 :            :  */
     526                 :            : static SessionBackupState sessionBackupState = SESSION_BACKUP_NONE;
     527                 :            : 
     528                 :            : /*
     529                 :            :  * Shared state data for WAL insertion.
     530                 :            :  */
     531                 :            : typedef struct XLogCtlInsert
     532                 :            : {
     533                 :            :     slock_t     insertpos_lck;  /* protects CurrBytePos and PrevBytePos */
     534                 :            : 
     535                 :            :     /*
     536                 :            :      * CurrBytePos is the end of reserved WAL. The next record will be
     537                 :            :      * inserted at that position. PrevBytePos is the start position of the
     538                 :            :      * previously inserted (or rather, reserved) record - it is copied to the
     539                 :            :      * prev-link of the next record. These are stored as "usable byte
     540                 :            :      * positions" rather than XLogRecPtrs (see XLogBytePosToRecPtr()).
     541                 :            :      */
     542                 :            :     uint64      CurrBytePos;
     543                 :            :     uint64      PrevBytePos;
     544                 :            : 
     545                 :            :     /*
     546                 :            :      * Make sure the above heavily-contended spinlock and byte positions are
     547                 :            :      * on their own cache line. In particular, the RedoRecPtr and full page
     548                 :            :      * write variables below should be on a different cache line. They are
     549                 :            :      * read on every WAL insertion, but updated rarely, and we don't want
     550                 :            :      * those reads to steal the cache line containing Curr/PrevBytePos.
     551                 :            :      */
     552                 :            :     char        pad[PG_CACHE_LINE_SIZE];
     553                 :            : 
     554                 :            :     /*
     555                 :            :      * fullPageWrites is the master copy used by all backends to determine
     556                 :            :      * whether to write full-page to WAL, instead of using process-local one.
     557                 :            :      * This is required because, when full_page_writes is changed by SIGHUP,
     558                 :            :      * we must WAL-log it before it actually affects WAL-logging by backends.
     559                 :            :      * Checkpointer sets at startup or after SIGHUP.
     560                 :            :      *
     561                 :            :      * To read these fields, you must hold an insertion lock. To modify them,
     562                 :            :      * you must hold ALL the locks.
     563                 :            :      */
     564                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  RedoRecPtr;     /* current redo point for insertions */
     565                 :            :     bool        forcePageWrites;    /* forcing full-page writes for PITR? */
     566                 :            :     bool        fullPageWrites;
     567                 :            : 
     568                 :            :     /*
     569                 :            :      * exclusiveBackupState indicates the state of an exclusive backup (see
     570                 :            :      * comments of ExclusiveBackupState for more details). nonExclusiveBackups
     571                 :            :      * is a counter indicating the number of streaming base backups currently
     572                 :            :      * in progress. forcePageWrites is set to true when either of these is
     573                 :            :      * non-zero. lastBackupStart is the latest checkpoint redo location used
     574                 :            :      * as a starting point for an online backup.
     575                 :            :      */
     576                 :            :     ExclusiveBackupState exclusiveBackupState;
     577                 :            :     int         nonExclusiveBackups;
     578                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastBackupStart;
     579                 :            : 
     580                 :            :     /*
     581                 :            :      * WAL insertion locks.
     582                 :            :      */
     583                 :            :     WALInsertLockPadded *WALInsertLocks;
     584                 :            : } XLogCtlInsert;
     585                 :            : 
     586                 :            : /*
     587                 :            :  * Total shared-memory state for XLOG.
     588                 :            :  */
     589                 :            : typedef struct XLogCtlData
     590                 :            : {
     591                 :            :     XLogCtlInsert Insert;
     592                 :            : 
     593                 :            :     /* Protected by info_lck: */
     594                 :            :     XLogwrtRqst LogwrtRqst;
     595                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  RedoRecPtr;     /* a recent copy of Insert->RedoRecPtr */
     596                 :            :     FullTransactionId ckptFullXid;  /* nextFullXid of latest checkpoint */
     597                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  asyncXactLSN;   /* LSN of newest async commit/abort */
     598                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  replicationSlotMinLSN;  /* oldest LSN needed by any slot */
     599                 :            : 
     600                 :            :     XLogSegNo   lastRemovedSegNo;   /* latest removed/recycled XLOG segment */
     601                 :            : 
     602                 :            :     /* Fake LSN counter, for unlogged relations. Protected by ulsn_lck. */
     603                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  unloggedLSN;
     604                 :            :     slock_t     ulsn_lck;
     605                 :            : 
     606                 :            :     /* Time and LSN of last xlog segment switch. Protected by WALWriteLock. */
     607                 :            :     pg_time_t   lastSegSwitchTime;
     608                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastSegSwitchLSN;
     609                 :            : 
     610                 :            :     /*
     611                 :            :      * Protected by info_lck and WALWriteLock (you must hold either lock to
     612                 :            :      * read it, but both to update)
     613                 :            :      */
     614                 :            :     XLogwrtResult LogwrtResult;
     615                 :            : 
     616                 :            :     /*
     617                 :            :      * Latest initialized page in the cache (last byte position + 1).
     618                 :            :      *
     619                 :            :      * To change the identity of a buffer (and InitializedUpTo), you need to
     620                 :            :      * hold WALBufMappingLock.  To change the identity of a buffer that's
     621                 :            :      * still dirty, the old page needs to be written out first, and for that
     622                 :            :      * you need WALWriteLock, and you need to ensure that there are no
     623                 :            :      * in-progress insertions to the page by calling
     624                 :            :      * WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish().
     625                 :            :      */
     626                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  InitializedUpTo;
     627                 :            : 
     628                 :            :     /*
     629                 :            :      * These values do not change after startup, although the pointed-to pages
     630                 :            :      * and xlblocks values certainly do.  xlblock values are protected by
     631                 :            :      * WALBufMappingLock.
     632                 :            :      */
     633                 :            :     char       *pages;          /* buffers for unwritten XLOG pages */
     634                 :            :     XLogRecPtr *xlblocks;       /* 1st byte ptr-s + XLOG_BLCKSZ */
     635                 :            :     int         XLogCacheBlck;  /* highest allocated xlog buffer index */
     636                 :            : 
     637                 :            :     /*
     638                 :            :      * Shared copy of ThisTimeLineID. Does not change after end-of-recovery.
     639                 :            :      * If we created a new timeline when the system was started up,
     640                 :            :      * PrevTimeLineID is the old timeline's ID that we forked off from.
     641                 :            :      * Otherwise it's equal to ThisTimeLineID.
     642                 :            :      */
     643                 :            :     TimeLineID  ThisTimeLineID;
     644                 :            :     TimeLineID  PrevTimeLineID;
     645                 :            : 
     646                 :            :     /*
     647                 :            :      * SharedRecoveryState indicates if we're still in crash or archive
     648                 :            :      * recovery.  Protected by info_lck.
     649                 :            :      */
     650                 :            :     RecoveryState SharedRecoveryState;
     651                 :            : 
     652                 :            :     /*
     653                 :            :      * SharedHotStandbyActive indicates if we're still in crash or archive
     654                 :            :      * recovery.  Protected by info_lck.
     655                 :            :      */
     656                 :            :     bool        SharedHotStandbyActive;
     657                 :            : 
     658                 :            :     /*
     659                 :            :      * WalWriterSleeping indicates whether the WAL writer is currently in
     660                 :            :      * low-power mode (and hence should be nudged if an async commit occurs).
     661                 :            :      * Protected by info_lck.
     662                 :            :      */
     663                 :            :     bool        WalWriterSleeping;
     664                 :            : 
     665                 :            :     /*
     666                 :            :      * recoveryWakeupLatch is used to wake up the startup process to continue
     667                 :            :      * WAL replay, if it is waiting for WAL to arrive or failover trigger file
     668                 :            :      * to appear.
     669                 :            :      */
     670                 :            :     Latch       recoveryWakeupLatch;
     671                 :            : 
     672                 :            :     /*
     673                 :            :      * During recovery, we keep a copy of the latest checkpoint record here.
     674                 :            :      * lastCheckPointRecPtr points to start of checkpoint record and
     675                 :            :      * lastCheckPointEndPtr points to end+1 of checkpoint record.  Used by the
     676                 :            :      * checkpointer when it wants to create a restartpoint.
     677                 :            :      *
     678                 :            :      * Protected by info_lck.
     679                 :            :      */
     680                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointRecPtr;
     681                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointEndPtr;
     682                 :            :     CheckPoint  lastCheckPoint;
     683                 :            : 
     684                 :            :     /*
     685                 :            :      * lastReplayedEndRecPtr points to end+1 of the last record successfully
     686                 :            :      * replayed. When we're currently replaying a record, ie. in a redo
     687                 :            :      * function, replayEndRecPtr points to the end+1 of the record being
     688                 :            :      * replayed, otherwise it's equal to lastReplayedEndRecPtr.
     689                 :            :      */
     690                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastReplayedEndRecPtr;
     691                 :            :     TimeLineID  lastReplayedTLI;
     692                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  replayEndRecPtr;
     693                 :            :     TimeLineID  replayEndTLI;
     694                 :            :     /* timestamp of last COMMIT/ABORT record replayed (or being replayed) */
     695                 :            :     TimestampTz recoveryLastXTime;
     696                 :            : 
     697                 :            :     /*
     698                 :            :      * timestamp of when we started replaying the current chunk of WAL data,
     699                 :            :      * only relevant for replication or archive recovery
     700                 :            :      */
     701                 :            :     TimestampTz currentChunkStartTime;
     702                 :            :     /* Are we requested to pause recovery? */
     703                 :            :     bool        recoveryPause;
     704                 :            : 
     705                 :            :     /*
     706                 :            :      * lastFpwDisableRecPtr points to the start of the last replayed
     707                 :            :      * XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record that instructs full_page_writes is disabled.
     708                 :            :      */
     709                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastFpwDisableRecPtr;
     710                 :            : 
     711                 :            :     slock_t     info_lck;       /* locks shared variables shown above */
     712                 :            : } XLogCtlData;
     713                 :            : 
     714                 :            : static XLogCtlData *XLogCtl = NULL;
     715                 :            : 
     716                 :            : /* a private copy of XLogCtl->Insert.WALInsertLocks, for convenience */
     717                 :            : static WALInsertLockPadded *WALInsertLocks = NULL;
     718                 :            : 
     719                 :            : /*
     720                 :            :  * We maintain an image of pg_control in shared memory.
     721                 :            :  */
     722                 :            : static ControlFileData *ControlFile = NULL;
     723                 :            : 
     724                 :            : /*
     725                 :            :  * Calculate the amount of space left on the page after 'endptr'. Beware
     726                 :            :  * multiple evaluation!
     727                 :            :  */
     728                 :            : #define INSERT_FREESPACE(endptr)    \
     729                 :            :     (((endptr) % XLOG_BLCKSZ == 0) ? 0 : (XLOG_BLCKSZ - (endptr) % XLOG_BLCKSZ))
     730                 :            : 
     731                 :            : /* Macro to advance to next buffer index. */
     732                 :            : #define NextBufIdx(idx)     \
     733                 :            :         (((idx) == XLogCtl->XLogCacheBlck) ? 0 : ((idx) + 1))
     734                 :            : 
     735                 :            : /*
     736                 :            :  * XLogRecPtrToBufIdx returns the index of the WAL buffer that holds, or
     737                 :            :  * would hold if it was in cache, the page containing 'recptr'.
     738                 :            :  */
     739                 :            : #define XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(recptr)  \
     740                 :            :     (((recptr) / XLOG_BLCKSZ) % (XLogCtl->XLogCacheBlck + 1))
     741                 :            : 
     742                 :            : /*
     743                 :            :  * These are the number of bytes in a WAL page usable for WAL data.
     744                 :            :  */
     745                 :            : #define UsableBytesInPage (XLOG_BLCKSZ - SizeOfXLogShortPHD)
     746                 :            : 
     747                 :            : /*
     748                 :            :  * Convert min_wal_size_mb and max wal_size_mb to equivalent segment count.
     749                 :            :  * Rounds down.
     750                 :            :  */
     751                 :            : #define ConvertToXSegs(x, segsize)  \
     752                 :            :     ((x) / ((segsize) / (1024 * 1024)))
     753                 :            : 
     754                 :            : /* The number of bytes in a WAL segment usable for WAL data. */
     755                 :            : static int  UsableBytesInSegment;
     756                 :            : 
     757                 :            : /*
     758                 :            :  * Private, possibly out-of-date copy of shared LogwrtResult.
     759                 :            :  * See discussion above.
     760                 :            :  */
     761                 :            : static XLogwrtResult LogwrtResult = {0, 0};
     762                 :            : 
     763                 :            : /*
     764                 :            :  * Codes indicating where we got a WAL file from during recovery, or where
     765                 :            :  * to attempt to get one.
     766                 :            :  */
     767                 :            : typedef enum
     768                 :            : {
     769                 :            :     XLOG_FROM_ANY = 0,          /* request to read WAL from any source */
     770                 :            :     XLOG_FROM_ARCHIVE,          /* restored using restore_command */
     771                 :            :     XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL,           /* existing file in pg_wal */
     772                 :            :     XLOG_FROM_STREAM            /* streamed from master */
     773                 :            : } XLogSource;
     774                 :            : 
     775                 :            : /* human-readable names for XLogSources, for debugging output */
     776                 :            : static const char *xlogSourceNames[] = {"any", "archive", "pg_wal", "stream"};
     777                 :            : 
     778                 :            : /*
     779                 :            :  * openLogFile is -1 or a kernel FD for an open log file segment.
     780                 :            :  * openLogSegNo identifies the segment.  These variables are only used to
     781                 :            :  * write the XLOG, and so will normally refer to the active segment.
     782                 :            :  */
     783                 :            : static int  openLogFile = -1;
     784                 :            : static XLogSegNo openLogSegNo = 0;
     785                 :            : 
     786                 :            : /*
     787                 :            :  * These variables are used similarly to the ones above, but for reading
     788                 :            :  * the XLOG.  Note, however, that readOff generally represents the offset
     789                 :            :  * of the page just read, not the seek position of the FD itself, which
     790                 :            :  * will be just past that page. readLen indicates how much of the current
     791                 :            :  * page has been read into readBuf, and readSource indicates where we got
     792                 :            :  * the currently open file from.
     793                 :            :  */
     794                 :            : static int  readFile = -1;
     795                 :            : static XLogSegNo readSegNo = 0;
     796                 :            : static uint32 readOff = 0;
     797                 :            : static uint32 readLen = 0;
     798                 :            : static XLogSource readSource = 0;   /* XLOG_FROM_* code */
     799                 :            : 
     800                 :            : /*
     801                 :            :  * Keeps track of which source we're currently reading from. This is
     802                 :            :  * different from readSource in that this is always set, even when we don't
     803                 :            :  * currently have a WAL file open. If lastSourceFailed is set, our last
     804                 :            :  * attempt to read from currentSource failed, and we should try another source
     805                 :            :  * next.
     806                 :            :  */
     807                 :            : static XLogSource currentSource = 0;    /* XLOG_FROM_* code */
     808                 :            : static bool lastSourceFailed = false;
     809                 :            : 
     810                 :            : typedef struct XLogPageReadPrivate
     811                 :            : {
     812                 :            :     int         emode;
     813                 :            :     bool        fetching_ckpt;  /* are we fetching a checkpoint record? */
     814                 :            :     bool        randAccess;
     815                 :            : } XLogPageReadPrivate;
     816                 :            : 
     817                 :            : /*
     818                 :            :  * These variables track when we last obtained some WAL data to process,
     819                 :            :  * and where we got it from.  (XLogReceiptSource is initially the same as
     820                 :            :  * readSource, but readSource gets reset to zero when we don't have data
     821                 :            :  * to process right now.  It is also different from currentSource, which
     822                 :            :  * also changes when we try to read from a source and fail, while
     823                 :            :  * XLogReceiptSource tracks where we last successfully read some WAL.)
     824                 :            :  */
     825                 :            : static TimestampTz XLogReceiptTime = 0;
     826                 :            : static XLogSource XLogReceiptSource = 0;    /* XLOG_FROM_* code */
     827                 :            : 
     828                 :            : /* State information for XLOG reading */
     829                 :            : static XLogRecPtr ReadRecPtr;   /* start of last record read */
     830                 :            : static XLogRecPtr EndRecPtr;    /* end+1 of last record read */
     831                 :            : 
     832                 :            : /*
     833                 :            :  * Local copies of equivalent fields in the control file.  When running
     834                 :            :  * crash recovery, minRecoveryPoint is set to InvalidXLogRecPtr as we
     835                 :            :  * expect to replay all the WAL available, and updateMinRecoveryPoint is
     836                 :            :  * switched to false to prevent any updates while replaying records.
     837                 :            :  * Those values are kept consistent as long as crash recovery runs.
     838                 :            :  */
     839                 :            : static XLogRecPtr minRecoveryPoint;
     840                 :            : static TimeLineID minRecoveryPointTLI;
     841                 :            : static bool updateMinRecoveryPoint = true;
     842                 :            : 
     843                 :            : /*
     844                 :            :  * Have we reached a consistent database state? In crash recovery, we have
     845                 :            :  * to replay all the WAL, so reachedConsistency is never set. During archive
     846                 :            :  * recovery, the database is consistent once minRecoveryPoint is reached.
     847                 :            :  */
     848                 :            : bool        reachedConsistency = false;
     849                 :            : 
     850                 :            : static bool InRedo = false;
     851                 :            : 
     852                 :            : /* Have we launched bgwriter during recovery? */
     853                 :            : static bool bgwriterLaunched = false;
     854                 :            : 
     855                 :            : /* For WALInsertLockAcquire/Release functions */
     856                 :            : static int  MyLockNo = 0;
     857                 :            : static bool holdingAllLocks = false;
     858                 :            : 
     859                 :            : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
     860                 :            : static MemoryContext walDebugCxt = NULL;
     861                 :            : #endif
     862                 :            : 
     863                 :            : static void readRecoverySignalFile(void);
     864                 :            : static void validateRecoveryParameters(void);
     865                 :            : static void exitArchiveRecovery(TimeLineID endTLI, XLogRecPtr endOfLog);
     866                 :            : static bool recoveryStopsBefore(XLogReaderState *record);
     867                 :            : static bool recoveryStopsAfter(XLogReaderState *record);
     868                 :            : static void recoveryPausesHere(void);
     869                 :            : static bool recoveryApplyDelay(XLogReaderState *record);
     870                 :            : static void SetLatestXTime(TimestampTz xtime);
     871                 :            : static void SetCurrentChunkStartTime(TimestampTz xtime);
     872                 :            : static void CheckRequiredParameterValues(void);
     873                 :            : static void XLogReportParameters(void);
     874                 :            : static void checkTimeLineSwitch(XLogRecPtr lsn, TimeLineID newTLI,
     875                 :            :                                 TimeLineID prevTLI);
     876                 :            : static void LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed(void);
     877                 :            : static void CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord(void);
     878                 :            : static void CheckPointGuts(XLogRecPtr checkPointRedo, int flags);
     879                 :            : static void KeepLogSeg(XLogRecPtr recptr, XLogSegNo *logSegNo);
     880                 :            : static XLogRecPtr XLogGetReplicationSlotMinimumLSN(void);
     881                 :            : 
     882                 :            : static void AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(XLogRecPtr upto, bool opportunistic);
     883                 :            : static bool XLogCheckpointNeeded(XLogSegNo new_segno);
     884                 :            : static void XLogWrite(XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst, bool flexible);
     885                 :            : static bool InstallXLogFileSegment(XLogSegNo *segno, char *tmppath,
     886                 :            :                                    bool find_free, XLogSegNo max_segno,

     929                 :            : 
     930                 :            : static void CopyXLogRecordToWAL(int write_len, bool isLogSwitch,
     931                 :            :                                 XLogRecData *rdata,
     932                 :            :                                 XLogRecPtr StartPos, XLogRecPtr EndPos);
     933                 :            : static void ReserveXLogInsertLocation(int size, XLogRecPtr *StartPos,
     934                 :            :                                       XLogRecPtr *EndPos, XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr);
     935                 :            : static bool ReserveXLogSwitch(XLogRecPtr *StartPos, XLogRecPtr *EndPos,
     936                 :            :                               XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr);
     937                 :            : static XLogRecPtr WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(XLogRecPtr upto);
     938                 :            : static char *GetXLogBuffer(XLogRecPtr ptr);
     939                 :            : static XLogRecPtr XLogBytePosToRecPtr(uint64 bytepos);
     940                 :            : static XLogRecPtr XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(uint64 bytepos);
     941                 :            : static uint64 XLogRecPtrToBytePos(XLogRecPtr ptr);
     942                 :            : static void checkXLogConsistency(XLogReaderState *record);
     943                 :            : 
     944                 :            : static void WALInsertLockAcquire(void);
     945                 :            : static void WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive(void);
     946                 :            : static void WALInsertLockRelease(void);
     947                 :            : static void WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(XLogRecPtr insertingAt);
     948                 :            : 
     949                 :            : /*
     950                 :            :  * Insert an XLOG record represented by an already-constructed chain of data
     951                 :            :  * chunks.  This is a low-level routine; to construct the WAL record header
     952                 :            :  * and data, use the higher-level routines in xloginsert.c.
     953                 :            :  *
     954                 :            :  * If 'fpw_lsn' is valid, it is the oldest LSN among the pages that this
     955                 :            :  * WAL record applies to, that were not included in the record as full page
     956                 :            :  * images.  If fpw_lsn <= RedoRecPtr, the function does not perform the
     957                 :            :  * insertion and returns InvalidXLogRecPtr.  The caller can then recalculate
     958                 :            :  * which pages need a full-page image, and retry.  If fpw_lsn is invalid, the
     959                 :            :  * record is always inserted.
     960                 :            :  *
     961                 :            :  * 'flags' gives more in-depth control on the record being inserted. See
     962                 :            :  * XLogSetRecordFlags() for details.
     963                 :            :  *
     964                 :            :  * The first XLogRecData in the chain must be for the record header, and its
     965                 :            :  * data must be MAXALIGNed.  XLogInsertRecord fills in the xl_prev and
     966                 :            :  * xl_crc fields in the header, the rest of the header must already be filled
     967                 :            :  * by the caller.
     968                 :            :  *
     969                 :            :  * Returns XLOG pointer to end of record (beginning of next record).
     970                 :            :  * This can be used as LSN for data pages affected by the logged action.
     971                 :            :  * (LSN is the XLOG point up to which the XLOG must be flushed to disk
     972                 :            :  * before the data page can be written out.  This implements the basic
     973                 :            :  * WAL rule "write the log before the data".)
     974                 :            :  */
     975                 :            : XLogRecPtr
     976                 :    1157941 : XLogInsertRecord(XLogRecData *rdata,
     977                 :            :                  XLogRecPtr fpw_lsn,
     978                 :            :                  uint8 flags)
     979                 :            : {
     980                 :    1157941 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
     981                 :            :     pg_crc32c   rdata_crc;
     982                 :            :     bool        inserted;
     983                 :    1157941 :     XLogRecord *rechdr = (XLogRecord *) rdata->data;
     984                 :    1157941 :     uint8       info = rechdr->xl_info & ~XLR_INFO_MASK;
     985 [ +  + ][ +  + ]:    1157941 :     bool        isLogSwitch = (rechdr->xl_rmid == RM_XLOG_ID &&
     986                 :            :                                info == XLOG_SWITCH);
     987                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  StartPos;
     988                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  EndPos;
     989                 :    1157941 :     bool        prevDoPageWrites = doPageWrites;
     990                 :            : 
     991                 :            :     /* we assume that all of the record header is in the first chunk */
     992                 :            :     Assert(rdata->len >= SizeOfXLogRecord);
     993                 :            : 
     994                 :            :     /* cross-check on whether we should be here or not */
     995         [ -  + ]:    1157941 :     if (!XLogInsertAllowed())
     996                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "cannot make new WAL entries during recovery");
     997                 :            : 
     998                 :            :     /*----------
     999                 :            :      *
    1000                 :            :      * We have now done all the preparatory work we can without holding a
    1001                 :            :      * lock or modifying shared state. From here on, inserting the new WAL
    1002                 :            :      * record to the shared WAL buffer cache is a two-step process:
    1003                 :            :      *
    1004                 :            :      * 1. Reserve the right amount of space from the WAL. The current head of
    1005                 :            :      *    reserved space is kept in Insert->CurrBytePos, and is protected by
    1006                 :            :      *    insertpos_lck.
    1007                 :            :      *
    1008                 :            :      * 2. Copy the record to the reserved WAL space. This involves finding the
    1009                 :            :      *    correct WAL buffer containing the reserved space, and copying the
    1010                 :            :      *    record in place. This can be done concurrently in multiple processes.
    1011                 :            :      *
    1012                 :            :      * To keep track of which insertions are still in-progress, each concurrent
    1013                 :            :      * inserter acquires an insertion lock. In addition to just indicating that
    1014                 :            :      * an insertion is in progress, the lock tells others how far the inserter
    1015                 :            :      * has progressed. There is a small fixed number of insertion locks,
    1016                 :            :      * determined by NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS. When an inserter crosses a page
    1017                 :            :      * boundary, it updates the value stored in the lock to the how far it has
    1018                 :            :      * inserted, to allow the previous buffer to be flushed.
    1019                 :            :      *
    1020                 :            :      * Holding onto an insertion lock also protects RedoRecPtr and
    1021                 :            :      * fullPageWrites from changing until the insertion is finished.
    1022                 :            :      *
    1023                 :            :      * Step 2 can usually be done completely in parallel. If the required WAL
    1024                 :            :      * page is not initialized yet, you have to grab WALBufMappingLock to
    1025                 :            :      * initialize it, but the WAL writer tries to do that ahead of insertions
    1026                 :            :      * to avoid that from happening in the critical path.
    1027                 :            :      *
    1028                 :            :      *----------
    1029                 :            :      */
    1030                 :    1157941 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    1031         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :     if (isLogSwitch)
    1032                 :          1 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    1033                 :            :     else
    1034                 :    1157940 :         WALInsertLockAcquire();
    1035                 :            : 
    1036                 :            :     /*
    1037                 :            :      * Check to see if my copy of RedoRecPtr is out of date. If so, may have
    1038                 :            :      * to go back and have the caller recompute everything. This can only
    1039                 :            :      * happen just after a checkpoint, so it's better to be slow in this case
    1040                 :            :      * and fast otherwise.
    1041                 :            :      *
    1042                 :            :      * Also check to see if fullPageWrites or forcePageWrites was just turned
    1043                 :            :      * on; if we weren't already doing full-page writes then go back and
    1044                 :            :      * recompute.
    1045                 :            :      *
    1046                 :            :      * If we aren't doing full-page writes then RedoRecPtr doesn't actually
    1047                 :            :      * affect the contents of the XLOG record, so we'll update our local copy
    1048                 :            :      * but not force a recomputation.  (If doPageWrites was just turned off,
    1049                 :            :      * we could recompute the record without full pages, but we choose not to
    1050                 :            :      * bother.)
    1051                 :            :      */
    1052         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :     if (RedoRecPtr != Insert->RedoRecPtr)
    1053                 :            :     {
    1054                 :            :         Assert(RedoRecPtr < Insert->RedoRecPtr);
    1055                 :         99 :         RedoRecPtr = Insert->RedoRecPtr;
    1056                 :            :     }
    1057 [ -  + ][ #  # ]:    1157941 :     doPageWrites = (Insert->fullPageWrites || Insert->forcePageWrites);
    1058                 :            : 
    1059 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:    1157941 :     if (doPageWrites &&
    1060         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :         (!prevDoPageWrites ||
    1061         [ -  + ]:    1024584 :          (fpw_lsn != InvalidXLogRecPtr && fpw_lsn <= RedoRecPtr)))
    1062                 :            :     {
    1063                 :            :         /*
    1064                 :            :          * Oops, some buffer now needs to be backed up that the caller didn't
    1065                 :            :          * back up.  Start over.
    1066                 :            :          */
    1067                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    1068                 :          0 :         END_CRIT_SECTION();
    1069                 :          0 :         return InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    1070                 :            :     }
    1071                 :            : 
    1072                 :            :     /*
    1073                 :            :      * Reserve space for the record in the WAL. This also sets the xl_prev
    1074                 :            :      * pointer.
    1075                 :            :      */
    1076         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :     if (isLogSwitch)
    1077                 :          1 :         inserted = ReserveXLogSwitch(&StartPos, &EndPos, &rechdr->xl_prev);
    1078                 :            :     else
    1079                 :            :     {
    1080                 :    1157940 :         ReserveXLogInsertLocation(rechdr->xl_tot_len, &StartPos, &EndPos,
    1081                 :            :                                   &rechdr->xl_prev);
    1082                 :    1157940 :         inserted = true;
    1083                 :            :     }
    1084                 :            : 
    1085         [ +  - ]:    1157941 :     if (inserted)
    1086                 :            :     {
    1087                 :            :         /*
    1088                 :            :          * Now that xl_prev has been filled in, calculate CRC of the record
    1089                 :            :          * header.
    1090                 :            :          */
    1091                 :    1157941 :         rdata_crc = rechdr->xl_crc;
    1092                 :    1157941 :         COMP_CRC32C(rdata_crc, rechdr, offsetof(XLogRecord, xl_crc));
    1093                 :    1157941 :         FIN_CRC32C(rdata_crc);
    1094                 :    1157941 :         rechdr->xl_crc = rdata_crc;
    1095                 :            : 
    1096                 :            :         /*
    1097                 :            :          * All the record data, including the header, is now ready to be
    1098                 :            :          * inserted. Copy the record in the space reserved.
    1099                 :            :          */
    1100                 :    1157941 :         CopyXLogRecordToWAL(rechdr->xl_tot_len, isLogSwitch, rdata,
    1101                 :            :                             StartPos, EndPos);
    1102                 :            : 
    1103                 :            :         /*
    1104                 :            :          * Unless record is flagged as not important, update LSN of last
    1105                 :            :          * important record in the current slot. When holding all locks, just
    1106                 :            :          * update the first one.
    1107                 :            :          */
    1108         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :         if ((flags & XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT) == 0)
    1109                 :            :         {
    1110         [ +  + ]:    1157059 :             int         lockno = holdingAllLocks ? 0 : MyLockNo;
    1111                 :            : 
    1112                 :    1157941 :             WALInsertLocks[lockno].l.lastImportantAt = StartPos;
    1113                 :            :         }
    1114                 :            :     }
    1115                 :            :     else
    1116                 :            :     {
    1117                 :            :         /*
    1118                 :            :          * This was an xlog-switch record, but the current insert location was
    1119                 :            :          * already exactly at the beginning of a segment, so there was no need
    1120                 :            :          * to do anything.
    1121                 :            :          */
    1122                 :            :     }
    1123                 :            : 
    1124                 :            :     /*
    1125                 :            :      * Done! Let others know that we're finished.
    1126                 :            :      */
    1127                 :    1157941 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    1128                 :            : 
    1129                 :    1157941 :     MarkCurrentTransactionIdLoggedIfAny();
    1130                 :            : 
    1131                 :    1157941 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    1132                 :            : 
    1133                 :            :     /*
    1134                 :            :      * Update shared LogwrtRqst.Write, if we crossed page boundary.
    1135                 :            :      */
    1136         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :     if (StartPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ != EndPos / XLOG_BLCKSZ)
    1137                 :            :     {
    1138         [ -  + ]:      23652 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    1139                 :            :         /* advance global request to include new block(s) */
    1140         [ +  - ]:      23652 :         if (XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write < EndPos)
    1141                 :      23652 :             XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write = EndPos;
    1142                 :            :         /* update local result copy while I have the chance */
    1143                 :      23652 :         LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    1144                 :      23652 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    1145                 :            :     }
    1146                 :            : 
    1147                 :            :     /*
    1148                 :            :      * If this was an XLOG_SWITCH record, flush the record and the empty
    1149                 :            :      * padding space that fills the rest of the segment, and perform
    1150                 :            :      * end-of-segment actions (eg, notifying archiver).
    1151                 :            :      */
    1152         [ +  + ]:    1157941 :     if (isLogSwitch)
    1153                 :            :     {
    1154                 :          1 :         TRACE_POSTGRESQL_WAL_SWITCH();
    1155                 :          1 :         XLogFlush(EndPos);
    1156                 :            : 
    1157                 :            :         /*
    1158                 :            :          * Even though we reserved the rest of the segment for us, which is
    1159                 :            :          * reflected in EndPos, we return a pointer to just the end of the
    1160                 :            :          * xlog-switch record.
    1161                 :            :          */
    1162         [ +  - ]:          1 :         if (inserted)
    1163                 :            :         {

    1166                 :            :             {

    1175                 :            :     }
    1176                 :            : 
    1177                 :            : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
    1178                 :            :     if (XLOG_DEBUG)

    1188                 :            :         initStringInfo(&buf);
    1189                 :            :         appendStringInfo(&buf, "INSERT @ %X/%X: ",
    1190                 :            :                          (uint32) (EndPos >> 32), (uint32) EndPos);
    1191                 :            : 
    1192                 :            :         /*

    1194                 :            :          * entries, so that we can pass it to the rm_desc function as one
    1195                 :            :          * contiguous chunk.
    1196                 :            :          */
    1197                 :            :         initStringInfo(&recordBuf);
    1198                 :            :         for (; rdata != NULL; rdata = rdata->next)
    1199                 :            :             appendBinaryStringInfo(&recordBuf, rdata->data, rdata->len);
    1200                 :            :

    1203                 :            :

    1226                 :            : 
    1227                 :            :     /*
    1228                 :            :      * Update our global variables

    1230                 :    1157941 :     ProcLastRecPtr = StartPos;
