    1232                 :            : 
    1233                 :    1157941 :     return EndPos;
    1234                 :            : }
    1235                 :            : 
    1236                 :            : /*
    1237                 :            :  * Reserves the right amount of space for a record of given size from the WAL.
    1238                 :            :  * *StartPos is set to the beginning of the reserved section, *EndPos to
    1239                 :            :  * its end+1. *PrevPtr is set to the beginning of the previous record; it is
    1240                 :            :  * used to set the xl_prev of this record.
    1241                 :            :  *
    1242                 :            :  * This is the performance critical part of XLogInsert that must be serialized
    1243                 :            :  * across backends. The rest can happen mostly in parallel. Try to keep this
    1244                 :            :  * section as short as possible, insertpos_lck can be heavily contended on a
    1245                 :            :  * busy system.
    1246                 :            :  *
    1247                 :            :  * NB: The space calculation here must match the code in CopyXLogRecordToWAL,
    1248                 :            :  * where we actually copy the record to the reserved space.
    1249                 :            :  */
    1250                 :            : static void
    1251                 :    1157940 : ReserveXLogInsertLocation(int size, XLogRecPtr *StartPos, XLogRecPtr *EndPos,
    1252                 :            :                           XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr)
    1253                 :            : {
    1254                 :    1157940 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1255                 :            :     uint64      startbytepos;
    1256                 :            :     uint64      endbytepos;
    1257                 :            :     uint64      prevbytepos;
    1258                 :            : 
    1259                 :    1157940 :     size = MAXALIGN(size);
    1260                 :            : 
    1261                 :            :     /* All (non xlog-switch) records should contain data. */
    1262                 :            :     Assert(size > SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1263                 :            : 
    1264                 :            :     /*
    1265                 :            :      * The duration the spinlock needs to be held is minimized by minimizing
    1266                 :            :      * the calculations that have to be done while holding the lock. The
    1267                 :            :      * current tip of reserved WAL is kept in CurrBytePos, as a byte position
    1268                 :            :      * that only counts "usable" bytes in WAL, that is, it excludes all WAL
    1269                 :            :      * page headers. The mapping between "usable" byte positions and physical
    1270                 :            :      * positions (XLogRecPtrs) can be done outside the locked region, and
    1271                 :            :      * because the usable byte position doesn't include any headers, reserving
    1272                 :            :      * X bytes from WAL is almost as simple as "CurrBytePos += X".
    1273                 :            :      */
    1274         [ -  + ]:    1157940 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1275                 :            : 
    1276                 :    1157940 :     startbytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1277                 :    1157940 :     endbytepos = startbytepos + size;
    1278                 :    1157940 :     prevbytepos = Insert->PrevBytePos;
    1279                 :    1157940 :     Insert->CurrBytePos = endbytepos;
    1280                 :    1157940 :     Insert->PrevBytePos = startbytepos;
    1281                 :            : 
    1282                 :    1157940 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1283                 :            : 
    1284                 :    1157940 :     *StartPos = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(startbytepos);
    1285                 :    1157940 :     *EndPos = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(endbytepos);
    1286                 :    1157940 :     *PrevPtr = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(prevbytepos);
    1287                 :            : 
    1288                 :            :     /*
    1289                 :            :      * Check that the conversions between "usable byte positions" and
    1290                 :            :      * XLogRecPtrs work consistently in both directions.
    1291                 :            :      */
    1292                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*StartPos) == startbytepos);
    1293                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos) == endbytepos);
    1294                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*PrevPtr) == prevbytepos);
    1295                 :    1157940 : }
    1296                 :            : 
    1297                 :            : /*
    1298                 :            :  * Like ReserveXLogInsertLocation(), but for an xlog-switch record.
    1299                 :            :  *
    1300                 :            :  * A log-switch record is handled slightly differently. The rest of the
    1301                 :            :  * segment will be reserved for this insertion, as indicated by the returned
    1302                 :            :  * *EndPos value. However, if we are already at the beginning of the current
    1303                 :            :  * segment, *StartPos and *EndPos are set to the current location without
    1304                 :            :  * reserving any space, and the function returns false.
    1305                 :            : */
    1306                 :            : static bool
    1307                 :          1 : ReserveXLogSwitch(XLogRecPtr *StartPos, XLogRecPtr *EndPos, XLogRecPtr *PrevPtr)
    1308                 :            : {
    1309                 :          1 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1310                 :            :     uint64      startbytepos;
    1311                 :            :     uint64      endbytepos;
    1312                 :            :     uint64      prevbytepos;
    1313                 :          1 :     uint32      size = MAXALIGN(SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1314                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  ptr;
    1315                 :            :     uint32      segleft;
    1316                 :            : 
    1317                 :            :     /*
    1318                 :            :      * These calculations are a bit heavy-weight to be done while holding a
    1319                 :            :      * spinlock, but since we're holding all the WAL insertion locks, there
    1320                 :            :      * are no other inserters competing for it. GetXLogInsertRecPtr() does
    1321                 :            :      * compete for it, but that's not called very frequently.
    1322                 :            :      */
    1323         [ -  + ]:          1 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1324                 :            : 
    1325                 :          1 :     startbytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1326                 :            : 
    1327                 :          1 :     ptr = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(startbytepos);
    1328         [ -  + ]:          1 :     if (XLogSegmentOffset(ptr, wal_segment_size) == 0)
    1329                 :            :     {
    1330                 :          0 :         SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1331                 :          0 :         *EndPos = *StartPos = ptr;
    1332                 :          0 :         return false;
    1333                 :            :     }
    1334                 :            : 
    1335                 :          1 :     endbytepos = startbytepos + size;
    1336                 :          1 :     prevbytepos = Insert->PrevBytePos;
    1337                 :            : 
    1338                 :          1 :     *StartPos = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(startbytepos);
    1339                 :          1 :     *EndPos = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(endbytepos);
    1340                 :            : 
    1341                 :          1 :     segleft = wal_segment_size - XLogSegmentOffset(*EndPos, wal_segment_size);
    1342         [ +  - ]:          1 :     if (segleft != wal_segment_size)
    1343                 :            :     {
    1344                 :            :         /* consume the rest of the segment */
    1345                 :          1 :         *EndPos += segleft;
    1346                 :          1 :         endbytepos = XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos);
    1347                 :            :     }
    1348                 :          1 :     Insert->CurrBytePos = endbytepos;
    1349                 :          1 :     Insert->PrevBytePos = startbytepos;
    1350                 :            : 
    1351                 :          1 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1352                 :            : 
    1353                 :          1 :     *PrevPtr = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(prevbytepos);
    1354                 :            : 
    1355                 :            :     Assert(XLogSegmentOffset(*EndPos, wal_segment_size) == 0);
    1356                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*EndPos) == endbytepos);
    1357                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*StartPos) == startbytepos);
    1358                 :            :     Assert(XLogRecPtrToBytePos(*PrevPtr) == prevbytepos);
    1359                 :            : 
    1360                 :          1 :     return true;
    1361                 :            : }
    1362                 :            : 
    1363                 :            : /*
    1364                 :            :  * Checks whether the current buffer page and backup page stored in the
    1365                 :            :  * WAL record are consistent or not. Before comparing the two pages, a
    1366                 :            :  * masking can be applied to the pages to ignore certain areas like hint bits,
    1367                 :            :  * unused space between pd_lower and pd_upper among other things. This
    1368                 :            :  * function should be called once WAL replay has been completed for a
    1369                 :            :  * given record.
    1370                 :            :  */
    1371                 :            : static void
    1372                 :          0 : checkXLogConsistency(XLogReaderState *record)
    1373                 :            : {
    1374                 :          0 :     RmgrId      rmid = XLogRecGetRmid(record);
    1375                 :            :     RelFileNode rnode;
    1376                 :            :     ForkNumber  forknum;
    1377                 :            :     BlockNumber blkno;
    1378                 :            :     int         block_id;
    1379                 :            : 
    1380                 :            :     /* Records with no backup blocks have no need for consistency checks. */
    1381         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!XLogRecHasAnyBlockRefs(record))
    1382                 :          0 :         return;
    1383                 :            : 
    1384                 :            :     Assert((XLogRecGetInfo(record) & XLR_CHECK_CONSISTENCY) != 0);
    1385                 :            : 
    1386         [ #  # ]:          0 :     for (block_id = 0; block_id <= record->max_block_id; block_id++)
    1387                 :            :     {
    1388                 :            :         Buffer      buf;
    1389                 :            :         Page        page;
    1390                 :            : 
    1391         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (!XLogRecGetBlockTag(record, block_id, &rnode, &forknum, &blkno))
    1392                 :            :         {
    1393                 :            :             /*
    1394                 :            :              * WAL record doesn't contain a block reference with the given id.
    1395                 :            :              * Do nothing.
    1396                 :            :              */
    1397                 :          0 :             continue;
    1398                 :            :         }
    1399                 :            : 
    1400                 :            :         Assert(XLogRecHasBlockImage(record, block_id));
    1401                 :            : 
    1402         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (XLogRecBlockImageApply(record, block_id))
    1403                 :            :         {
    1404                 :            :             /*
    1405                 :            :              * WAL record has already applied the page, so bypass the
    1406                 :            :              * consistency check as that would result in comparing the full
    1407                 :            :              * page stored in the record with itself.
    1408                 :            :              */
    1409                 :          0 :             continue;
    1410                 :            :         }
    1411                 :            : 
    1412                 :            :         /*
    1413                 :            :          * Read the contents from the current buffer and store it in a
    1414                 :            :          * temporary page.
    1415                 :            :          */

    1417                 :            :                                      RBM_NORMAL_NO_LOG);

    1419                 :          0 :             continue;
    1420                 :            : 
    1421                 :          0 :         LockBuffer(buf, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    1422         [ #  # ]:          0 :         page = BufferGetPage(buf);
    1423                 :            : 
    1424                 :            :         /*
    1425                 :            :          * Take a copy of the local page where WAL has been applied to have a
    1426                 :            :          * comparison base before masking it...
    1427                 :            :          */
    1428                 :          0 :         memcpy(replay_image_masked, page, BLCKSZ);
    1429                 :            : 
    1430                 :            :         /* No need for this page anymore now that a copy is in. */
    1431                 :          0 :         UnlockReleaseBuffer(buf);
    1432                 :            : 
    1433                 :            :         /*
    1434                 :            :          * If the block LSN is already ahead of this WAL record, we can't
    1435                 :            :          * expect contents to match.  This can happen if recovery is
    1436                 :            :          * restarted.
    1437                 :            :          */
    1438         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (PageGetLSN(replay_image_masked) > record->EndRecPtr)
    1439                 :          0 :             continue;
    1440                 :            : 
    1441                 :            :         /*
    1442                 :            :          * Read the contents from the backup copy, stored in WAL record and
    1443                 :            :          * store it in a temporary page. There is no need to allocate a new
    1444                 :            :          * page here, a local buffer is fine to hold its contents and a mask
    1445                 :            :          * can be directly applied on it.
    1446                 :            :          */
    1447         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (!RestoreBlockImage(record, block_id, master_image_masked))
    1448                 :          0 :             elog(ERROR, "failed to restore block image");
    1449                 :            : 
    1450                 :            :         /*
    1451                 :            :          * If masking function is defined, mask both the master and replay

    1455                 :            :         {

    1457                 :          0 :             RmgrTable[rmid].rm_mask(master_image_masked, blkno);
    1458                 :            :         }
    1459                 :            : 
    1460                 :            :         /* Time to compare the master and replay images. */
    1461         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (memcmp(replay_image_masked, master_image_masked, BLCKSZ) != 0)
    1462                 :            :         {
    1463                 :          0 :             elog(FATAL,

    1465                 :            :                  rnode.spcNode, rnode.dbNode, rnode.relNode,
    1466                 :            :                  forknum, blkno);
    1467                 :            :         }
    1468                 :            :     }
    1469                 :            : }
    1470                 :            : 
    1471                 :            : /*
    1472                 :            :  * Subroutine of XLogInsertRecord.  Copies a WAL record to an already-reserved
    1473                 :            :  * area in the WAL.
    1474                 :            :  */
    1475                 :            : static void
    1476                 :    1157941 : CopyXLogRecordToWAL(int write_len, bool isLogSwitch, XLogRecData *rdata,
    1477                 :            :                     XLogRecPtr StartPos, XLogRecPtr EndPos)

    1480                 :            :     int         freespace;

    1482                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  CurrPos;

    1484                 :            : 
    1485                 :            :     /*
    1486                 :            :      * Get a pointer to the right place in the right WAL buffer to start
    1487                 :            :      * inserting to.
    1488                 :            :      */
    1489                 :    1157941 :     CurrPos = StartPos;
    1490                 :    1157941 :     currpos = GetXLogBuffer(CurrPos);
    1491         [ +  - ]:    1157941 :     freespace = INSERT_FREESPACE(CurrPos);
    1492                 :            : 
    1493                 :            :     /*
    1494                 :            :      * there should be enough space for at least the first field (xl_tot_len)
    1495                 :            :      * on this page.
    1496                 :            :      */
    1497                 :            :     Assert(freespace >= sizeof(uint32));
    1498                 :            : 
    1499                 :            :     /* Copy record data */
    1500                 :    1157941 :     written = 0;
    1501         [ +  + ]:    4741046 :     while (rdata != NULL)
    1502                 :            :     {
    1503                 :    3583105 :         char       *rdata_data = rdata->data;
    1504                 :    3583105 :         int         rdata_len = rdata->len;
    1505                 :            : 
    1506         [ +  + ]:    3605613 :         while (rdata_len > freespace)
    1507                 :            :         {
    1508                 :            :             /*
    1509                 :            :              * Write what fits on this page, and continue on the next page.
    1510                 :            :              */
    1511                 :            :             Assert(CurrPos % XLOG_BLCKSZ >= SizeOfXLogShortPHD || freespace == 0);
    1512                 :      22508 :             memcpy(currpos, rdata_data, freespace);
    1513                 :      22508 :             rdata_data += freespace;
    1514                 :      22508 :             rdata_len -= freespace;
    1515                 :      22508 :             written += freespace;
    1516                 :      22508 :             CurrPos += freespace;
    1517                 :            : 
    1518                 :            :             /*
    1519                 :            :              * Get pointer to beginning of next page, and set the xlp_rem_len
    1520                 :            :              * in the page header. Set XLP_FIRST_IS_CONTRECORD.
    1521                 :            :              *
    1522                 :            :              * It's safe to set the contrecord flag and xlp_rem_len without a
    1523                 :            :              * lock on the page. All the other flags were already set when the
    1524                 :            :              * page was initialized, in AdvanceXLInsertBuffer, and we're the
    1525                 :            :              * only backend that needs to set the contrecord flag.
    1526                 :            :              */
    1527                 :      22508 :             currpos = GetXLogBuffer(CurrPos);
    1528                 :      22508 :             pagehdr = (XLogPageHeader) currpos;
    1529                 :      22508 :             pagehdr->xlp_rem_len = write_len - written;
    1530                 :      22508 :             pagehdr->xlp_info |= XLP_FIRST_IS_CONTRECORD;
    1531                 :            : 
    1532                 :            :             /* skip over the page header */
    1533         [ +  + ]:      22508 :             if (XLogSegmentOffset(CurrPos, wal_segment_size) == 0)
    1534                 :            :             {
    1535                 :         10 :                 CurrPos += SizeOfXLogLongPHD;

    1544                 :            :         }
    1545                 :            : 
    1546                 :            :         Assert(CurrPos % XLOG_BLCKSZ >= SizeOfXLogShortPHD || rdata_len == 0);
    1547                 :    3583105 :         memcpy(currpos, rdata_data, rdata_len);
    1548                 :    3583105 :         currpos += rdata_len;

    1555                 :            :     Assert(written == write_len);
    1556                 :            : 
    1557                 :            :     /*
    1558                 :            :      * If this was an xlog-switch, it's not enough to write the switch record,
    1559                 :            :      * we also have to consume all the remaining space in the WAL segment.  We
    1560                 :            :      * have already reserved that space, but we need to actually fill it.
    1561                 :            :      */
    1562 [ +  + ][ +  - ]:    1157942 :     if (isLogSwitch && XLogSegmentOffset(CurrPos, wal_segment_size) != 0)
    1563                 :            :     {
    1564                 :            :         /* An xlog-switch record doesn't contain any data besides the header */
    1565                 :            :         Assert(write_len == SizeOfXLogRecord);
    1566                 :            : 
    1567                 :            :         /* Assert that we did reserve the right amount of space */
    1568                 :            :         Assert(XLogSegmentOffset(EndPos, wal_segment_size) == 0);
    1569                 :            : 
    1570                 :            :         /* Use up all the remaining space on the current page */
    1571                 :          1 :         CurrPos += freespace;
    1572                 :            : 
    1573                 :            :         /*
    1574                 :            :          * Cause all remaining pages in the segment to be flushed, leaving the
    1575                 :            :          * XLog position where it should be, at the start of the next segment.
    1576                 :            :          * We do this one page at a time, to make sure we don't deadlock
    1577                 :            :          * against ourselves if wal_buffers < wal_segment_size.
    1578                 :            :          */
    1579         [ +  + ]:        924 :         while (CurrPos < EndPos)
    1580                 :            :         {
    1581                 :            :             /*
    1582                 :            :              * The minimal action to flush the page would be to call
    1583                 :            :              * WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(CurrPos) followed by
    1584                 :            :              * AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(...).  The page would be left initialized
    1585                 :            :              * mostly to zeros, except for the page header (always the short
    1586                 :            :              * variant, as this is never a segment's first page).
    1587                 :            :              *
    1588                 :            :              * The large vistas of zeros are good for compressibility, but the
    1589                 :            :              * headers interrupting them every XLOG_BLCKSZ (with values that
    1590                 :            :              * differ from page to page) are not.  The effect varies with
    1591                 :            :              * compression tool, but bzip2 for instance compresses about an
    1592                 :            :              * order of magnitude worse if those headers are left in place.
    1593                 :            :              *
    1594                 :            :              * Rather than complicating AdvanceXLInsertBuffer itself (which is
    1595                 :            :              * called in heavily-loaded circumstances as well as this lightly-
    1596                 :            :              * loaded one) with variant behavior, we just use GetXLogBuffer
    1597                 :            :              * (which itself calls the two methods we need) to get the pointer
    1598                 :            :              * and zero most of the page.  Then we just zero the page header.
    1599                 :            :              */
    1600                 :        923 :             currpos = GetXLogBuffer(CurrPos);
    1601 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:       3692 :             MemSet(currpos, 0, SizeOfXLogShortPHD);
         [ +  - ][ +  - ]
                 [ +  + ]
    1602                 :            : 
    1603                 :        923 :             CurrPos += XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1604                 :            :         }
    1605                 :            :     }
    1606                 :            :     else
    1607                 :            :     {
    1608                 :            :         /* Align the end position, so that the next record starts aligned */
    1609                 :    1157940 :         CurrPos = MAXALIGN64(CurrPos);
    1610                 :            :     }
    1611                 :            : 
    1612         [ -  + ]:    1157941 :     if (CurrPos != EndPos)
    1613                 :          0 :         elog(PANIC, "space reserved for WAL record does not match what was written");
    1614                 :    1157941 : }
    1615                 :            : 
    1616                 :            : /*
    1617                 :            :  * Acquire a WAL insertion lock, for inserting to WAL.
    1618                 :            :  */
    1619                 :            : static void
    1620                 :    1157940 : WALInsertLockAcquire(void)
    1621                 :            : {
    1622                 :            :     bool        immed;
    1623                 :            : 
    1624                 :            :     /*
    1625                 :            :      * It doesn't matter which of the WAL insertion locks we acquire, so try
    1626                 :            :      * the one we used last time.  If the system isn't particularly busy, it's
    1627                 :            :      * a good bet that it's still available, and it's good to have some
    1628                 :            :      * affinity to a particular lock so that you don't unnecessarily bounce
    1629                 :            :      * cache lines between processes when there's no contention.
    1630                 :            :      *
    1631                 :            :      * If this is the first time through in this backend, pick a lock
    1632                 :            :      * (semi-)randomly.  This allows the locks to be used evenly if you have a
    1633                 :            :      * lot of very short connections.
    1634                 :            :      */
    1635                 :            :     static int  lockToTry = -1;
    1636                 :            : 
    1637         [ +  + ]:    1157940 :     if (lockToTry == -1)
    1638                 :        832 :         lockToTry = MyProc->pgprocno % NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS;
    1639                 :    1157940 :     MyLockNo = lockToTry;
    1640                 :            : 
    1641                 :            :     /*
    1642                 :            :      * The insertingAt value is initially set to 0, as we don't know our
    1643                 :            :      * insert location yet.
    1644                 :            :      */
    1645                 :    1157940 :     immed = LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1646         [ +  + ]:    1157940 :     if (!immed)
    1647                 :            :     {
    1648                 :            :         /*
    1649                 :            :          * If we couldn't get the lock immediately, try another lock next
    1650                 :            :          * time.  On a system with more insertion locks than concurrent
    1651                 :            :          * inserters, this causes all the inserters to eventually migrate to a
    1652                 :            :          * lock that no-one else is using.  On a system with more inserters
    1653                 :            :          * than locks, it still helps to distribute the inserters evenly
    1654                 :            :          * across the locks.
    1655                 :            :          */
    1656                 :          1 :         lockToTry = (lockToTry + 1) % NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS;
    1657                 :            :     }
    1658                 :    1157940 : }
    1659                 :            : 
    1660                 :            : /*
    1661                 :            :  * Acquire all WAL insertion locks, to prevent other backends from inserting
    1662                 :            :  * to WAL.
    1663                 :            :  */
    1664                 :            : static void
    1665                 :         77 : WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive(void)
    1666                 :            : {
    1667                 :            :     int         i;
    1668                 :            : 
    1669                 :            :     /*
    1670                 :            :      * When holding all the locks, all but the last lock's insertingAt
    1671                 :            :      * indicator is set to 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF, which is higher than any real
    1672                 :            :      * XLogRecPtr value, to make sure that no-one blocks waiting on those.
    1673                 :            :      */
    1674         [ +  + ]:        616 :     for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1; i++)
    1675                 :            :     {
    1676                 :        539 :         LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1677                 :        539 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1678                 :        539 :                         &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1679                 :            :                         PG_UINT64_MAX);
    1680                 :            :     }
    1681                 :            :     /* Variable value reset to 0 at release */
    1682                 :         77 :     LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    1683                 :            : 
    1684                 :         77 :     holdingAllLocks = true;
    1685                 :         77 : }
    1686                 :            : 
    1687                 :            : /*
    1688                 :            :  * Release our insertion lock (or locks, if we're holding them all).
    1689                 :            :  *
    1690                 :            :  * NB: Reset all variables to 0, so they cause LWLockWaitForVar to block the
    1691                 :            :  * next time the lock is acquired.
    1692                 :            :  */
    1693                 :            : static void
    1694                 :    1158017 : WALInsertLockRelease(void)
    1695                 :            : {
    1696         [ +  + ]:    1158017 :     if (holdingAllLocks)
    1697                 :            :     {
    1698                 :            :         int         i;
    1699                 :            : 
    1700         [ +  + ]:        693 :         for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS; i++)
    1701                 :        616 :             LWLockReleaseClearVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1702                 :        616 :                                   &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1703                 :            :                                   0);
    1704                 :            : 
    1705                 :         77 :         holdingAllLocks = false;
    1706                 :            :     }
    1707                 :            :     else
    1708                 :            :     {
    1709                 :    1157940 :         LWLockReleaseClearVar(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock,
    1710                 :    1157940 :                               &WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.insertingAt,
    1711                 :            :                               0);
    1712                 :            :     }
    1713                 :    1158017 : }
    1714                 :            : 
    1715                 :            : /*
    1716                 :            :  * Update our insertingAt value, to let others know that we've finished
    1717                 :            :  * inserting up to that point.
    1718                 :            :  */
    1719                 :            : static void
    1720                 :          0 : WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(XLogRecPtr insertingAt)
    1721                 :            : {
    1722         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (holdingAllLocks)
    1723                 :            :     {
    1724                 :            :         /*
    1725                 :            :          * We use the last lock to mark our actual position, see comments in
    1726                 :            :          * WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive.
    1727                 :            :          */
    1728                 :          0 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1].l.lock,
    1729                 :          0 :                         &WALInsertLocks[NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS - 1].l.insertingAt,
    1730                 :            :                         insertingAt);
    1731                 :            :     }
    1732                 :            :     else
    1733                 :          0 :         LWLockUpdateVar(&WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.lock,
    1734                 :          0 :                         &WALInsertLocks[MyLockNo].l.insertingAt,
    1735                 :            :                         insertingAt);
    1736                 :          0 : }
    1737                 :            : 
    1738                 :            : /*
    1739                 :            :  * Wait for any WAL insertions < upto to finish.
    1740                 :            :  *
    1741                 :            :  * Returns the location of the oldest insertion that is still in-progress.
    1742                 :            :  * Any WAL prior to that point has been fully copied into WAL buffers, and
    1743                 :            :  * can be flushed out to disk. Because this waits for any insertions older
    1744                 :            :  * than 'upto' to finish, the return value is always >= 'upto'.
    1745                 :            :  *
    1746                 :            :  * Note: When you are about to write out WAL, you must call this function
    1747                 :            :  * *before* acquiring WALWriteLock, to avoid deadlocks. This function might
    1748                 :            :  * need to wait for an insertion to finish (or at least advance to next
    1749                 :            :  * uninitialized page), and the inserter might need to evict an old WAL buffer
    1750                 :            :  * to make room for a new one, which in turn requires WALWriteLock.
    1751                 :            :  */
    1752                 :            : static XLogRecPtr
    1753                 :     100106 : WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(XLogRecPtr upto)
    1754                 :            : {
    1755                 :            :     uint64      bytepos;
    1756                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  reservedUpto;
    1757                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  finishedUpto;
    1758                 :     100106 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    1759                 :            :     int         i;
    1760                 :            : 
    1761         [ -  + ]:     100106 :     if (MyProc == NULL)
    1762                 :          0 :         elog(PANIC, "cannot wait without a PGPROC structure");
    1763                 :            : 
    1764                 :            :     /* Read the current insert position */
    1765         [ -  + ]:     100106 :     SpinLockAcquire(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1766                 :     100106 :     bytepos = Insert->CurrBytePos;
    1767                 :     100106 :     SpinLockRelease(&Insert->insertpos_lck);
    1768                 :     100106 :     reservedUpto = XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(bytepos);
    1769                 :            : 
    1770                 :            :     /*
    1771                 :            :      * No-one should request to flush a piece of WAL that hasn't even been
    1772                 :            :      * reserved yet. However, it can happen if there is a block with a bogus
    1773                 :            :      * LSN on disk, for example. XLogFlush checks for that situation and
    1774                 :            :      * complains, but only after the flush. Here we just assume that to mean
    1775                 :            :      * that all WAL that has been reserved needs to be finished. In this
    1776                 :            :      * corner-case, the return value can be smaller than 'upto' argument.
    1777                 :            :      */
    1778         [ -  + ]:     100106 :     if (upto > reservedUpto)
    1779                 :            :     {
    1780                 :          0 :         elog(LOG, "request to flush past end of generated WAL; request %X/%X, currpos %X/%X",
    1781                 :            :              (uint32) (upto >> 32), (uint32) upto,
    1782                 :            :              (uint32) (reservedUpto >> 32), (uint32) reservedUpto);
    1783                 :          0 :         upto = reservedUpto;
    1784                 :            :     }
    1785                 :            : 
    1786                 :            :     /*
    1787                 :            :      * Loop through all the locks, sleeping on any in-progress insert older
    1788                 :            :      * than 'upto'.
    1789                 :            :      *
    1790                 :            :      * finishedUpto is our return value, indicating the point upto which all
    1791                 :            :      * the WAL insertions have been finished. Initialize it to the head of
    1792                 :            :      * reserved WAL, and as we iterate through the insertion locks, back it
    1793                 :            :      * out for any insertion that's still in progress.
    1794                 :            :      */
    1795                 :     100106 :     finishedUpto = reservedUpto;
    1796         [ +  + ]:     900954 :     for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS; i++)
    1797                 :            :     {
    1798                 :     800848 :         XLogRecPtr  insertingat = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    1799                 :            : 
    1800                 :            :         do
    1801                 :            :         {
    1802                 :            :             /*
    1803                 :            :              * See if this insertion is in progress. LWLockWait will wait for
    1804                 :            :              * the lock to be released, or for the 'value' to be set by a
    1805                 :            :              * LWLockUpdateVar call.  When a lock is initially acquired, its
    1806                 :            :              * value is 0 (InvalidXLogRecPtr), which means that we don't know
    1807                 :            :              * where it's inserting yet.  We will have to wait for it.  If
    1808                 :            :              * it's a small insertion, the record will most likely fit on the
    1809                 :            :              * same page and the inserter will release the lock without ever
    1810                 :            :              * calling LWLockUpdateVar.  But if it has to sleep, it will
    1811                 :            :              * advertise the insertion point with LWLockUpdateVar before
    1812                 :            :              * sleeping.
    1813                 :            :              */
    1814         [ +  - ]:     800848 :             if (LWLockWaitForVar(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock,
    1815                 :     800848 :                                  &WALInsertLocks[i].l.insertingAt,
    1816                 :            :                                  insertingat, &insertingat))
    1817                 :            :             {
    1818                 :            :                 /* the lock was free, so no insertion in progress */
    1819                 :     800848 :                 insertingat = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    1820                 :     800848 :                 break;
    1821                 :            :             }
    1822                 :            : 
    1823                 :            :             /*
    1824                 :            :              * This insertion is still in progress. Have to wait, unless the
    1825                 :            :              * inserter has proceeded past 'upto'.
    1826                 :            :              */
    1827         [ #  # ]:          0 :         } while (insertingat < upto);
    1828                 :            : 
    1829 [ -  + ][ #  # ]:     800848 :         if (insertingat != InvalidXLogRecPtr && insertingat < finishedUpto)
    1830                 :          0 :             finishedUpto = insertingat;
    1831                 :            :     }
    1832                 :     100106 :     return finishedUpto;
    1833                 :            : }
    1834                 :            : 
    1835                 :            : /*
    1836                 :            :  * Get a pointer to the right location in the WAL buffer containing the
    1837                 :            :  * given XLogRecPtr.
    1838                 :            :  *
    1839                 :            :  * If the page is not initialized yet, it is initialized. That might require
    1840                 :            :  * evicting an old dirty buffer from the buffer cache, which means I/O.
    1841                 :            :  *
    1842                 :            :  * The caller must ensure that the page containing the requested location
    1843                 :            :  * isn't evicted yet, and won't be evicted. The way to ensure that is to
    1844                 :            :  * hold onto a WAL insertion lock with the insertingAt position set to
    1845                 :            :  * something <= ptr. GetXLogBuffer() will update insertingAt if it needs
    1846                 :            :  * to evict an old page from the buffer. (This means that once you call
    1847                 :            :  * GetXLogBuffer() with a given 'ptr', you must not access anything before
    1848                 :            :  * that point anymore, and must not call GetXLogBuffer() with an older 'ptr'
    1849                 :            :  * later, because older buffers might be recycled already)
    1850                 :            :  */
    1851                 :            : static char *
    1852                 :    1181372 : GetXLogBuffer(XLogRecPtr ptr)
    1853                 :            : {
    1854                 :            :     int         idx;
    1855                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  endptr;
    1856                 :            :     static uint64 cachedPage = 0;
    1857                 :            :     static char *cachedPos = NULL;
    1858                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  expectedEndPtr;
    1859                 :            : 
    1860                 :            :     /*
    1861                 :            :      * Fast path for the common case that we need to access again the same
    1862                 :            :      * page as last time.
    1863                 :            :      */
    1864         [ +  + ]:    1181372 :     if (ptr / XLOG_BLCKSZ == cachedPage)
    1865                 :            :     {
    1866                 :            :         Assert(((XLogPageHeader) cachedPos)->xlp_magic == XLOG_PAGE_MAGIC);
    1867                 :            :         Assert(((XLogPageHeader) cachedPos)->xlp_pageaddr == ptr - (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ));
    1868                 :    1149441 :         return cachedPos + ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1869                 :            :     }
    1870                 :            : 
    1871                 :            :     /*
    1872                 :            :      * The XLog buffer cache is organized so that a page is always loaded to a
    1873                 :            :      * particular buffer.  That way we can easily calculate the buffer a given
    1874                 :            :      * page must be loaded into, from the XLogRecPtr alone.
    1875                 :            :      */
    1876                 :      31931 :     idx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(ptr);
    1877                 :            : 
    1878                 :            :     /*
    1879                 :            :      * See what page is loaded in the buffer at the moment. It could be the
    1880                 :            :      * page we're looking for, or something older. It can't be anything newer
    1881                 :            :      * - that would imply the page we're looking for has already been written
    1882                 :            :      * out to disk and evicted, and the caller is responsible for making sure
    1883                 :            :      * that doesn't happen.
    1884                 :            :      *
    1885                 :            :      * However, we don't hold a lock while we read the value. If someone has
    1886                 :            :      * just initialized the page, it's possible that we get a "torn read" of
    1887                 :            :      * the XLogRecPtr if 64-bit fetches are not atomic on this platform. In
    1888                 :            :      * that case we will see a bogus value. That's ok, we'll grab the mapping
    1889                 :            :      * lock (in AdvanceXLInsertBuffer) and retry if we see anything else than
    1890                 :            :      * the page we're looking for. But it means that when we do this unlocked
    1891                 :            :      * read, we might see a value that appears to be ahead of the page we're
    1892                 :            :      * looking for. Don't PANIC on that, until we've verified the value while
    1893                 :            :      * holding the lock.
    1894                 :            :      */
    1895                 :      31931 :     expectedEndPtr = ptr;
    1896                 :      31931 :     expectedEndPtr += XLOG_BLCKSZ - ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    1897                 :            : 
    1898                 :      31931 :     endptr = XLogCtl->xlblocks[idx];
    1899         [ -  + ]:      31931 :     if (expectedEndPtr != endptr)
    1900                 :            :     {
    1901                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  initializedUpto;
    1902                 :            : 
    1903                 :            :         /*
    1904                 :            :          * Before calling AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(), which can block, let others
    1905                 :            :          * know how far we're finished with inserting the record.
    1906                 :            :          *
    1907                 :            :          * NB: If 'ptr' points to just after the page header, advertise a
    1908                 :            :          * position at the beginning of the page rather than 'ptr' itself. If
    1909                 :            :          * there are no other insertions running, someone might try to flush
    1910                 :            :          * up to our advertised location. If we advertised a position after
    1911                 :            :          * the page header, someone might try to flush the page header, even
    1912                 :            :          * though page might actually not be initialized yet. As the first
    1913                 :            :          * inserter on the page, we are effectively responsible for making
    1914                 :            :          * sure that it's initialized, before we let insertingAt to move past
    1915                 :            :          * the page header.
    1916                 :            :          */
    1917 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :         if (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ == SizeOfXLogShortPHD &&
    1918                 :          0 :             XLogSegmentOffset(ptr, wal_segment_size) > XLOG_BLCKSZ)
    1919                 :          0 :             initializedUpto = ptr - SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    1920 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :         else if (ptr % XLOG_BLCKSZ == SizeOfXLogLongPHD &&

    1922                 :          0 :             initializedUpto = ptr - SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    1923                 :            :         else
    1924                 :          0 :             initializedUpto = ptr;
    1925                 :            : 
    1926                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockUpdateInsertingAt(initializedUpto);

    1928                 :          0 :         AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(ptr, false);

    1934                 :            :     }
    1935                 :            :     else
    1936                 :            :     {
    1937                 :            :         /*

    1939                 :            :          * won't arrive later to overwrite the WAL data we write on the page.

    1943                 :            :

    1945                 :            :      * Found the buffer holding this page. Return a pointer to the right

    1956                 :            : 
    1957                 :            : /*
    1958                 :            :  * Converts a "usable byte position" to XLogRecPtr. A usable byte position
    1959                 :            :  * is the position starting from the beginning of WAL, excluding all WAL
    1960                 :            :  * page headers.

    1962                 :            : static XLogRecPtr
    1963                 :    2780740 : XLogBytePosToRecPtr(uint64 bytepos)

    1996                 :            : /*
    1997                 :            :  * Like XLogBytePosToRecPtr, but if the position is at a page boundary,
    1998                 :            :  * returns a pointer to the beginning of the page (ie. before page header),
    1999                 :            :  * not to where the first xlog record on that page would go to. This is used

    2003                 :    1258048 : XLogBytePosToEndRecPtr(uint64 bytepos)

    2081                 :            : 
    2082                 :            : /*
    2083                 :            :  * Initialize XLOG buffers, writing out old buffers if they still contain
    2084                 :            :  * unwritten data, upto the page containing 'upto'. Or if 'opportunistic' is
    2085                 :            :  * true, initialize as many pages as we can without having to write out
    2086                 :            :  * unwritten data. Any new pages are initialized to zeros, with pages headers
    2087                 :            :  * initialized properly.
    2088                 :            :  */
    2089                 :            : static void
    2090                 :      15379 : AdvanceXLInsertBuffer(XLogRecPtr upto, bool opportunistic)
    2091                 :            : {
    2092                 :      15379 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    2093                 :            :     int         nextidx;
    2094                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  OldPageRqstPtr;
    2095                 :            :     XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst;
    2096                 :      15379 :     XLogRecPtr  NewPageEndPtr = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    2097                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  NewPageBeginPtr;
    2098                 :            :     XLogPageHeader NewPage;
    2099                 :      15379 :     int         npages = 0;
    2100                 :            : 
    2101                 :      15379 :     LWLockAcquire(WALBufMappingLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    2102                 :            : 
    2103                 :            :     /*
    2104                 :            :      * Now that we have the lock, check if someone initialized the page
    2105                 :            :      * already.
    2106                 :            :      */
    2107 [ -  + ][ +  - ]:      47222 :     while (upto >= XLogCtl->InitializedUpTo || opportunistic)
    2108                 :            :     {
    2109                 :      47222 :         nextidx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(XLogCtl->InitializedUpTo);
    2110                 :            : 
    2111                 :            :         /*
    2112                 :            :          * Get ending-offset of the buffer page we need to replace (this may
    2113                 :            :          * be zero if the buffer hasn't been used yet).  Fall through if it's
    2114                 :            :          * already written out.
    2115                 :            :          */
    2116                 :      47222 :         OldPageRqstPtr = XLogCtl->xlblocks[nextidx];
    2117         [ +  + ]:      47222 :         if (LogwrtResult.Write < OldPageRqstPtr)
    2118                 :            :         {
    2119                 :            :             /*
    2120                 :            :              * Nope, got work to do. If we just want to pre-initialize as much
    2121                 :            :              * as we can without flushing, give up now.
    2122                 :            :              */
    2123         [ +  - ]:      15379 :             if (opportunistic)
    2124                 :      15379 :                 break;
    2125                 :            : 
    2126                 :            :             /* Before waiting, get info_lck and update LogwrtResult */
    2127         [ #  # ]:          0 :             SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2128         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write < OldPageRqstPtr)
    2129                 :          0 :                 XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write = OldPageRqstPtr;
    2130                 :          0 :             LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2131                 :          0 :             SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2132                 :            : 
    2133                 :            :             /*
    2134                 :            :              * Now that we have an up-to-date LogwrtResult value, see if we
    2135                 :            :              * still need to write it or if someone else already did.
    2136                 :            :              */
    2137         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (LogwrtResult.Write < OldPageRqstPtr)
    2138                 :            :             {
    2139                 :            :                 /*
    2140                 :            :                  * Must acquire write lock. Release WALBufMappingLock first,
    2141                 :            :                  * to make sure that all insertions that we need to wait for
    2142                 :            :                  * can finish (up to this same position). Otherwise we risk
    2143                 :            :                  * deadlock.
    2144                 :            :                  */
    2145                 :          0 :                 LWLockRelease(WALBufMappingLock);
    2146                 :            : 
    2147                 :          0 :                 WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(OldPageRqstPtr);
    2148                 :            : 
    2149                 :          0 :                 LWLockAcquire(WALWriteLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    2150                 :            : 
    2151                 :          0 :                 LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2152         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 if (LogwrtResult.Write >= OldPageRqstPtr)
    2153                 :            :                 {
    2154                 :            :                     /* OK, someone wrote it already */
    2155                 :          0 :                     LWLockRelease(WALWriteLock);
    2156                 :            :                 }
    2157                 :            :                 else
    2158                 :            :                 {
    2159                 :            :                     /* Have to write it ourselves */
    2160                 :          0 :                     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_WAL_BUFFER_WRITE_DIRTY_START();
    2161                 :          0 :                     WriteRqst.Write = OldPageRqstPtr;
    2162                 :          0 :                     WriteRqst.Flush = 0;
    2163                 :          0 :                     XLogWrite(WriteRqst, false);
    2164                 :          0 :                     LWLockRelease(WALWriteLock);
    2165                 :          0 :                     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_WAL_BUFFER_WRITE_DIRTY_DONE();

    2167                 :            :                 /* Re-acquire WALBufMappingLock and retry */
    2168                 :          0 :                 LWLockAcquire(WALBufMappingLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    2169                 :          0 :                 continue;
    2170                 :            :             }
    2171                 :            :         }
    2172                 :            : 
    2173                 :            :         /*
    2174                 :            :          * Now the next buffer slot is free and we can set it up to be the
    2175                 :            :          * next output page.
    2176                 :            :          */
    2177                 :      31843 :         NewPageBeginPtr = XLogCtl->InitializedUpTo;
    2178                 :      31843 :         NewPageEndPtr = NewPageBeginPtr + XLOG_BLCKSZ;
    2179                 :            : 
    2180                 :            :         Assert(XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(NewPageBeginPtr) == nextidx);
    2181                 :            : 
    2182                 :      31843 :         NewPage = (XLogPageHeader) (XLogCtl->pages + nextidx * (Size) XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    2183                 :            : 
    2184                 :            :         /*
    2185                 :            :          * Be sure to re-zero the buffer so that bytes beyond what we've
    2186                 :            :          * written will look like zeroes and not valid XLOG records...
    2187                 :            :          */
    2188 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:      31843 :         MemSet((char *) NewPage, 0, XLOG_BLCKSZ);
         [ +  - ][ -  + ]
                 [ #  # ]
    2189                 :            : 
    2190                 :            :         /*
    2191                 :            :          * Fill the new page's header
    2192                 :            :          */
    2193                 :      31843 :         NewPage->xlp_magic = XLOG_PAGE_MAGIC;
    2194                 :            : 
    2195                 :            :         /* NewPage->xlp_info = 0; */ /* done by memset */
    2196                 :      31843 :         NewPage->xlp_tli = ThisTimeLineID;
    2197                 :      31843 :         NewPage->xlp_pageaddr = NewPageBeginPtr;
    2198                 :            : 
    2199                 :            :         /* NewPage->xlp_rem_len = 0; */  /* done by memset */
    2200                 :            : 
    2201                 :            :         /*
    2202                 :            :          * If online backup is not in progress, mark the header to indicate
    2203                 :            :          * that WAL records beginning in this page have removable backup
    2204                 :            :          * blocks.  This allows the WAL archiver to know whether it is safe to
    2205                 :            :          * compress archived WAL data by transforming full-block records into
    2206                 :            :          * the non-full-block format.  It is sufficient to record this at the
    2207                 :            :          * page level because we force a page switch (in fact a segment
    2208                 :            :          * switch) when starting a backup, so the flag will be off before any
    2209                 :            :          * records can be written during the backup.  At the end of a backup,
    2210                 :            :          * the last page will be marked as all unsafe when perhaps only part
    2211                 :            :          * is unsafe, but at worst the archiver would miss the opportunity to
    2212                 :            :          * compress a few records.
    2213                 :            :          */
    2214         [ +  - ]:      31843 :         if (!Insert->forcePageWrites)
    2215                 :      31843 :             NewPage->xlp_info |= XLP_BKP_REMOVABLE;
    2216                 :            : 
    2217                 :            :         /*
    2218                 :            :          * If first page of an XLOG segment file, make it a long header.
    2219                 :            :          */
    2220         [ +  + ]:      31843 :         if ((XLogSegmentOffset(NewPage->xlp_pageaddr, wal_segment_size)) == 0)

    2222                 :         15 :             XLogLongPageHeader NewLongPage = (XLogLongPageHeader) NewPage;

    2252                 :      15379 : }
    2253                 :            : 
    2254                 :            : /*
    2255                 :            :  * Calculate CheckPointSegments based on max_wal_size_mb and
    2256                 :            :  * checkpoint_completion_target.
    2257                 :            :  */
    2258                 :            : static void
    2259                 :       4365 : CalculateCheckpointSegments(void)
    2260                 :            : {
    2261                 :            :     double      target;
    2262                 :            : 
    2263                 :            :     /*-------
    2264                 :            :      * Calculate the distance at which to trigger a checkpoint, to avoid
    2265                 :            :      * exceeding max_wal_size_mb. This is based on two assumptions:
    2266                 :            :      *
    2267                 :            :      * a) we keep WAL for only one checkpoint cycle (prior to PG11 we kept
    2268                 :            :      *    WAL for two checkpoint cycles to allow us to recover from the
    2269                 :            :      *    secondary checkpoint if the first checkpoint failed, though we
    2270                 :            :      *    only did this on the master anyway, not on standby. Keeping just
    2271                 :            :      *    one checkpoint simplifies processing and reduces disk space in
    2272                 :            :      *    many smaller databases.)
    2273                 :            :      * b) during checkpoint, we consume checkpoint_completion_target *
    2274                 :            :      *    number of segments consumed between checkpoints.
    2275                 :            :      *-------
    2276                 :            :      */
    2277                 :       8730 :     target = (double) ConvertToXSegs(max_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) /
    2278                 :       4365 :         (1.0 + CheckPointCompletionTarget);
    2279                 :            : 
    2280                 :            :     /* round down */
    2281                 :       4365 :     CheckPointSegments = (int) target;
    2282                 :            : 
    2283         [ -  + ]:       4365 :     if (CheckPointSegments < 1)
    2284                 :          0 :         CheckPointSegments = 1;
    2285                 :       4365 : }
    2286                 :            : 
    2287                 :            : void
    2288                 :       2910 : assign_max_wal_size(int newval, void *extra)
    2289                 :            : {
    2290                 :       2910 :     max_wal_size_mb = newval;
    2291                 :       2910 :     CalculateCheckpointSegments();
    2292                 :       2910 : }
    2293                 :            : 
    2294                 :            : void
    2295                 :          0 : assign_checkpoint_completion_target(double newval, void *extra)
    2296                 :            : {
    2297                 :          0 :     CheckPointCompletionTarget = newval;
    2298                 :          0 :     CalculateCheckpointSegments();
    2299                 :          0 : }
    2300                 :            : 
    2301                 :            : /*
    2302                 :            :  * At a checkpoint, how many WAL segments to recycle as preallocated future
    2303                 :            :  * XLOG segments? Returns the highest segment that should be preallocated.
    2304                 :            :  */
    2305                 :            : static XLogSegNo
    2306                 :         12 : XLOGfileslop(XLogRecPtr lastredoptr)
    2307                 :            : {
    2308                 :            :     XLogSegNo   minSegNo;
    2309                 :            :     XLogSegNo   maxSegNo;
    2310                 :            :     double      distance;
    2311                 :            :     XLogSegNo   recycleSegNo;
    2312                 :            : 
    2313                 :            :     /*
    2314                 :            :      * Calculate the segment numbers that min_wal_size_mb and max_wal_size_mb
    2315                 :            :      * correspond to. Always recycle enough segments to meet the minimum, and
    2316                 :            :      * remove enough segments to stay below the maximum.
    2317                 :            :      */
    2318                 :         24 :     minSegNo = lastredoptr / wal_segment_size +
    2319                 :         12 :         ConvertToXSegs(min_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) - 1;
    2320                 :         24 :     maxSegNo = lastredoptr / wal_segment_size +
    2321                 :         12 :         ConvertToXSegs(max_wal_size_mb, wal_segment_size) - 1;
    2322                 :            : 
    2323                 :            :     /*
    2324                 :            :      * Between those limits, recycle enough segments to get us through to the
    2325                 :            :      * estimated end of next checkpoint.
    2326                 :            :      *
    2327                 :            :      * To estimate where the next checkpoint will finish, assume that the
    2328                 :            :      * system runs steadily consuming CheckPointDistanceEstimate bytes between
    2329                 :            :      * every checkpoint.
    2330                 :            :      */
    2331                 :         12 :     distance = (1.0 + CheckPointCompletionTarget) * CheckPointDistanceEstimate;
    2332                 :            :     /* add 10% for good measure. */
    2333                 :         12 :     distance *= 1.10;
    2334                 :            : 
    2335                 :         12 :     recycleSegNo = (XLogSegNo) ceil(((double) lastredoptr + distance) /
    2336                 :            :                                     wal_segment_size);
    2337                 :            : 
    2338         [ +  + ]:         12 :     if (recycleSegNo < minSegNo)
    2339                 :         10 :         recycleSegNo = minSegNo;
    2340         [ -  + ]:         12 :     if (recycleSegNo > maxSegNo)
    2341                 :          0 :         recycleSegNo = maxSegNo;
    2342                 :            : 
    2343                 :         12 :     return recycleSegNo;
    2344                 :            : }
    2345                 :            : 
    2346                 :            : /*
    2347                 :            :  * Check whether we've consumed enough xlog space that a checkpoint is needed.
    2348                 :            :  *
    2349                 :            :  * new_segno indicates a log file that has just been filled up (or read
    2350                 :            :  * during recovery). We measure the distance from RedoRecPtr to new_segno
    2351                 :            :  * and see if that exceeds CheckPointSegments.
    2352                 :            :  *
    2353                 :            :  * Note: it is caller's responsibility that RedoRecPtr is up-to-date.
    2354                 :            :  */
    2355                 :            : static bool
    2356                 :         12 : XLogCheckpointNeeded(XLogSegNo new_segno)
    2357                 :            : {
    2358                 :            :     XLogSegNo   old_segno;
    2359                 :            : 
    2360                 :         12 :     XLByteToSeg(RedoRecPtr, old_segno, wal_segment_size);
    2361                 :            : 
    2362         [ -  + ]:         12 :     if (new_segno >= old_segno + (uint64) (CheckPointSegments - 1))
    2363                 :          0 :         return true;
    2364                 :         12 :     return false;
    2365                 :            : }
    2366                 :            : 
    2367                 :            : /*
    2368                 :            :  * Write and/or fsync the log at least as far as WriteRqst indicates.
    2369                 :            :  *
    2370                 :            :  * If flexible == true, we don't have to write as far as WriteRqst, but
    2371                 :            :  * may stop at any convenient boundary (such as a cache or logfile boundary).
    2372                 :            :  * This option allows us to avoid uselessly issuing multiple writes when a
    2373                 :            :  * single one would do.
    2374                 :            :  *
    2375                 :            :  * Must be called with WALWriteLock held. WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(WriteRqst)
    2376                 :            :  * must be called before grabbing the lock, to make sure the data is ready to
    2377                 :            :  * write.
    2378                 :            :  */
    2379                 :            : static void
    2380                 :      90737 : XLogWrite(XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst, bool flexible)
    2381                 :            : {
    2382                 :            :     bool        ispartialpage;
    2383                 :            :     bool        last_iteration;
    2384                 :            :     bool        finishing_seg;
    2385                 :            :     bool        use_existent;
    2386                 :            :     int         curridx;
    2387                 :            :     int         npages;
    2388                 :            :     int         startidx;
    2389                 :            :     uint32      startoffset;
    2390                 :            : 
    2391                 :            :     /* We should always be inside a critical section here */
    2392                 :            :     Assert(CritSectionCount > 0);
    2393                 :            : 
    2394                 :            :     /*
    2395                 :            :      * Update local LogwrtResult (caller probably did this already, but...)
    2396                 :            :      */
    2397                 :      90737 :     LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2398                 :            : 
    2399                 :            :     /*
    2400                 :            :      * Since successive pages in the xlog cache are consecutively allocated,
    2401                 :            :      * we can usually gather multiple pages together and issue just one
    2402                 :            :      * write() call.  npages is the number of pages we have determined can be
    2403                 :            :      * written together; startidx is the cache block index of the first one,
    2404                 :            :      * and startoffset is the file offset at which it should go. The latter
    2405                 :            :      * two variables are only valid when npages > 0, but we must initialize
    2406                 :            :      * all of them to keep the compiler quiet.
    2407                 :            :      */
    2408                 :      90737 :     npages = 0;
    2409                 :      90737 :     startidx = 0;
    2410                 :      90737 :     startoffset = 0;
    2411                 :            : 
    2412                 :            :     /*
    2413                 :            :      * Within the loop, curridx is the cache block index of the page to
    2414                 :            :      * consider writing.  Begin at the buffer containing the next unwritten
    2415                 :            :      * page, or last partially written page.
    2416                 :            :      */
    2417                 :      90737 :     curridx = XLogRecPtrToBufIdx(LogwrtResult.Write);
    2418                 :            : 
    2419         [ +  + ]:     110459 :     while (LogwrtResult.Write < WriteRqst.Write)
    2420                 :            :     {

    2422                 :            :          * Make sure we're not ahead of the insert process.  This could happen
    2423                 :            :          * if we're passed a bogus WriteRqst.Write that is past the end of the
    2424                 :            :          * last page that's been initialized by AdvanceXLInsertBuffer.
    2425                 :            :          */

    2428         [ -  + ]:     109589 :         if (LogwrtResult.Write >= EndPtr)
    2429                 :          0 :             elog(PANIC, "xlog write request %X/%X is past end of log %X/%X",

    2439                 :            :                              wal_segment_size))

    2471                 :            :         }
    2472                 :     109589 :         npages++;
    2473                 :            : 
    2474                 :            :         /*
    2475                 :            :          * Dump the set if this will be the last loop iteration, or if we are
    2476                 :            :          * at the last page of the cache area (since the next page won't be

    2480                 :     109589 :         last_iteration = WriteRqst.Write <= LogwrtResult.Write;

    2486         [ +  + ]:      19629 :             curridx == XLogCtl->XLogCacheBlck ||
    2487                 :            :             finishing_seg)

    2505                 :            :                 {

    2507                 :          0 :                         continue;
    2508         [ #  # ]:          0 :                     ereport(PANIC,
    2509                 :            :                             (errcode_for_file_access(),

    2516                 :      89967 :                 from += written;
    2517                 :      89967 :                 startoffset += written;
