    2520                 :      89967 :             npages = 0;
    2521                 :            : 
    2522                 :            :             /*
    2523                 :            :              * If we just wrote the whole last page of a logfile segment,
    2524                 :            :              * fsync the segment immediately.  This avoids having to go back
    2525                 :            :              * and re-open prior segments when an fsync request comes along
    2526                 :            :              * later. Doing it here ensures that one and only one backend will
    2527                 :            :              * perform this fsync.
    2528                 :            :              *
    2529                 :            :              * This is also the right place to notify the Archiver that the
    2530                 :            :              * segment is ready to copy to archival storage, and to update the
    2531                 :            :              * timer for archive_timeout, and to signal for a checkpoint if
    2532                 :            :              * too many logfile segments have been used since the last
    2533                 :            :              * checkpoint.
    2534                 :            :              */
    2535         [ +  + ]:      89967 :             if (finishing_seg)
    2536                 :            :             {
    2537                 :         12 :                 issue_xlog_fsync(openLogFile, openLogSegNo);
    2538                 :            : 
    2539                 :            :                 /* signal that we need to wakeup walsenders later */
    2540                 :         12 :                 WalSndWakeupRequest();
    2541                 :            : 
    2542                 :         12 :                 LogwrtResult.Flush = LogwrtResult.Write;    /* end of page */
    2543                 :            : 
    2544         [ +  - ]:         12 :                 if (XLogArchivingActive())
    2545                 :         12 :                     XLogArchiveNotifySeg(openLogSegNo);
    2546                 :            : 
    2547                 :         12 :                 XLogCtl->lastSegSwitchTime = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);

    2549                 :            : 
    2550                 :            :                 /*
    2551                 :            :                  * Request a checkpoint if we've consumed too much xlog since
    2552                 :            :                  * the last one.  For speed, we first check using the local
    2553                 :            :                  * copy of RedoRecPtr, which might be out of date; if it looks
    2554                 :            :                  * like a checkpoint is needed, forcibly update RedoRecPtr and
    2555                 :            :                  * recheck.
    2556                 :            :                  */
    2557 [ +  - ][ -  + ]:         12 :                 if (IsUnderPostmaster && XLogCheckpointNeeded(openLogSegNo))

    2561                 :          0 :                         RequestCheckpoint(CHECKPOINT_CAUSE_XLOG);
    2562                 :            :                 }
    2563                 :            :             }
    2564                 :            :         }
    2565                 :            : 
    2566         [ +  + ]:     109589 :         if (ispartialpage)
    2567                 :            :         {
    2568                 :            :             /* Only asked to write a partial page */
    2569                 :      85013 :             LogwrtResult.Write = WriteRqst.Write;
    2570                 :      85013 :             break;
    2571                 :            :         }
    2572         [ +  + ]:      24576 :         curridx = NextBufIdx(curridx);
    2573                 :            :

    2576                 :       4854 :             break;
    2577                 :            :     }
    2578                 :            : 
    2579                 :            :     Assert(npages == 0);
    2580                 :            : 
    2581                 :            :     /*
    2582                 :            :      * If asked to flush, do so

    2705                 :            : /*
    2706                 :            :  * Advance minRecoveryPoint in control file.
    2707                 :            :  *
    2708                 :            :  * If we crash during recovery, we must reach this point again before the
    2709                 :            :  * database is consistent.
    2710                 :            :  *
    2711                 :            :  * If 'force' is true, 'lsn' argument is ignored. Otherwise, minRecoveryPoint
    2712                 :            :  * is only updated if it's not already greater than or equal to 'lsn'.
    2713                 :            :  */
    2714                 :            : static void
    2715                 :          0 : UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(XLogRecPtr lsn, bool force)
    2716                 :            : {
    2717                 :            :     /* Quick check using our local copy of the variable */
    2718 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!updateMinRecoveryPoint || (!force && lsn <= minRecoveryPoint))
                 [ #  # ]
    2719                 :          0 :         return;
    2720                 :            : 
    2721                 :            :     /*
    2722                 :            :      * An invalid minRecoveryPoint means that we need to recover all the WAL,
    2723                 :            :      * i.e., we're doing crash recovery.  We never modify the control file's
    2724                 :            :      * value in that case, so we can short-circuit future checks here too. The
    2725                 :            :      * local values of minRecoveryPoint and minRecoveryPointTLI should not be
    2726                 :            :      * updated until crash recovery finishes.  We only do this for the startup
    2727                 :            :      * process as it should not update its own reference of minRecoveryPoint
    2728                 :            :      * until it has finished crash recovery to make sure that all WAL
    2729                 :            :      * available is replayed in this case.  This also saves from extra locks
    2730                 :            :      * taken on the control file from the startup process.
    2731                 :            :      */
    2732 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(minRecoveryPoint) && InRecovery)
    2733                 :            :     {
    2734                 :          0 :         updateMinRecoveryPoint = false;
    2735                 :          0 :         return;
    2736                 :            :     }
    2737                 :            : 
    2738                 :          0 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    2739                 :            : 
    2740                 :            :     /* update local copy */
    2741                 :          0 :     minRecoveryPoint = ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint;
    2742                 :          0 :     minRecoveryPointTLI = ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI;
    2743                 :            : 
    2744         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(minRecoveryPoint))
    2745                 :          0 :         updateMinRecoveryPoint = false;
    2746 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (force || minRecoveryPoint < lsn)
    2747                 :            :     {
    2748                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  newMinRecoveryPoint;
    2749                 :            :         TimeLineID  newMinRecoveryPointTLI;
    2750                 :            : 
    2751                 :            :         /*
    2752                 :            :          * To avoid having to update the control file too often, we update it
    2753                 :            :          * all the way to the last record being replayed, even though 'lsn'
    2754                 :            :          * would suffice for correctness.  This also allows the 'force' case
    2755                 :            :          * to not need a valid 'lsn' value.
    2756                 :            :          *
    2757                 :            :          * Another important reason for doing it this way is that the passed
    2758                 :            :          * 'lsn' value could be bogus, i.e., past the end of available WAL, if
    2759                 :            :          * the caller got it from a corrupted heap page.  Accepting such a
    2760                 :            :          * value as the min recovery point would prevent us from coming up at
    2761                 :            :          * all.  Instead, we just log a warning and continue with recovery.
    2762                 :            :          * (See also the comments about corrupt LSNs in XLogFlush.)
    2763                 :            :          */
    2764         [ #  # ]:          0 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2765                 :          0 :         newMinRecoveryPoint = XLogCtl->replayEndRecPtr;

    2794                 :            : 
    2795                 :            : /*
    2796                 :            :  * Ensure that all XLOG data through the given position is flushed to disk.
    2797                 :            :  *
    2798                 :            :  * NOTE: this differs from XLogWrite mainly in that the WALWriteLock is not
    2799                 :            :  * already held, and we try to avoid acquiring it if possible.
    2800                 :            :  */
    2801                 :            : void
    2802                 :      85707 : XLogFlush(XLogRecPtr record)
    2803                 :            : {
    2804                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  WriteRqstPtr;
    2805                 :            :     XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst;
    2806                 :            : 
    2807                 :            :     /*
    2808                 :            :      * During REDO, we are reading not writing WAL.  Therefore, instead of
    2809                 :            :      * trying to flush the WAL, we should update minRecoveryPoint instead. We
    2810                 :            :      * test XLogInsertAllowed(), not InRecovery, because we need checkpointer
    2811                 :            :      * to act this way too, and because when it tries to write the
    2812                 :            :      * end-of-recovery checkpoint, it should indeed flush.
    2813                 :            :      */
    2814         [ -  + ]:      85707 :     if (!XLogInsertAllowed())
    2815                 :            :     {
    2816                 :          0 :         UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(record, false);
    2817                 :       1016 :         return;
    2818                 :            :     }
    2819                 :            : 
    2820                 :            :     /* Quick exit if already known flushed */
    2821         [ +  + ]:      85707 :     if (record <= LogwrtResult.Flush)
    2822                 :       1016 :         return;
    2823                 :            : 
    2824                 :            : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
    2825                 :            :     if (XLOG_DEBUG)
    2826                 :            :         elog(LOG, "xlog flush request %X/%X; write %X/%X; flush %X/%X",
    2827                 :            :              (uint32) (record >> 32), (uint32) record,
    2828                 :            :              (uint32) (LogwrtResult.Write >> 32), (uint32) LogwrtResult.Write,
    2829                 :            :              (uint32) (LogwrtResult.Flush >> 32), (uint32) LogwrtResult.Flush);
    2830                 :            : #endif
    2831                 :            : 
    2832                 :      84691 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    2833                 :            : 
    2834                 :            :     /*
    2835                 :            :      * Since fsync is usually a horribly expensive operation, we try to
    2836                 :            :      * piggyback as much data as we can on each fsync: if we see any more data
    2837                 :            :      * entered into the xlog buffer, we'll write and fsync that too, so that
    2838                 :            :      * the final value of LogwrtResult.Flush is as large as possible. This
    2839                 :            :      * gives us some chance of avoiding another fsync immediately after.
    2840                 :            :      */
    2841                 :            : 
    2842                 :            :     /* initialize to given target; may increase below */
    2843                 :      84691 :     WriteRqstPtr = record;
    2844                 :            : 
    2845                 :            :     /*
    2846                 :            :      * Now wait until we get the write lock, or someone else does the flush
    2847                 :            :      * for us.
    2848                 :            :      */
    2849                 :            :     for (;;)
    2850                 :            :     {
    2851                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  insertpos;
    2852                 :            : 
    2853                 :            :         /* read LogwrtResult and update local state */
    2854         [ -  + ]:      84730 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2855         [ +  + ]:      84730 :         if (WriteRqstPtr < XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write)
    2856                 :          6 :             WriteRqstPtr = XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write;
    2857                 :      84730 :         LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2858                 :      84730 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    2859                 :            : 
    2860                 :            :         /* done already? */
    2861         [ +  + ]:      84730 :         if (record <= LogwrtResult.Flush)
    2862                 :          3 :             break;
    2863                 :            : 
    2864                 :            :         /*
    2865                 :            :          * Before actually performing the write, wait for all in-flight
    2866                 :            :          * insertions to the pages we're about to write to finish.
    2867                 :            :          */
    2868                 :      84727 :         insertpos = WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(WriteRqstPtr);
    2869                 :            : 
    2870                 :            :         /*
    2871                 :            :          * Try to get the write lock. If we can't get it immediately, wait
    2872                 :            :          * until it's released, and recheck if we still need to do the flush
    2873                 :            :          * or if the backend that held the lock did it for us already. This
    2874                 :            :          * helps to maintain a good rate of group committing when the system
    2875                 :            :          * is bottlenecked by the speed of fsyncing.
    2876                 :            :          */
    2877         [ +  + ]:      84727 :         if (!LWLockAcquireOrWait(WALWriteLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE))
    2878                 :            :         {
    2879                 :            :             /*
    2880                 :            :              * The lock is now free, but we didn't acquire it yet. Before we
    2881                 :            :              * do, loop back to check if someone else flushed the record for
    2882                 :            :              * us already.
    2883                 :            :              */
    2884                 :         39 :             continue;
    2885                 :            :         }
    2886                 :            : 
    2887                 :            :         /* Got the lock; recheck whether request is satisfied */
    2888                 :      84688 :         LogwrtResult = XLogCtl->LogwrtResult;
    2889         [ -  + ]:      84688 :         if (record <= LogwrtResult.Flush)
    2890                 :            :         {
    2891                 :          0 :             LWLockRelease(WALWriteLock);
    2892                 :          0 :             break;
    2893                 :            :         }
    2894                 :            : 
    2895                 :            :         /*
    2896                 :            :          * Sleep before flush! By adding a delay here, we may give further
    2897                 :            :          * backends the opportunity to join the backlog of group commit
    2898                 :            :          * followers; this can significantly improve transaction throughput,
    2899                 :            :          * at the risk of increasing transaction latency.
    2900                 :            :          *
    2901                 :            :          * We do not sleep if enableFsync is not turned on, nor if there are
    2902                 :            :          * fewer than CommitSiblings other backends with active transactions.
    2903                 :            :          */
    2904         [ -  + ]:      84688 :         if (CommitDelay > 0 && enableFsync &&
           [ #  #  #  # ]
    2905                 :          0 :             MinimumActiveBackends(CommitSiblings))
    2906                 :            :         {
    2907                 :          0 :             pg_usleep(CommitDelay);
    2908                 :            : 
    2909                 :            :             /*
    2910                 :            :              * Re-check how far we can now flush the WAL. It's generally not
    2911                 :            :              * safe to call WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish while holding
    2912                 :            :              * WALWriteLock, because an in-progress insertion might need to
    2913                 :            :              * also grab WALWriteLock to make progress. But we know that all
    2914                 :            :              * the insertions up to insertpos have already finished, because
    2915                 :            :              * that's what the earlier WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish() returned.
    2916                 :            :              * We're only calling it again to allow insertpos to be moved
    2917                 :            :              * further forward, not to actually wait for anyone.
    2918                 :            :              */
    2919                 :          0 :             insertpos = WaitXLogInsertionsToFinish(insertpos);
    2920                 :            :         }
    2921                 :            : 
    2922                 :            :         /* try to write/flush later additions to XLOG as well */
    2923                 :      84688 :         WriteRqst.Write = insertpos;
    2924                 :      84688 :         WriteRqst.Flush = insertpos;
    2925                 :            : 
    2926                 :      84688 :         XLogWrite(WriteRqst, false);
    2927                 :            : 
    2928                 :      84688 :         LWLockRelease(WALWriteLock);
    2929                 :            :         /* done */
    2930                 :      84688 :         break;
    2931                 :         39 :     }
    2932                 :            : 
    2933                 :      84691 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    2934                 :            : 
    2935                 :            :     /* wake up walsenders now that we've released heavily contended locks */
    2936 [ +  + ][ +  - ]:      84691 :     WalSndWakeupProcessRequests();
    2937                 :            : 
    2938                 :            :     /*
    2939                 :            :      * If we still haven't flushed to the request point then we have a
    2940                 :            :      * problem; most likely, the requested flush point is past end of XLOG.
    2941                 :            :      * This has been seen to occur when a disk page has a corrupted LSN.
    2942                 :            :      *
    2943                 :            :      * Formerly we treated this as a PANIC condition, but that hurts the
    2944                 :            :      * system's robustness rather than helping it: we do not want to take down
    2945                 :            :      * the whole system due to corruption on one data page.  In particular, if
    2946                 :            :      * the bad page is encountered again during recovery then we would be
    2947                 :            :      * unable to restart the database at all!  (This scenario actually
    2948                 :            :      * happened in the field several times with 7.1 releases.)  As of 8.4, bad
    2949                 :            :      * LSNs encountered during recovery are UpdateMinRecoveryPoint's problem;
    2950                 :            :      * the only time we can reach here during recovery is while flushing the
    2951                 :            :      * end-of-recovery checkpoint record, and we don't expect that to have a
    2952                 :            :      * bad LSN.
    2953                 :            :      *
    2954                 :            :      * Note that for calls from xact.c, the ERROR will be promoted to PANIC
    2955                 :            :      * since xact.c calls this routine inside a critical section.  However,
    2956                 :            :      * calls from bufmgr.c are not within critical sections and so we will not
    2957                 :            :      * force a restart for a bad LSN on a data page.
    2958                 :            :      */
    2959         [ -  + ]:      84691 :     if (LogwrtResult.Flush < record)
    2960                 :      84691 :         elog(ERROR,
    2961                 :            :              "xlog flush request %X/%X is not satisfied --- flushed only to %X/%X",
    2962                 :            :              (uint32) (record >> 32), (uint32) record,
    2963                 :            :              (uint32) (LogwrtResult.Flush >> 32), (uint32) LogwrtResult.Flush);
    2964                 :            : }
    2965                 :            : 
    2966                 :            : /*
    2967                 :            :  * Write & flush xlog, but without specifying exactly where to.
    2968                 :            :  *
    2969                 :            :  * We normally write only completed blocks; but if there is nothing to do on
    2970                 :            :  * that basis, we check for unwritten async commits in the current incomplete
    2971                 :            :  * block, and write through the latest one of those.  Thus, if async commits
    2972                 :            :  * are not being used, we will write complete blocks only.
    2973                 :            :  *
    2974                 :            :  * If, based on the above, there's anything to write we do so immediately. But
    2975                 :            :  * to avoid calling fsync, fdatasync et. al. at a rate that'd impact
    2976                 :            :  * concurrent IO, we only flush WAL every wal_writer_delay ms, or if there's
    2977                 :            :  * more than wal_writer_flush_after unflushed blocks.
    2978                 :            :  *
    2979                 :            :  * We can guarantee that async commits reach disk after at most three
    2980                 :            :  * wal_writer_delay cycles. (When flushing complete blocks, we allow XLogWrite
    2981                 :            :  * to write "flexibly", meaning it can stop at the end of the buffer ring;
    2982                 :            :  * this makes a difference only with very high load or long wal_writer_delay,
    2983                 :            :  * but imposes one extra cycle for the worst case for async commits.)
    2984                 :            :  *
    2985                 :            :  * This routine is invoked periodically by the background walwriter process.
    2986                 :            :  *
    2987                 :            :  * Returns true if there was any work to do, even if we skipped flushing due
    2988                 :            :  * to wal_writer_delay/wal_writer_flush_after.
    2989                 :            :  */
    2990                 :            : bool
    2991                 :      19208 : XLogBackgroundFlush(void)
    2992                 :            : {
    2993                 :            :     XLogwrtRqst WriteRqst;
    2994                 :      19208 :     bool        flexible = true;
    2995                 :            :     static TimestampTz lastflush;
    2996                 :            :     TimestampTz now;

    3123                 :     287569 : XLogNeedsFlush(XLogRecPtr record)

    3125                 :            :     /*
    3126                 :            :      * During recovery, we don't flush WAL but update minRecoveryPoint
    3127                 :            :      * instead. So "needs flush" is taken to mean whether minRecoveryPoint
    3128                 :            :      * would need to be updated.
    3129                 :            :      */
    3130         [ -  + ]:     287569 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    3131                 :            :     {
    3132                 :            :         /*
    3133                 :            :          * An invalid minRecoveryPoint means that we need to recover all the
    3134                 :            :          * WAL, i.e., we're doing crash recovery.  We never modify the control
    3135                 :            :          * file's value in that case, so we can short-circuit future checks
    3136                 :            :          * here too.  This triggers a quick exit path for the startup process,
    3137                 :            :          * which cannot update its local copy of minRecoveryPoint as long as
    3138                 :            :          * it has not replayed all WAL available when doing crash recovery.

    3188                 :            : /*
    3189                 :            :  * Create a new XLOG file segment, or open a pre-existing one.

    3191                 :            :  * log, seg: identify segment to be created/opened.
    3192                 :            :  *

    3195                 :            :  * file was used.
    3196                 :            :  *

    3202                 :            :  *

    3265                 :            :          * Zero-fill the file.  With this setting, we do this the hard way to
    3266                 :            :          * ensure that all the file space has really been allocated.  On
    3267                 :            :          * platforms that allow "holes" in files, just seeking to the end
    3268                 :            :          * doesn't allocate intermediate space.  This way, we know that we
    3269                 :            :          * have all the space and (after the fsync below) that all the
    3270                 :            :          * indirect blocks are down on disk.  Therefore, fdatasync(2) or
    3271                 :            :          * O_DSYNC will be sufficient to sync future writes to the log file.

    3512                 :            : 
    3513                 :            : /*
    3514                 :            :  * Install a new XLOG segment file as a current or future log segment.
    3515                 :            :  *
    3516                 :            :  * This is used both to install a newly-created segment (which has a temp
    3517                 :            :  * filename while it's being created) and to recycle an old segment.
    3518                 :            :  *
    3519                 :            :  * *segno: identify segment to install as (or first possible target).
    3520                 :            :  * When find_free is true, this is modified on return to indicate the
    3521                 :            :  * actual installation location or last segment searched.
    3522                 :            :  *
    3523                 :            :  * tmppath: initial name of file to install.  It will be renamed into place.
    3524                 :            :  *
    3525                 :            :  * find_free: if true, install the new segment at the first empty segno
    3526                 :            :  * number at or after the passed numbers.  If false, install the new segment
    3527                 :            :  * exactly where specified, deleting any existing segment file there.
    3528                 :            :  *
    3529                 :            :  * max_segno: maximum segment number to install the new file as.  Fail if no
    3530                 :            :  * free slot is found between *segno and max_segno. (Ignored when find_free
    3531                 :            :  * is false.)
    3532                 :            :  *
    3533                 :            :  * use_lock: if true, acquire ControlFileLock while moving file into
    3534                 :            :  * place.  This should be true except during bootstrap log creation.  The
    3535                 :            :  * caller must *not* hold the lock at call.
    3536                 :            :  *
    3537                 :            :  * Returns true if the file was installed successfully.  false indicates that
    3538                 :            :  * max_segno limit was exceeded, or an error occurred while renaming the
    3539                 :            :  * file into place.
    3540                 :            :  */
    3541                 :            : static bool
    3542                 :         12 : InstallXLogFileSegment(XLogSegNo *segno, char *tmppath,
    3543                 :            :                        bool find_free, XLogSegNo max_segno,
    3544                 :            :                        bool use_lock)
    3545                 :            : {
    3546                 :            :     char        path[MAXPGPATH];
    3547                 :            :     struct stat stat_buf;
    3548                 :            : 
    3549                 :         12 :     XLogFilePath(path, ThisTimeLineID, *segno, wal_segment_size);
    3550                 :            : 
    3551                 :            :     /*
    3552                 :            :      * We want to be sure that only one process does this at a time.
    3553                 :            :      */
    3554         [ +  - ]:         12 :     if (use_lock)
    3555                 :         12 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    3556                 :            : 
    3557         [ -  + ]:         12 :     if (!find_free)
    3558                 :            :     {
    3559                 :            :         /* Force installation: get rid of any pre-existing segment file */
    3560                 :          0 :         durable_unlink(path, DEBUG1);
    3561                 :            :     }
    3562                 :            :     else
    3563                 :            :     {
    3564                 :            :         /* Find a free slot to put it in */
    3565         [ +  + ]:         59 :         while (stat(path, &stat_buf) == 0)
    3566                 :            :         {
    3567         [ -  + ]:         47 :             if ((*segno) >= max_segno)
    3568                 :            :             {
    3569                 :            :                 /* Failed to find a free slot within specified range */
    3570         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 if (use_lock)
    3571                 :          0 :                     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    3572                 :          0 :                 return false;
    3573                 :            :             }

    3575                 :         47 :             XLogFilePath(path, ThisTimeLineID, *segno, wal_segment_size);
    3576                 :            :         }
    3577                 :            :     }
    3578                 :            : 
    3579                 :            :     /*
    3580                 :            :      * Perform the rename using link if available, paranoidly trying to avoid
    3581                 :            :      * overwriting an existing file (there shouldn't be one).
    3582                 :            :      */

    3584                 :            :     {

    3586                 :          0 :             LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    3587                 :            :         /* durable_link_or_rename already emitted log message */
    3588                 :          0 :         return false;
    3589                 :            :     }
    3590                 :            : 
    3591         [ +  - ]:         12 :     if (use_lock)
    3592                 :         12 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    3593                 :            : 
    3594                 :         12 :     return true;
    3595                 :            : }

    3597                 :            : /*
    3598                 :            :  * Open a pre-existing logfile segment for writing.
    3599                 :            :  */

    3617                 :            : /*

    3700                 :            : 
    3701                 :            : /*
    3702                 :            :  * Open a logfile segment for reading (during recovery).
    3703                 :            :  *
    3704                 :            :  * This version searches for the segment with any TLI listed in expectedTLEs.
    3705                 :            :  */
    3706                 :            : static int
    3707                 :          1 : XLogFileReadAnyTLI(XLogSegNo segno, int emode, int source)
    3708                 :            : {
    3709                 :            :     char        path[MAXPGPATH];
    3710                 :            :     ListCell   *cell;
    3711                 :            :     int         fd;
    3712                 :            :     List       *tles;
    3713                 :            : 
    3714                 :            :     /*
    3715                 :            :      * Loop looking for a suitable timeline ID: we might need to read any of
    3716                 :            :      * the timelines listed in expectedTLEs.
    3717                 :            :      *
    3718                 :            :      * We expect curFileTLI on entry to be the TLI of the preceding file in
    3719                 :            :      * sequence, or 0 if there was no predecessor.  We do not allow curFileTLI
    3720                 :            :      * to go backwards; this prevents us from picking up the wrong file when a
    3721                 :            :      * parent timeline extends to higher segment numbers than the child we
    3722                 :            :      * want to read.
    3723                 :            :      *
    3724                 :            :      * If we haven't read the timeline history file yet, read it now, so that
    3725                 :            :      * we know which TLIs to scan.  We don't save the list in expectedTLEs,
    3726                 :            :      * however, unless we actually find a valid segment.  That way if there is
    3727                 :            :      * neither a timeline history file nor a WAL segment in the archive, and
    3728                 :            :      * streaming replication is set up, we'll read the timeline history file
    3729                 :            :      * streamed from the master when we start streaming, instead of recovering
    3730                 :            :      * with a dummy history generated here.
    3731                 :            :      */
    3732         [ -  + ]:          1 :     if (expectedTLEs)
    3733                 :          0 :         tles = expectedTLEs;
    3734                 :            :     else
    3735                 :          1 :         tles = readTimeLineHistory(recoveryTargetTLI);
    3736                 :            : 
    3737         [ +  - ]:          1 :     foreach(cell, tles)
    3738                 :            :     {
    3739                 :          1 :         TimeLineHistoryEntry *hent = (TimeLineHistoryEntry *) lfirst(cell);
    3740                 :          1 :         TimeLineID  tli = hent->tli;
    3741                 :            : 
    3742         [ -  + ]:          1 :         if (tli < curFileTLI)
    3743                 :          0 :             break;              /* don't bother looking at too-old TLIs */
    3744                 :            : 
    3745                 :            :         /*
    3746                 :            :          * Skip scanning the timeline ID that the logfile segment to read
    3747                 :            :          * doesn't belong to
    3748                 :            :          */
    3749         [ +  - ]:          1 :         if (hent->begin != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    3750                 :            :         {
    3751                 :          1 :             XLogSegNo   beginseg = 0;
    3752                 :            : 
    3753                 :          1 :             XLByteToSeg(hent->begin, beginseg, wal_segment_size);
    3754                 :            : 
    3755                 :            :             /*
    3756                 :            :              * The logfile segment that doesn't belong to the timeline is
    3757                 :            :              * older or newer than the segment that the timeline started or
    3758                 :            :              * ended at, respectively. It's sufficient to check only the
    3759                 :            :              * starting segment of the timeline here. Since the timelines are
    3760                 :            :              * scanned in descending order in this loop, any segments newer
    3761                 :            :              * than the ending segment should belong to newer timeline and
    3762                 :            :              * have already been read before. So it's not necessary to check
    3763                 :            :              * the ending segment of the timeline here.
    3764                 :            :              */
    3765         [ -  + ]:          1 :             if (segno < beginseg)
    3766                 :          0 :                 continue;

    3781                 :            :

    3785                 :            :                               XLOG_FROM_PG_WAL, true);

    3787                 :            :             {

    3804                 :            : /*
    3805                 :            :  * Close the current logfile segment for writing.

    3807                 :            : static void

    3809                 :            : {
    3810                 :            :     Assert(openLogFile >= 0);
    3811                 :            : 
    3812                 :            :     /*
    3813                 :            :      * WAL segment files will not be re-read in normal operation, so we advise
    3814                 :            :      * the OS to release any cached pages.  But do not do so if WAL archiving
    3815                 :            :      * or streaming is active, because archiver and walsender process could
    3816                 :            :      * use the cache to read the WAL segment.
    3817                 :            :      */
    3818                 :            : #if defined(USE_POSIX_FADVISE) && defined(POSIX_FADV_DONTNEED)

    3823         [ -  + ]:        236 :     if (close(openLogFile))
    3824         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    3825                 :            :                 (errcode_for_file_access(),
    3826                 :            :                  errmsg("could not close file \"%s\": %m",
    3827                 :            :                         XLogFileNameP(ThisTimeLineID, openLogSegNo))));
    3828                 :        236 :     openLogFile = -1;
    3829                 :        236 : }
    3830                 :            : 
    3831                 :            : /*
    3832                 :            :  * Preallocate log files beyond the specified log endpoint.
    3833                 :            :  *
    3834                 :            :  * XXX this is currently extremely conservative, since it forces only one
    3835                 :            :  * future log segment to exist, and even that only if we are 75% done with
    3836                 :            :  * the current one.  This is only appropriate for very low-WAL-volume systems.
    3837                 :            :  * High-volume systems will be OK once they've built up a sufficient set of
    3838                 :            :  * recycled log segments, but the startup transient is likely to include
    3839                 :            :  * a lot of segment creations by foreground processes, which is not so good.
    3840                 :            :  */
    3841                 :            : static void
    3842                 :         76 : PreallocXlogFiles(XLogRecPtr endptr)
    3843                 :            : {
    3844                 :            :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    3845                 :            :     int         lf;
    3846                 :            :     bool        use_existent;
    3847                 :            :     uint64      offset;
    3848                 :            : 
    3849                 :         76 :     XLByteToPrevSeg(endptr, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    3850                 :         76 :     offset = XLogSegmentOffset(endptr - 1, wal_segment_size);
    3851         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (offset >= (uint32) (0.75 * wal_segment_size))
    3852                 :            :     {
    3853                 :         15 :         _logSegNo++;
    3854                 :         15 :         use_existent = true;
    3855                 :         15 :         lf = XLogFileInit(_logSegNo, &use_existent, true);
    3856                 :         15 :         close(lf);
    3857         [ -  + ]:         15 :         if (!use_existent)
    3858                 :          0 :             CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added++;
    3859                 :            :     }
    3860                 :         76 : }
    3861                 :            : 
    3862                 :            : /*
    3863                 :            :  * Throws an error if the given log segment has already been removed or
    3864                 :            :  * recycled. The caller should only pass a segment that it knows to have
    3865                 :            :  * existed while the server has been running, as this function always
    3866                 :            :  * succeeds if no WAL segments have been removed since startup.
    3867                 :            :  * 'tli' is only used in the error message.
    3868                 :            :  *
    3869                 :            :  * Note: this function guarantees to keep errno unchanged on return.
    3870                 :            :  * This supports callers that use this to possibly deliver a better
    3871                 :            :  * error message about a missing file, while still being able to throw
    3872                 :            :  * a normal file-access error afterwards, if this does return.
    3873                 :            :  */
    3874                 :            : void
    3875                 :          0 : CheckXLogRemoved(XLogSegNo segno, TimeLineID tli)
    3876                 :            : {
    3877                 :          0 :     int         save_errno = errno;
    3878                 :            :     XLogSegNo   lastRemovedSegNo;
    3879                 :            : 
    3880         [ #  # ]:          0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    3881                 :          0 :     lastRemovedSegNo = XLogCtl->lastRemovedSegNo;
    3882                 :          0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    3883                 :            : 
    3884         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (segno <= lastRemovedSegNo)
    3885                 :            :     {
    3886                 :            :         char        filename[MAXFNAMELEN];

    3888                 :          0 :         XLogFileName(filename, tli, segno, wal_segment_size);
    3889                 :          0 :         errno = save_errno;
    3890         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    3891                 :            :                 (errcode_for_file_access(),

    3898                 :            : /*

    3902                 :            :  * NB: the result can be out of date arbitrarily fast, the caller has to deal

    3964                 :            : /*

    4002                 :            :          * non-parent timelines, but that would be a whole lot more

    4023                 :            : /*
    4024                 :            :  * Remove WAL files that are not part of the given timeline's history.
    4025                 :            :  *
    4026                 :            :  * This is called during recovery, whenever we switch to follow a new
    4027                 :            :  * timeline, and at the end of recovery when we create a new timeline. We
    4028                 :            :  * wouldn't otherwise care about extra WAL files lying in pg_wal, but they
    4029                 :            :  * might be leftover pre-allocated or recycled WAL segments on the old timeline
    4030                 :            :  * that we haven't used yet, and contain garbage. If we just leave them in
    4031                 :            :  * pg_wal, they will eventually be archived, and we can't let that happen.
    4032                 :            :  * Files that belong to our timeline history are valid, because we have
    4033                 :            :  * successfully replayed them, but from others we can't be sure.
    4034                 :            :  *
    4035                 :            :  * 'switchpoint' is the current point in WAL where we switch to new timeline,
    4036                 :            :  * and 'newTLI' is the new timeline we switch to.
    4037                 :            :  */
    4038                 :            : static void
    4039                 :          0 : RemoveNonParentXlogFiles(XLogRecPtr switchpoint, TimeLineID newTLI)
    4040                 :            : {

    4085                 :            : 
    4086                 :            : /*
    4087                 :            :  * Recycle or remove a log file that's no longer needed.
    4088                 :            :  *
    4089                 :            :  * endptr is current (or recent) end of xlog, and lastredoptr is the
    4090                 :            :  * redo pointer of the last checkpoint. These are used to determine
    4091                 :            :  * whether we want to recycle rather than delete no-longer-wanted log files.
    4092                 :            :  * If lastredoptr is not known, pass invalid, and the function will recycle,
    4093                 :            :  * somewhat arbitrarily, 10 future segments.
    4094                 :            :  */
    4095                 :            : static void
    4096                 :         12 : RemoveXlogFile(const char *segname, XLogRecPtr lastredoptr, XLogRecPtr endptr)
    4097                 :            : {
    4098                 :            :     char        path[MAXPGPATH];
    4099                 :            : #ifdef WIN32
    4100                 :            :     char        newpath[MAXPGPATH];
    4101                 :            : #endif
    4102                 :            :     struct stat statbuf;
    4103                 :            :     XLogSegNo   endlogSegNo;
    4104                 :            :     XLogSegNo   recycleSegNo;
    4105                 :            : 
    4106         [ +  - ]:         12 :     if (wal_recycle)
    4107                 :            :     {
    4108                 :            :         /*
    4109                 :            :          * Initialize info about where to try to recycle to.
    4110                 :            :          */
    4111                 :         12 :         XLByteToSeg(endptr, endlogSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    4112         [ -  + ]:         12 :         if (lastredoptr == InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    4113                 :          0 :             recycleSegNo = endlogSegNo + 10;
    4114                 :            :         else
    4115                 :         12 :             recycleSegNo = XLOGfileslop(lastredoptr);
    4116                 :            :     }
    4117                 :            :     else
    4118                 :          0 :         recycleSegNo = 0;       /* keep compiler quiet */
    4119                 :            : 
    4120                 :         12 :     snprintf(path, MAXPGPATH, XLOGDIR "/%s", segname);
    4121                 :            : 
    4122                 :            :     /*
    4123                 :            :      * Before deleting the file, see if it can be recycled as a future log
    4124                 :            :      * segment. Only recycle normal files, pg_standby for example can create
    4125                 :            :      * symbolic links pointing to a separate archive directory.
    4126                 :            :      */
    4127 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:         12 :     if (wal_recycle &&
    4128         [ +  - ]:         12 :         endlogSegNo <= recycleSegNo &&
    4129   [ +  -  +  - ]:         36 :         lstat(path, &statbuf) == 0 && S_ISREG(statbuf.st_mode) &&
    4130                 :         12 :         InstallXLogFileSegment(&endlogSegNo, path,
    4131                 :            :                                true, recycleSegNo, true))
    4132                 :            :     {
    4133         [ -  + ]:         12 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    4134                 :            :                 (errmsg("recycled write-ahead log file \"%s\"",
    4135                 :            :                         segname)));
    4136                 :         12 :         CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled++;
    4137                 :            :         /* Needn't recheck that slot on future iterations */
    4138                 :         12 :         endlogSegNo++;
    4139                 :            :     }
    4140                 :            :     else
    4141                 :            :     {
    4142                 :            :         /* No need for any more future segments... */
    4143                 :            :         int         rc;
    4144                 :            : 
    4145         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    4146                 :            :                 (errmsg("removing write-ahead log file \"%s\"",
    4147                 :            :                         segname)));
    4148                 :            : 
    4149                 :            : #ifdef WIN32
    4150                 :            : 
    4151                 :            :         /*
    4152                 :            :          * On Windows, if another process (e.g another backend) holds the file
    4153                 :            :          * open in FILE_SHARE_DELETE mode, unlink will succeed, but the file
    4154                 :            :          * will still show up in directory listing until the last handle is
    4155                 :            :          * closed. To avoid confusing the lingering deleted file for a live
    4156                 :            :          * WAL file that needs to be archived, rename it before deleting it.
    4157                 :            :          *
    4158                 :            :          * If another process holds the file open without FILE_SHARE_DELETE
    4159                 :            :          * flag, rename will fail. We'll try again at the next checkpoint.
    4160                 :            :          */
    4161                 :            :         snprintf(newpath, MAXPGPATH, "%s.deleted", path);
    4162                 :            :         if (rename(path, newpath) != 0)
    4163                 :            :         {
    4164                 :            :             ereport(LOG,
    4165                 :            :                     (errcode_for_file_access(),
    4166                 :            :                      errmsg("could not rename file \"%s\": %m",
    4167                 :            :                             path)));
    4168                 :            :             return;
    4169                 :            :         }
    4170                 :            :         rc = durable_unlink(newpath, LOG);
    4171                 :            : #else
    4172                 :          0 :         rc = durable_unlink(path, LOG);
    4173                 :            : #endif
    4174         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (rc != 0)
    4175                 :            :         {
    4176                 :            :             /* Message already logged by durable_unlink() */
    4177                 :          0 :             return;
    4178                 :            :         }
    4179                 :          0 :         CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed++;
    4180                 :            :     }
    4181                 :            : 
    4182                 :         12 :     XLogArchiveCleanup(segname);
    4183                 :            : }
    4184                 :            : 
    4185                 :            : /*
    4186                 :            :  * Verify whether pg_wal and pg_wal/archive_status exist.
    4187                 :            :  * If the latter does not exist, recreate it.
    4188                 :            :  *
    4189                 :            :  * It is not the goal of this function to verify the contents of these
    4190                 :            :  * directories, but to help in cases where someone has performed a cluster
    4191                 :            :  * copy for PITR purposes but omitted pg_wal from the copy.
    4192                 :            :  *
    4193                 :            :  * We could also recreate pg_wal if it doesn't exist, but a deliberate
    4194                 :            :  * policy decision was made not to.  It is fairly common for pg_wal to be
    4195                 :            :  * a symlink, and if that was the DBA's intent then automatically making a
    4196                 :            :  * plain directory would result in degraded performance with no notice.
    4197                 :            :  */
    4198                 :            : static void
    4199                 :          1 : ValidateXLOGDirectoryStructure(void)
    4200                 :            : {
    4201                 :            :     char        path[MAXPGPATH];

    4263                 :            : 
    4264                 :            : /*
    4265                 :            :  * Attempt to read an XLOG record.
    4266                 :            :  *
    4267                 :            :  * If RecPtr is valid, try to read a record at that position.  Otherwise
    4268                 :            :  * try to read a record just after the last one previously read.
    4269                 :            :  *
    4270                 :            :  * If no valid record is available, returns NULL, or fails if emode is PANIC.
    4271                 :            :  * (emode must be either PANIC, LOG). In standby mode, retries until a valid
    4272                 :            :  * record is available.
    4273                 :            :  */
    4274                 :            : static XLogRecord *
    4275                 :          2 : ReadRecord(XLogReaderState *xlogreader, XLogRecPtr RecPtr, int emode,
    4276                 :            :            bool fetching_ckpt)
    4277                 :            : {
    4278                 :            :     XLogRecord *record;
    4279                 :          2 :     XLogPageReadPrivate *private = (XLogPageReadPrivate *) xlogreader->private_data;
    4280                 :            : 
    4281                 :            :     /* Pass through parameters to XLogPageRead */
    4282                 :          2 :     private->fetching_ckpt = fetching_ckpt;
    4283                 :          2 :     private->emode = emode;
    4284                 :          2 :     private->randAccess = (RecPtr != InvalidXLogRecPtr);
    4285                 :            : 
    4286                 :            :     /* This is the first attempt to read this page. */
    4287                 :          2 :     lastSourceFailed = false;
    4288                 :            : 
    4289                 :            :     for (;;)
    4290                 :            :     {
    4291                 :            :         char       *errormsg;
    4292                 :            : 
    4293                 :          2 :         record = XLogReadRecord(xlogreader, RecPtr, &errormsg);
    4294                 :          2 :         ReadRecPtr = xlogreader->ReadRecPtr;
    4295                 :          2 :         EndRecPtr = xlogreader->EndRecPtr;
    4296         [ -  + ]:          2 :         if (record == NULL)
    4297                 :            :         {
    4298         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (readFile >= 0)
    4299                 :            :             {
    4300                 :          0 :                 close(readFile);
    4301                 :          0 :                 readFile = -1;
    4302                 :            :             }
    4303                 :            : 
    4304                 :            :             /*
    4305                 :            :              * We only end up here without a message when XLogPageRead()
    4306                 :            :              * failed - in that case we already logged something. In
    4307                 :            :              * StandbyMode that only happens if we have been triggered, so we
    4308                 :            :              * shouldn't loop anymore in that case.
    4309                 :            :              */

    4313                 :            :                         (errmsg_internal("%s", errormsg) /* already translated */ ));

    4343                 :            :         }
    4344                 :            :         else
    4345                 :            :         {
    4346                 :            :             /* No valid record available from this source */
    4347                 :          0 :             lastSourceFailed = true;
    4348                 :            : 
    4349                 :            :             /*
    4350                 :            :              * If archive recovery was requested, but we were still doing
    4351                 :            :              * crash recovery, switch to archive recovery and retry using the
    4352                 :            :              * offline archive. We have now replayed all the valid WAL in
    4353                 :            :              * pg_wal, so we are presumably now consistent.
    4354                 :            :              *
    4355                 :            :              * We require that there's at least some valid WAL present in
    4356                 :            :              * pg_wal, however (!fetching_ckpt).  We could recover using the
    4357                 :            :              * WAL from the archive, even if pg_wal is completely empty, but
    4358                 :            :              * we'd have no idea how far we'd have to replay to reach
    4359                 :            :              * consistency.  So err on the safe side and give up.
    4360                 :            :              */
    4361 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :             if (!InArchiveRecovery && ArchiveRecoveryRequested &&

    4364         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 ereport(DEBUG1,

    4411                 :            :             }

    4421                 :            : 
    4422                 :            : /*
    4423                 :            :  * Scan for new timelines that might have appeared in the archive since we
    4424                 :            :  * started recovery.
    4425                 :            :  *
    4426                 :            :  * If there are any, the function changes recovery target TLI to the latest
    4427                 :            :  * one and returns 'true'.
    4428                 :            :  */

    4508                 :            : 
    4509                 :            : /*
    4510                 :            :  * I/O routines for pg_control
    4511                 :            :  *
    4512                 :            :  * *ControlFile is a buffer in shared memory that holds an image of the
    4513                 :            :  * contents of pg_control.  WriteControlFile() initializes pg_control
    4514                 :            :  * given a preloaded buffer, ReadControlFile() loads the buffer from
    4515                 :            :  * the pg_control file (during postmaster or standalone-backend startup),
    4516                 :            :  * and UpdateControlFile() rewrites pg_control after we modify xlog state.
    4517                 :            :  *
    4518                 :            :  * For simplicity, WriteControlFile() initializes the fields of pg_control
    4519                 :            :  * that are related to checking backend/database compatibility, and
    4520                 :            :  * ReadControlFile() verifies they are correct.  We could split out the
    4521                 :            :  * I/O and compatibility-check functions, but there seems no need currently.
    4522                 :            :  */
    4523                 :            : static void
    4524                 :          0 : WriteControlFile(void)
    4525                 :            : {
    4526                 :            :     int         fd;
    4527                 :            :     char        buffer[PG_CONTROL_FILE_SIZE];   /* need not be aligned */
    4528                 :            : 
    4529                 :            :     /*
    4530                 :            :      * Ensure that the size of the pg_control data structure is sane.  See the
    4531                 :            :      * comments for these symbols in pg_control.h.
    4532                 :            :      */
    4533                 :            :     StaticAssertStmt(sizeof(ControlFileData) <= PG_CONTROL_MAX_SAFE_SIZE,
    4534                 :            :                      "pg_control is too large for atomic disk writes");
    4535                 :            :     StaticAssertStmt(sizeof(ControlFileData) <= PG_CONTROL_FILE_SIZE,
    4536                 :            :                      "sizeof(ControlFileData) exceeds PG_CONTROL_FILE_SIZE");
    4537                 :            : 
    4538                 :            :     /*
    4539                 :            :      * Initialize version and compatibility-check fields
    4540                 :            :      */
    4541                 :          0 :     ControlFile->pg_control_version = PG_CONTROL_VERSION;
    4542                 :          0 :     ControlFile->catalog_version_no = CATALOG_VERSION_NO;
    4543                 :            : 
    4544                 :          0 :     ControlFile->maxAlign = MAXIMUM_ALIGNOF;

    4560                 :            : 
    4561                 :            :     /* Contents are protected with a CRC */
    4562                 :          0 :     INIT_CRC32C(ControlFile->crc);

    4568                 :            :     /*
    4569                 :            :      * We write out PG_CONTROL_FILE_SIZE bytes into pg_control, zero-padding
    4570                 :            :      * the excess over sizeof(ControlFileData).  This reduces the odds of
    4571                 :            :      * premature-EOF errors when reading pg_control.  We'll still fail when we
    4572                 :            :      * check the contents of the file, but hopefully with a more specific
    4573                 :            :      * error than "couldn't read pg_control".
    4574                 :            :      */

    4585                 :            :

    4707         [ -  + ]:       1455 :     if (ControlFile->floatFormat != FLOATFORMAT_VALUE)
    4708         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(FATAL,
    4709                 :            :                 (errmsg("database files are incompatible with server"),
    4710                 :            :                  errdetail("The database cluster appears to use a different floating-point number format than the server executable."),

    4712         [ -  + ]:       1455 :     if (ControlFile->blcksz != BLCKSZ)

    4714                 :            :                 (errmsg("database files are incompatible with server"),
    4715                 :            :                  errdetail("The database cluster was initialized with BLCKSZ %d,"
    4716                 :            :                            " but the server was compiled with BLCKSZ %d.",
    4717                 :            :                            ControlFile->blcksz, BLCKSZ),
    4718                 :            :                  errhint("It looks like you need to recompile or initdb.")));

    4721                 :            :                 (errmsg("database files are incompatible with server"),

    4867                 :            : /*
    4868                 :            :  * Returns a fake LSN for unlogged relations.
    4869                 :            :  *
    4870                 :            :  * Each call generates an LSN that is greater than any previous value
    4871                 :            :  * returned. The current counter value is saved and restored across clean
    4872                 :            :  * shutdowns, but like unlogged relations, does not survive a crash. This can
    4873                 :            :  * be used in lieu of real LSN values returned by XLogInsert, if you need an
    4874                 :            :  * LSN-like increasing sequence of numbers without writing any WAL.
    4875                 :            :  */
    4876                 :            : XLogRecPtr
    4877                 :          0 : GetFakeLSNForUnloggedRel(void)
    4878                 :            : {
    4879                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  nextUnloggedLSN;
    4880                 :            : 
    4881                 :            :     /* increment the unloggedLSN counter, need SpinLock */
    4882         [ #  # ]:          0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->ulsn_lck);
    4883                 :          0 :     nextUnloggedLSN = XLogCtl->unloggedLSN++;
    4884                 :          0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->ulsn_lck);
    4885                 :            : 
    4886                 :          0 :     return nextUnloggedLSN;
    4887                 :            : }
    4888                 :            : 
    4889                 :            : /*
    4890                 :            :  * Auto-tune the number of XLOG buffers.
    4891                 :            :  *
    4892                 :            :  * The preferred setting for wal_buffers is about 3% of shared_buffers, with
    4893                 :            :  * a maximum of one XLOG segment (there is little reason to think that more
    4894                 :            :  * is helpful, at least so long as we force an fsync when switching log files)
    4895                 :            :  * and a minimum of 8 blocks (which was the default value prior to PostgreSQL
    4896                 :            :  * 9.1, when auto-tuning was added).
    4897                 :            :  *
    4898                 :            :  * This should not be called until NBuffers has received its final value.
    4899                 :            :  */
    4900                 :            : static int
    4901                 :          0 : XLOGChooseNumBuffers(void)
    4902                 :            : {
    4903                 :            :     int         xbuffers;
    4904                 :            : 
    4905                 :          0 :     xbuffers = NBuffers / 32;
    4906         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (xbuffers > (wal_segment_size / XLOG_BLCKSZ))
    4907                 :          0 :         xbuffers = (wal_segment_size / XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    4908         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (xbuffers < 8)
    4909                 :          0 :         xbuffers = 8;
    4910                 :          0 :     return xbuffers;
    4911                 :            : }
    4912                 :            : 
    4913                 :            : /*
    4914                 :            :  * GUC check_hook for wal_buffers
    4915                 :            :  */
    4916                 :            : bool
    4917                 :       2910 : check_wal_buffers(int *newval, void **extra, GucSource source)
    4918                 :            : {
    4919                 :            :     /*
    4920                 :            :      * -1 indicates a request for auto-tune.
    4921                 :            :      */
    4922         [ +  + ]:       2910 :     if (*newval == -1)
    4923                 :            :     {
    4924                 :            :         /*
    4925                 :            :          * If we haven't yet changed the boot_val default of -1, just let it
    4926                 :            :          * be.  We'll fix it when XLOGShmemSize is called.
    4927                 :            :          */
    4928         [ +  - ]:       1455 :         if (XLOGbuffers == -1)
    4929                 :       1455 :             return true;
    4930                 :            : 
    4931                 :            :         /* Otherwise, substitute the auto-tune value */
    4932                 :          0 :         *newval = XLOGChooseNumBuffers();
    4933                 :            :     }
    4934                 :            : 
    4935                 :            :     /*
    4936                 :            :      * We clamp manually-set values to at least 4 blocks.  Prior to PostgreSQL
    4937                 :            :      * 9.1, a minimum of 4 was enforced by guc.c, but since that is no longer
    4938                 :            :      * the case, we just silently treat such values as a request for the
    4939                 :            :      * minimum.  (We could throw an error instead, but that doesn't seem very
    4940                 :            :      * helpful.)
    4941                 :            :      */
    4942         [ -  + ]:       1455 :     if (*newval < 4)
    4943                 :          0 :         *newval = 4;
    4944                 :            : 
    4945                 :       1455 :     return true;
    4946                 :            : }
    4947                 :            : 
    4948                 :            : /*
    4949                 :            :  * Read the control file, set respective GUCs.
    4950                 :            :  *
    4951                 :            :  * This is to be called during startup, including a crash recovery cycle,
    4952                 :            :  * unless in bootstrap mode, where no control file yet exists.  As there's no
    4953                 :            :  * usable shared memory yet (its sizing can depend on the contents of the
    4954                 :            :  * control file!), first store the contents in local memory. XLOGShmemInit()
    4955                 :            :  * will then copy it to shared memory later.
    4956                 :            :  *
    4957                 :            :  * reset just controls whether previous contents are to be expected (in the
    4958                 :            :  * reset case, there's a dangling pointer into old shared memory), or not.
    4959                 :            :  */
    4960                 :            : void
    4961                 :       1455 : LocalProcessControlFile(bool reset)
    4962                 :            : {
    4963                 :            :     Assert(reset || ControlFile == NULL);
    4964                 :       1455 :     ControlFile = palloc(sizeof(ControlFileData));
    4965                 :       1455 :     ReadControlFile();
    4966                 :       1455 : }
    4967                 :            : 
    4968                 :            : /*
    4969                 :            :  * Initialization of shared memory for XLOG
    4970                 :            :  */
    4971                 :            : Size
    4972                 :       2910 : XLOGShmemSize(void)
    4973                 :            : {
    4974                 :            :     Size        size;
    4975                 :            : 
    4976                 :            :     /*
    4977                 :            :      * If the value of wal_buffers is -1, use the preferred auto-tune value.
    4978                 :            :      * This isn't an amazingly clean place to do this, but we must wait till
    4979                 :            :      * NBuffers has received its final value, and must do it before using the
    4980                 :            :      * value of XLOGbuffers to do anything important.
    4981                 :            :      */
    4982         [ -  + ]:       2910 :     if (XLOGbuffers == -1)
    4983                 :            :     {
    4984                 :            :         char        buf[32];
    4985                 :            : 
    4986                 :          0 :         snprintf(buf, sizeof(buf), "%d", XLOGChooseNumBuffers());
    4987                 :          0 :         SetConfigOption("wal_buffers", buf, PGC_POSTMASTER, PGC_S_OVERRIDE);
    4988                 :            :     }
    4989                 :            :     Assert(XLOGbuffers > 0);
    4990                 :            : 
    4991                 :            :     /* XLogCtl */
    4992                 :       2910 :     size = sizeof(XLogCtlData);
    4993                 :            : 
    4994                 :            :     /* WAL insertion locks, plus alignment */
    4995                 :       2910 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(sizeof(WALInsertLockPadded), NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS + 1));
    4996                 :            :     /* xlblocks array */
    4997                 :       2910 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(sizeof(XLogRecPtr), XLOGbuffers));
    4998                 :            :     /* extra alignment padding for XLOG I/O buffers */
    4999                 :       2910 :     size = add_size(size, XLOG_BLCKSZ);
    5000                 :            :     /* and the buffers themselves */
    5001                 :       2910 :     size = add_size(size, mul_size(XLOG_BLCKSZ, XLOGbuffers));
    5002                 :            : 
    5003                 :            :     /*
    5004                 :            :      * Note: we don't count ControlFileData, it comes out of the "slop factor"
    5005                 :            :      * added by CreateSharedMemoryAndSemaphores.  This lets us use this
    5006                 :            :      * routine again below to compute the actual allocation size.
    5007                 :            :      */
    5008                 :            : 
    5009                 :       2910 :     return size;
    5010                 :            : }
    5011                 :            : 
    5012                 :            : void

    5120                 :            : 
    5121                 :            : /*
    5122                 :            :  * This func must be called ONCE on system install.  It creates pg_control

    5124                 :            :  */
    5125                 :            : void
    5126                 :          0 : BootStrapXLOG(void)
