    7885                 :          0 :         ControlFile->backupEndPoint <= lastReplayedEndRecPtr)
    7886                 :            :     {
    7887                 :            :         /*
    7888                 :            :          * We have reached the end of base backup, as indicated by pg_control.
    7889                 :            :          * The data on disk is now consistent. Reset backupStartPoint and
    7890                 :            :          * backupEndPoint, and update minRecoveryPoint to make sure we don't
    7891                 :            :          * allow starting up at an earlier point even if recovery is stopped
    7892                 :            :          * and restarted soon after this.
    7893                 :            :          */
    7894                 :          0 :         elog(DEBUG1, "end of backup reached");
    7895                 :            : 
    7896                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    7897                 :            :

    7902                 :          0 :         ControlFile->backupEndPoint = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    7903                 :          0 :         ControlFile->backupEndRequired = false;
    7904                 :          0 :         UpdateControlFile();
    7905                 :            : 
    7906                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    7907                 :            :     }
    7908                 :            :

    7911                 :            :      * known to be incorrectly set if ControlFile->backupEndRequired, until

    7914                 :            :      * consistent yet.

    7936                 :            :      * enabling connections.

    7938 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (standbyState == STANDBY_SNAPSHOT_READY &&

    7952                 :            : 
    7953                 :            : /*
    7954                 :            :  * Is the system still in recovery?
    7955                 :            :  *
    7956                 :            :  * Unlike testing InRecovery, this works in any process that's connected to
    7957                 :            :  * shared memory.
    7958                 :            :  *
    7959                 :            :  * As a side-effect, we initialize the local TimeLineID and RedoRecPtr
    7960                 :            :  * variables the first time we see that recovery is finished.
    7961                 :            :  */
    7962                 :            : bool
    7963                 :   14707923 : RecoveryInProgress(void)
    7964                 :            : {
    7965                 :            :     /*
    7966                 :            :      * We check shared state each time only until we leave recovery mode. We
    7967                 :            :      * can't re-enter recovery, so there's no need to keep checking after the
    7968                 :            :      * shared variable has once been seen false.
    7969                 :            :      */
    7970         [ +  + ]:   14707923 :     if (!LocalRecoveryInProgress)
    7971                 :   14707064 :         return false;
    7972                 :            :     else
    7973                 :            :     {
    7974                 :            :         /*
    7975                 :            :          * use volatile pointer to make sure we make a fresh read of the
    7976                 :            :          * shared variable.
    7977                 :            :          */
    7978                 :        859 :         volatile XLogCtlData *xlogctl = XLogCtl;
    7979                 :            : 
    7980                 :        859 :         LocalRecoveryInProgress = (xlogctl->SharedRecoveryState != RECOVERY_STATE_DONE);
    7981                 :            : 
    7982                 :            :         /*
    7983                 :            :          * Initialize TimeLineID and RedoRecPtr when we discover that recovery
    7984                 :            :          * is finished. InitPostgres() relies upon this behaviour to ensure
    7985                 :            :          * that InitXLOGAccess() is called at backend startup.  (If you change
    7986                 :            :          * this, see also LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed.)
    7987                 :            :          */
    7988         [ +  - ]:        859 :         if (!LocalRecoveryInProgress)
    7989                 :            :         {
    7990                 :            :             /*
    7991                 :            :              * If we just exited recovery, make sure we read TimeLineID and
    7992                 :            :              * RedoRecPtr after SharedRecoveryState (for machines with weak
    7993                 :            :              * memory ordering).
    7994                 :            :              */
    7995                 :        859 :             pg_memory_barrier();
    7996                 :        859 :             InitXLOGAccess();
    7997                 :            :         }
    7998                 :            : 
    7999                 :            :         /*
    8000                 :            :          * Note: We don't need a memory barrier when we're still in recovery.
    8001                 :            :          * We might exit recovery immediately after return, so the caller
    8002                 :            :          * can't rely on 'true' meaning that we're still in recovery anyway.
    8003                 :            :          */
    8004                 :            : 
    8005                 :        859 :         return LocalRecoveryInProgress;
    8006                 :            :     }
    8007                 :            : }
    8008                 :            : 
    8009                 :            : /*
    8010                 :            :  * Returns current recovery state from shared memory.
    8011                 :            :  *
    8012                 :            :  * This returned state is kept consistent with the contents of the control

    8026                 :            : 
    8027                 :            : /*
    8028                 :            :  * Is HotStandby active yet? This is only important in special backends

    8031                 :            :  *

    8035                 :            :  */
    8036                 :            : bool

    8056                 :            : 
    8057                 :            : /*

    8067                 :            : 
    8068                 :            : /*
    8069                 :            :  * Is this process allowed to insert new WAL records?
    8070                 :            :  *
    8071                 :            :  * Ordinarily this is essentially equivalent to !RecoveryInProgress().
    8072                 :            :  * But we also have provisions for forcing the result "true" or "false"
    8073                 :            :  * within specific processes regardless of the global state.
    8074                 :            :  */
    8075                 :            : bool
    8076                 :    2401589 : XLogInsertAllowed(void)
    8077                 :            : {
    8078                 :            :     /*
    8079                 :            :      * If value is "unconditionally true" or "unconditionally false", just
    8080                 :            :      * return it.  This provides the normal fast path once recovery is known
    8081                 :            :      * done.
    8082                 :            :      */

    8084                 :    2400757 :         return (bool) LocalXLogInsertAllowed;
    8085                 :            : 
    8086                 :            :     /*
    8087                 :            :      * Else, must check to see if we're still in recovery.
    8088                 :            :      */

    8090                 :          0 :         return false;

    8094                 :            :      * no need to keep checking.
    8095                 :            :      */
    8096                 :        832 :     LocalXLogInsertAllowed = 1;
    8097                 :        832 :     return true;
    8098                 :            : }
    8099                 :            : 
    8100                 :            : /*
    8101                 :            :  * Make XLogInsertAllowed() return true in the current process only.
    8102                 :            :  *
    8103                 :            :  * Note: it is allowed to switch LocalXLogInsertAllowed back to -1 later,
    8104                 :            :  * and even call LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed() again after that.
    8105                 :            :  */
    8106                 :            : static void
    8107                 :          2 : LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed(void)

    8109                 :            :     Assert(LocalXLogInsertAllowed == -1);
    8110                 :          2 :     LocalXLogInsertAllowed = 1;
    8111                 :            : 
    8112                 :            :     /* Initialize as RecoveryInProgress() would do when switching state */
    8113                 :          2 :     InitXLOGAccess();
    8114                 :          2 : }
    8115                 :            : 
    8116                 :            : /*
    8117                 :            :  * Subroutine to try to fetch and validate a prior checkpoint record.
    8118                 :            :  *
    8119                 :            :  * whichChkpt identifies the checkpoint (merely for reporting purposes).
    8120                 :            :  * 1 for "primary", 0 for "other" (backup_label)
    8121                 :            :  */
    8122                 :            : static XLogRecord *
    8123                 :          1 : ReadCheckpointRecord(XLogReaderState *xlogreader, XLogRecPtr RecPtr,
    8124                 :            :                      int whichChkpt, bool report)
    8125                 :            : {

    8218                 :            : /*
    8219                 :            :  * This must be called in a backend process before creating WAL records
    8220                 :            :  * (except in a standalone backend, which does StartupXLOG instead).  We need
    8221                 :            :  * to initialize the local copies of ThisTimeLineID and RedoRecPtr.
    8222                 :            :  *
    8223                 :            :  * Note: before Postgres 8.0, we went to some effort to keep the postmaster
    8224                 :            :  * process's copies of ThisTimeLineID and RedoRecPtr valid too.  This was
    8225                 :            :  * unnecessary however, since the postmaster itself never touches XLOG anyway.
    8226                 :            :  */

    8248                 :            : /*

    8259                 :            :      * The possibly not up-to-date copy in XlogCtl is enough. Even if we
    8260                 :            :      * grabbed a WAL insertion lock to read the master copy, someone might
    8261                 :            :      * update it just after we've released the lock.
    8262                 :            :      */

    8265                 :       1014 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8266                 :            : 
    8267         [ +  + ]:       1014 :     if (RedoRecPtr < ptr)
    8268                 :        859 :         RedoRecPtr = ptr;
    8269                 :            :

    8271                 :            : }
    8272                 :            : 
    8273                 :            : /*
    8274                 :            :  * Return information needed to decide whether a modified block needs a
    8275                 :            :  * full-page image to be included in the WAL record.
    8276                 :            :  *
    8277                 :            :  * The returned values are cached copies from backend-private memory, and
    8278                 :            :  * possibly out-of-date.  XLogInsertRecord will re-check them against
    8279                 :            :  * up-to-date values, while holding the WAL insert lock.
    8280                 :            :  */
    8281                 :            : void
    8282                 :    1158935 : GetFullPageWriteInfo(XLogRecPtr *RedoRecPtr_p, bool *doPageWrites_p)

    8287                 :            : 
    8288                 :            : /*
    8289                 :            :  * GetInsertRecPtr -- Returns the current insert position.
    8290                 :            :  *
    8291                 :            :  * NOTE: The value *actually* returned is the position of the last full
    8292                 :            :  * xlog page. It lags behind the real insert position by at most 1 page.
    8293                 :            :  * For that, we don't need to scan through WAL insertion locks, and an
    8294                 :            :  * approximation is enough for the current usage of this function.
    8295                 :            :  */
    8296                 :            : XLogRecPtr

    8299                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8300                 :            :

    8302                 :         75 :     recptr = XLogCtl->LogwrtRqst.Write;
    8303                 :         75 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8304                 :            : 
    8305                 :         75 :     return recptr;
    8306                 :            : }
    8307                 :            : 
    8308                 :            : /*
    8309                 :            :  * GetFlushRecPtr -- Returns the current flush position, ie, the last WAL
    8310                 :            :  * position known to be fsync'd to disk.

    8321                 :            : 
    8322                 :            : /*
    8323                 :            :  * GetLastImportantRecPtr -- Returns the LSN of the last important record
    8324                 :            :  * inserted. All records not explicitly marked as unimportant are considered
    8325                 :            :  * important.
    8326                 :            :  *
    8327                 :            :  * The LSN is determined by computing the maximum of
    8328                 :            :  * WALInsertLocks[i].lastImportantAt.
    8329                 :            :  */
    8330                 :            : XLogRecPtr
    8331                 :        175 : GetLastImportantRecPtr(void)
    8332                 :            : {
    8333                 :        175 :     XLogRecPtr  res = InvalidXLogRecPtr;
    8334                 :            :     int         i;
    8335                 :            : 
    8336         [ +  + ]:       1575 :     for (i = 0; i < NUM_XLOGINSERT_LOCKS; i++)
    8337                 :            :     {
    8338                 :            :         XLogRecPtr  last_important;
    8339                 :            : 
    8340                 :            :         /*
    8341                 :            :          * Need to take a lock to prevent torn reads of the LSN, which are
    8342                 :            :          * possible on some of the supported platforms. WAL insert locks only
    8343                 :            :          * support exclusive mode, so we have to use that.
    8344                 :            :          */
    8345                 :       1400 :         LWLockAcquire(&WALInsertLocks[i].l.lock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);

    8348                 :            :

    8350                 :        512 :             res = last_important;
    8351                 :            :     }
    8352                 :            :

    8354                 :            : }

    8373                 :            : /*

    8376                 :            : void
    8377                 :          1 : ShutdownXLOG(int code, Datum arg)
    8378                 :            : {
    8379                 :            :     /*
    8380                 :            :      * We should have an aux process resource owner to use, and we should not
    8381                 :            :      * be in a transaction that's installed some other resowner.

    8384                 :            :     Assert(CurrentResourceOwner == NULL ||
    8385                 :            :            CurrentResourceOwner == AuxProcessResourceOwner);
    8386                 :          1 :     CurrentResourceOwner = AuxProcessResourceOwner;
    8387                 :            : 
    8388                 :            :     /* Don't be chatty in standalone mode */
    8389 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:          1 :     ereport(IsPostmasterEnvironment ? LOG : NOTICE,
    8390                 :            :             (errmsg("shutting down")));

    8394                 :            :      */
    8395                 :          1 :     WalSndInitStopping();
    8396                 :            :

    8398                 :            :      * Wait for WAL senders to be in stopping state.  This prevents commands
    8399                 :            :      * from writing new WAL.
    8400                 :            :      */
    8401                 :          1 :     WalSndWaitStopping();
    8402                 :            : 
    8403         [ -  + ]:          1 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    8404                 :          0 :         CreateRestartPoint(CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE);
    8405                 :            :     else
    8406                 :            :     {
    8407                 :            :         /*

    8409                 :            :          * remaining records are archived (postmaster wakes up the archiver
    8410                 :            :          * process one more time at the end of shutdown). The checkpoint
    8411                 :            :          * record will go to the next XLOG file and won't be archived (yet).
    8412                 :            :          */
    8413 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:          1 :         if (XLogArchivingActive() && XLogArchiveCommandSet())

    8417                 :            :     }

    8442                 :            : /*
    8443                 :            :  * Log end of a checkpoint.
    8444                 :            :  */
    8445                 :            : static void
    8446                 :         76 : LogCheckpointEnd(bool restartpoint)
    8447                 :            : {
    8448                 :            :     long        write_msecs,
    8449                 :            :                 sync_msecs,
    8450                 :            :                 total_msecs,
    8451                 :            :                 longest_msecs,
    8452                 :            :                 average_msecs;
    8453                 :            :     uint64      average_sync_time;
    8454                 :            : 
    8455                 :         76 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_end_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    8456                 :            : 
    8457                 :         76 :     write_msecs = TimestampDifferenceMilliseconds(CheckpointStats.ckpt_write_t,
    8458                 :            :                                                   CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_t);
    8459                 :            : 
    8460                 :         76 :     sync_msecs = TimestampDifferenceMilliseconds(CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_t,
    8461                 :            :                                                  CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_end_t);
    8462                 :            : 
    8463                 :            :     /* Accumulate checkpoint timing summary data, in milliseconds. */
    8464                 :         76 :     BgWriterStats.m_checkpoint_write_time += write_msecs;
    8465                 :         76 :     BgWriterStats.m_checkpoint_sync_time += sync_msecs;
    8466                 :            : 
    8467                 :            :     /*
    8468                 :            :      * All of the published timing statistics are accounted for.  Only
    8469                 :            :      * continue if a log message is to be written.
    8470                 :            :      */
    8471         [ +  - ]:         76 :     if (!log_checkpoints)
    8472                 :         76 :         return;
    8473                 :            : 
    8474                 :          0 :     total_msecs = TimestampDifferenceMilliseconds(CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t,
    8475                 :            :                                                   CheckpointStats.ckpt_end_t);
    8476                 :            : 
    8477                 :            :     /*
    8478                 :            :      * Timing values returned from CheckpointStats are in microseconds.
    8479                 :            :      * Convert to milliseconds for consistent printing.
    8480                 :            :      */
    8481                 :          0 :     longest_msecs = (long) ((CheckpointStats.ckpt_longest_sync + 999) / 1000);
    8482                 :            : 
    8483                 :          0 :     average_sync_time = 0;
    8484         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels > 0)
    8485                 :          0 :         average_sync_time = CheckpointStats.ckpt_agg_sync_time /
    8486                 :          0 :             CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels;
    8487                 :          0 :     average_msecs = (long) ((average_sync_time + 999) / 1000);
    8488                 :            : 
    8489         [ #  # ]:          0 :     elog(LOG, "%s complete: wrote %d buffers (%.1f%%); "
    8490                 :            :          "%d WAL file(s) added, %d removed, %d recycled; "
    8491                 :            :          "write=%ld.%03d s, sync=%ld.%03d s, total=%ld.%03d s; "
    8492                 :            :          "sync files=%d, longest=%ld.%03d s, average=%ld.%03d s; "
    8493                 :            :          "distance=%d kB, estimate=%d kB",
    8494                 :            :          restartpoint ? "restartpoint" : "checkpoint",
    8495                 :            :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written,
    8496                 :            :          (double) CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written * 100 / NBuffers,
    8497                 :            :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added,
    8498                 :            :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed,
    8499                 :            :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled,
    8500                 :            :          write_msecs / 1000, (int) (write_msecs % 1000),
    8501                 :            :          sync_msecs / 1000, (int) (sync_msecs % 1000),
    8502                 :            :          total_msecs / 1000, (int) (total_msecs % 1000),
    8503                 :            :          CheckpointStats.ckpt_sync_rels,
    8504                 :            :          longest_msecs / 1000, (int) (longest_msecs % 1000),
    8505                 :            :          average_msecs / 1000, (int) (average_msecs % 1000),
    8506                 :            :          (int) (PrevCheckPointDistance / 1024.0),
    8507                 :            :          (int) (CheckPointDistanceEstimate / 1024.0));
    8508                 :            : }
    8509                 :            : 
    8510                 :            : /*
    8511                 :            :  * Update the estimate of distance between checkpoints.
    8512                 :            :  *
    8513                 :            :  * The estimate is used to calculate the number of WAL segments to keep
    8514                 :            :  * preallocated, see XLOGFileSlop().
    8515                 :            :  */
    8516                 :            : static void
    8517                 :         76 : UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(uint64 nbytes)
    8518                 :            : {
    8519                 :            :     /*
    8520                 :            :      * To estimate the number of segments consumed between checkpoints, keep a
    8521                 :            :      * moving average of the amount of WAL generated in previous checkpoint
    8522                 :            :      * cycles. However, if the load is bursty, with quiet periods and busy
    8523                 :            :      * periods, we want to cater for the peak load. So instead of a plain
    8524                 :            :      * moving average, let the average decline slowly if the previous cycle
    8525                 :            :      * used less WAL than estimated, but bump it up immediately if it used
    8526                 :            :      * more.
    8527                 :            :      *
    8528                 :            :      * When checkpoints are triggered by max_wal_size, this should converge to
    8529                 :            :      * CheckpointSegments * wal_segment_size,
    8530                 :            :      *
    8531                 :            :      * Note: This doesn't pay any attention to what caused the checkpoint.
    8532                 :            :      * Checkpoints triggered manually with CHECKPOINT command, or by e.g.
    8533                 :            :      * starting a base backup, are counted the same as those created
    8534                 :            :      * automatically. The slow-decline will largely mask them out, if they are
    8535                 :            :      * not frequent. If they are frequent, it seems reasonable to count them
    8536                 :            :      * in as any others; if you issue a manual checkpoint every 5 minutes and
    8537                 :            :      * never let a timed checkpoint happen, it makes sense to base the
    8538                 :            :      * preallocation on that 5 minute interval rather than whatever
    8539                 :            :      * checkpoint_timeout is set to.
    8540                 :            :      */
    8541                 :         76 :     PrevCheckPointDistance = nbytes;
    8542         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (CheckPointDistanceEstimate < nbytes)
    8543                 :         13 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate = nbytes;
    8544                 :            :     else
    8545                 :         63 :         CheckPointDistanceEstimate =
    8546                 :         63 :             (0.90 * CheckPointDistanceEstimate + 0.10 * (double) nbytes);
    8547                 :         76 : }
    8548                 :            : 
    8549                 :            : /*
    8550                 :            :  * Perform a checkpoint --- either during shutdown, or on-the-fly
    8551                 :            :  *
    8552                 :            :  * flags is a bitwise OR of the following:
    8553                 :            :  *  CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN: checkpoint is for database shutdown.
    8554                 :            :  *  CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY: checkpoint is for end of WAL recovery.
    8555                 :            :  *  CHECKPOINT_IMMEDIATE: finish the checkpoint ASAP,
    8556                 :            :  *      ignoring checkpoint_completion_target parameter.
    8557                 :            :  *  CHECKPOINT_FORCE: force a checkpoint even if no XLOG activity has occurred
    8558                 :            :  *      since the last one (implied by CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN or
    8559                 :            :  *      CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY).
    8560                 :            :  *  CHECKPOINT_FLUSH_ALL: also flush buffers of unlogged tables.
    8561                 :            :  *
    8562                 :            :  * Note: flags contains other bits, of interest here only for logging purposes.
    8563                 :            :  * In particular note that this routine is synchronous and does not pay
    8564                 :            :  * attention to CHECKPOINT_WAIT.
    8565                 :            :  *
    8566                 :            :  * If !shutdown then we are writing an online checkpoint. This is a very special
    8567                 :            :  * kind of operation and WAL record because the checkpoint action occurs over
    8568                 :            :  * a period of time yet logically occurs at just a single LSN. The logical
    8569                 :            :  * position of the WAL record (redo ptr) is the same or earlier than the
    8570                 :            :  * physical position. When we replay WAL we locate the checkpoint via its
    8571                 :            :  * physical position then read the redo ptr and actually start replay at the
    8572                 :            :  * earlier logical position. Note that we don't write *anything* to WAL at
    8573                 :            :  * the logical position, so that location could be any other kind of WAL record.
    8574                 :            :  * All of this mechanism allows us to continue working while we checkpoint.
    8575                 :            :  * As a result, timing of actions is critical here and be careful to note that
    8576                 :            :  * this function will likely take minutes to execute on a busy system.
    8577                 :            :  */
    8578                 :            : void
    8579                 :         76 : CreateCheckPoint(int flags)
    8580                 :            : {
    8581                 :            :     bool        shutdown;
    8582                 :            :     CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    8583                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8584                 :            :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    8585                 :         76 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    8586                 :            :     uint32      freespace;
    8587                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  PriorRedoPtr;
    8588                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  curInsert;
    8589                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  last_important_lsn;
    8590                 :            :     VirtualTransactionId *vxids;
    8591                 :            :     int         nvxids;
    8592                 :            : 
    8593                 :            :     /*
    8594                 :            :      * An end-of-recovery checkpoint is really a shutdown checkpoint, just
    8595                 :            :      * issued at a different time.
    8596                 :            :      */
    8597         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (flags & (CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY))
    8598                 :          1 :         shutdown = true;
    8599                 :            :     else
    8600                 :         75 :         shutdown = false;
    8601                 :            : 
    8602                 :            :     /* sanity check */
    8603 [ -  + ][ #  # ]:         76 :     if (RecoveryInProgress() && (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY) == 0)
    8604                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "can't create a checkpoint during recovery");
    8605                 :            : 
    8606                 :            :     /*
    8607                 :            :      * Initialize InitXLogInsert working areas before entering the critical
    8608                 :            :      * section.  Normally, this is done by the first call to
    8609                 :            :      * RecoveryInProgress() or LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed(), but when creating
    8610                 :            :      * an end-of-recovery checkpoint, the LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed call is
    8611                 :            :      * done below in a critical section, and InitXLogInsert cannot be called
    8612                 :            :      * in a critical section.
    8613                 :            :      */
    8614                 :         76 :     InitXLogInsert();
    8615                 :            : 
    8616                 :            :     /*
    8617                 :            :      * Acquire CheckpointLock to ensure only one checkpoint happens at a time.
    8618                 :            :      * (This is just pro forma, since in the present system structure there is
    8619                 :            :      * only one process that is allowed to issue checkpoints at any given
    8620                 :            :      * time.)
    8621                 :            :      */
    8622                 :         76 :     LWLockAcquire(CheckpointLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8623                 :            : 
    8624                 :            :     /*
    8625                 :            :      * Prepare to accumulate statistics.
    8626                 :            :      *
    8627                 :            :      * Note: because it is possible for log_checkpoints to change while a
    8628                 :            :      * checkpoint proceeds, we always accumulate stats, even if
    8629                 :            :      * log_checkpoints is currently off.
    8630                 :            :      */
    8631 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:        836 :     MemSet(&CheckpointStats, 0, sizeof(CheckpointStats));
         [ +  - ][ +  - ]
                 [ +  + ]
    8632                 :         76 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    8633                 :            : 
    8634                 :            :     /*
    8635                 :            :      * Use a critical section to force system panic if we have trouble.
    8636                 :            :      */
    8637                 :         76 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    8638                 :            : 
    8639         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (shutdown)
    8640                 :            :     {
    8641                 :          1 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    8642                 :          1 :         ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNING;
    8643                 :          1 :         ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8644                 :          1 :         UpdateControlFile();
    8645                 :          1 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    8646                 :            :     }
    8647                 :            : 
    8648                 :            :     /*
    8649                 :            :      * Let smgr prepare for checkpoint; this has to happen before we determine
    8650                 :            :      * the REDO pointer.  Note that smgr must not do anything that'd have to
    8651                 :            :      * be undone if we decide no checkpoint is needed.
    8652                 :            :      */
    8653                 :         76 :     SyncPreCheckpoint();
    8654                 :            : 
    8655                 :            :     /* Begin filling in the checkpoint WAL record */
    8656 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:        912 :     MemSet(&checkPoint, 0, sizeof(checkPoint));
         [ +  - ][ +  - ]

    8657                 :         76 :     checkPoint.time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    8658                 :            :

    8660                 :            :      * For Hot Standby, derive the oldestActiveXid before we fix the redo
    8661                 :            :      * pointer. This allows us to begin accumulating changes to assemble our
    8662                 :            :      * starting snapshot of locks and transactions.
    8663                 :            :      */

    8666                 :            :     else
    8667                 :          1 :         checkPoint.oldestActiveXid = InvalidTransactionId;
    8668                 :            : 
    8669                 :            :     /*

    8674                 :            :

    8677                 :            :      * determine the checkpoint REDO pointer.
    8678                 :            :      */
    8679                 :         76 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    8680                 :         76 :     curInsert = XLogBytePosToRecPtr(Insert->CurrBytePos);
    8681                 :            : 
    8682                 :            :     /*

    8685                 :            :      * avoid inserting duplicate checkpoints when the system is idle.
    8686                 :            :      */
    8687         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if ((flags & (CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN | CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY |
    8688                 :            :                   CHECKPOINT_FORCE)) == 0)
    8689                 :            :     {
    8690         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (last_important_lsn == ControlFile->checkPoint)
    8691                 :            :         {
    8692                 :          0 :             WALInsertLockRelease();
    8693                 :          0 :             LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    8694                 :          0 :             END_CRIT_SECTION();

    8696                 :            :                     (errmsg("checkpoint skipped because system is idle")));
    8697                 :          0 :             return;
    8698                 :            :         }
    8699                 :            :     }
    8700                 :            : 
    8701                 :            :     /*
    8702                 :            :      * An end-of-recovery checkpoint is created before anyone is allowed to

    8704                 :            :      * enable XLogInsertAllowed.  (This also ensures ThisTimeLineID is
    8705                 :            :      * initialized, which we need here and in AdvanceXLInsertBuffer.)
    8706                 :            :      */

    8708                 :          0 :         LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed();
    8709                 :            : 
    8710                 :         76 :     checkPoint.ThisTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    8711         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY)
    8712                 :          0 :         checkPoint.PrevTimeLineID = XLogCtl->PrevTimeLineID;

    8715                 :            : 
    8716                 :         76 :     checkPoint.fullPageWrites = Insert->fullPageWrites;
    8717                 :            : 
    8718                 :            :     /*
    8719                 :            :      * Compute new REDO record ptr = location of next XLOG record.
    8720                 :            :      *
    8721                 :            :      * NB: this is NOT necessarily where the checkpoint record itself will be,
    8722                 :            :      * since other backends may insert more XLOG records while we're off doing
    8723                 :            :      * the buffer flush work.  Those XLOG records are logically after the
    8724                 :            :      * checkpoint, even though physically before it.  Got that?
    8725                 :            :      */
    8726         [ +  - ]:         76 :     freespace = INSERT_FREESPACE(curInsert);
    8727         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (freespace == 0)
    8728                 :            :     {
    8729         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (XLogSegmentOffset(curInsert, wal_segment_size) == 0)
    8730                 :          0 :             curInsert += SizeOfXLogLongPHD;
    8731                 :            :         else
    8732                 :          0 :             curInsert += SizeOfXLogShortPHD;
    8733                 :            :     }
    8734                 :         76 :     checkPoint.redo = curInsert;
    8735                 :            : 
    8736                 :            :     /*
    8737                 :            :      * Here we update the shared RedoRecPtr for future XLogInsert calls; this
    8738                 :            :      * must be done while holding all the insertion locks.
    8739                 :            :      *
    8740                 :            :      * Note: if we fail to complete the checkpoint, RedoRecPtr will be left
    8741                 :            :      * pointing past where it really needs to point.  This is okay; the only
    8742                 :            :      * consequence is that XLogInsert might back up whole buffers that it
    8743                 :            :      * didn't really need to.  We can't postpone advancing RedoRecPtr because
    8744                 :            :      * XLogInserts that happen while we are dumping buffers must assume that
    8745                 :            :      * their buffer changes are not included in the checkpoint.
    8746                 :            :      */
    8747                 :         76 :     RedoRecPtr = XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr = checkPoint.redo;
    8748                 :            : 
    8749                 :            :     /*
    8750                 :            :      * Now we can release the WAL insertion locks, allowing other xacts to
    8751                 :            :      * proceed while we are flushing disk buffers.
    8752                 :            :      */
    8753                 :         76 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    8754                 :            : 
    8755                 :            :     /* Update the info_lck-protected copy of RedoRecPtr as well */
    8756         [ -  + ]:         76 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8757                 :         76 :     XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr = checkPoint.redo;
    8758                 :         76 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    8759                 :            : 
    8760                 :            :     /*
    8761                 :            :      * If enabled, log checkpoint start.  We postpone this until now so as not
    8762                 :            :      * to log anything if we decided to skip the checkpoint.
    8763                 :            :      */
    8764         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (log_checkpoints)
    8765                 :          0 :         LogCheckpointStart(flags, false);
    8766                 :            : 
    8767                 :         76 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_CHECKPOINT_START(flags);
    8768                 :            : 
    8769                 :            :     /*
    8770                 :            :      * Get the other info we need for the checkpoint record.
    8771                 :            :      *
    8772                 :            :      * We don't need to save oldestClogXid in the checkpoint, it only matters
    8773                 :            :      * for the short period in which clog is being truncated, and if we crash
    8774                 :            :      * during that we'll redo the clog truncation and fix up oldestClogXid
    8775                 :            :      * there.
    8776                 :            :      */
    8777                 :         76 :     LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_SHARED);
    8778                 :         76 :     checkPoint.nextFullXid = ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid;
    8779                 :         76 :     checkPoint.oldestXid = ShmemVariableCache->oldestXid;
    8780                 :         76 :     checkPoint.oldestXidDB = ShmemVariableCache->oldestXidDB;
    8781                 :         76 :     LWLockRelease(XidGenLock);
    8782                 :            : 
    8783                 :         76 :     LWLockAcquire(CommitTsLock, LW_SHARED);
    8784                 :         76 :     checkPoint.oldestCommitTsXid = ShmemVariableCache->oldestCommitTsXid;
    8785                 :         76 :     checkPoint.newestCommitTsXid = ShmemVariableCache->newestCommitTsXid;
    8786                 :         76 :     LWLockRelease(CommitTsLock);
    8787                 :            : 
    8788                 :         76 :     LWLockAcquire(OidGenLock, LW_SHARED);
    8789                 :         76 :     checkPoint.nextOid = ShmemVariableCache->nextOid;
    8790         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (!shutdown)
    8791                 :         75 :         checkPoint.nextOid += ShmemVariableCache->oidCount;
    8792                 :         76 :     LWLockRelease(OidGenLock);
    8793                 :            : 
    8794                 :         76 :     MultiXactGetCheckptMulti(shutdown,
    8795                 :            :                              &checkPoint.nextMulti,

    8797                 :            :                              &checkPoint.oldestMulti,
    8798                 :            :                              &checkPoint.oldestMultiDB);
    8799                 :            : 
    8800                 :            :     /*
    8801                 :            :      * Having constructed the checkpoint record, ensure all shmem disk buffers
    8802                 :            :      * and commit-log buffers are flushed to disk.
    8803                 :            :      *
    8804                 :            :      * This I/O could fail for various reasons.  If so, we will fail to
    8805                 :            :      * complete the checkpoint, but there is no reason to force a system
    8806                 :            :      * panic. Accordingly, exit critical section while doing it.
    8807                 :            :      */
    8808                 :         76 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    8809                 :            : 
    8810                 :            :     /*
    8811                 :            :      * In some cases there are groups of actions that must all occur on one
    8812                 :            :      * side or the other of a checkpoint record. Before flushing the
    8813                 :            :      * checkpoint record we must explicitly wait for any backend currently
    8814                 :            :      * performing those groups of actions.
    8815                 :            :      *
    8816                 :            :      * One example is end of transaction, so we must wait for any transactions
    8817                 :            :      * that are currently in commit critical sections.  If an xact inserted
    8818                 :            :      * its commit record into XLOG just before the REDO point, then a crash
    8819                 :            :      * restart from the REDO point would not replay that record, which means
    8820                 :            :      * that our flushing had better include the xact's update of pg_xact.  So
    8821                 :            :      * we wait till he's out of his commit critical section before proceeding.
    8822                 :            :      * See notes in RecordTransactionCommit().
    8823                 :            :      *
    8824                 :            :      * Because we've already released the insertion locks, this test is a bit
    8825                 :            :      * fuzzy: it is possible that we will wait for xacts we didn't really need
    8826                 :            :      * to wait for.  But the delay should be short and it seems better to make
    8827                 :            :      * checkpoint take a bit longer than to hold off insertions longer than
    8828                 :            :      * necessary. (In fact, the whole reason we have this issue is that xact.c
    8829                 :            :      * does commit record XLOG insertion and clog update as two separate steps
    8830                 :            :      * protected by different locks, but again that seems best on grounds of
    8831                 :            :      * minimizing lock contention.)
    8832                 :            :      *
    8833                 :            :      * A transaction that has not yet set delayChkpt when we look cannot be at
    8834                 :            :      * risk, since he's not inserted his commit record yet; and one that's
    8835                 :            :      * already cleared it is not at risk either, since he's done fixing clog
    8836                 :            :      * and we will correctly flush the update below.  So we cannot miss any
    8837                 :            :      * xacts we need to wait for.
    8838                 :            :      */
    8839                 :         76 :     vxids = GetVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(&nvxids);
    8840         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (nvxids > 0)
    8841                 :            :     {
    8842                 :            :         do
    8843                 :            :         {
    8844                 :          0 :             pg_usleep(10000L);  /* wait for 10 msec */
    8845         [ #  # ]:          0 :         } while (HaveVirtualXIDsDelayingChkpt(vxids, nvxids));
    8846                 :            :     }
    8847                 :         76 :     pfree(vxids);
    8848                 :            : 
    8849                 :         76 :     CheckPointGuts(checkPoint.redo, flags);
    8850                 :            : 
    8851                 :            :     /*
    8852                 :            :      * Take a snapshot of running transactions and write this to WAL. This
    8853                 :            :      * allows us to reconstruct the state of running transactions during
    8854                 :            :      * archive recovery, if required. Skip, if this info disabled.
    8855                 :            :      *
    8856                 :            :      * If we are shutting down, or Startup process is completing crash
    8857                 :            :      * recovery we don't need to write running xact data.
    8858                 :            :      */

    8861                 :            : 
    8862                 :         76 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();

    8864                 :            :     /*
    8865                 :            :      * Now insert the checkpoint record into XLOG.
    8866                 :            :      */
    8867                 :         76 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    8868                 :         76 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) (&checkPoint), sizeof(checkPoint));
    8869         [ +  + ]:         76 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID,
    8870                 :            :                         shutdown ? XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN :
    8871                 :            :                         XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE);

    8873                 :         76 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    8874                 :            : 
    8875                 :            :     /*
    8876                 :            :      * We mustn't write any new WAL after a shutdown checkpoint, or it will be
    8877                 :            :      * overwritten at next startup.  No-one should even try, this just allows
    8878                 :            :      * sanity-checking.  In the case of an end-of-recovery checkpoint, we want
    8879                 :            :      * to just temporarily disable writing until the system has exited
    8880                 :            :      * recovery.
    8881                 :            :      */
    8882         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (shutdown)
    8883                 :            :     {
    8884         [ -  + ]:          1 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_END_OF_RECOVERY)
    8885                 :          0 :             LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;    /* return to "check" state */
    8886                 :            :         else
    8887                 :          1 :             LocalXLogInsertAllowed = 0; /* never again write WAL */
    8888                 :            :     }
    8889                 :            :

    8891                 :            :      * We now have ProcLastRecPtr = start of actual checkpoint record, recptr

    8936                 :            :      * have trouble while fooling with old log segments.

    8943                 :         76 :     SyncPostCheckpoint();
    8944                 :            :

    8947                 :            :      * exists.

    8949         [ +  - ]:         76 :     if (PriorRedoPtr != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
