    8951                 :            : 
    8952                 :            :     /*
    8953                 :            :      * Delete old log files, those no longer needed for last checkpoint to
    8954                 :            :      * prevent the disk holding the xlog from growing full.
    8955                 :            :      */
    8956                 :         76 :     XLByteToSeg(RedoRecPtr, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    8957                 :         76 :     KeepLogSeg(recptr, &_logSegNo);
    8958                 :         76 :     _logSegNo--;
    8959                 :         76 :     RemoveOldXlogFiles(_logSegNo, RedoRecPtr, recptr);
    8960                 :            : 
    8961                 :            :     /*
    8962                 :            :      * Make more log segments if needed.  (Do this after recycling old log
    8963                 :            :      * segments, since that may supply some of the needed files.)
    8964                 :            :      */
    8965         [ +  + ]:         76 :     if (!shutdown)
    8966                 :         75 :         PreallocXlogFiles(recptr);
    8967                 :            : 
    8968                 :            :     /*
    8969                 :            :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    8970                 :            :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    8971                 :            :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    8972                 :            :      * in subtrans.c).  During recovery, though, we mustn't do this because
    8973                 :            :      * StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    8974                 :            :      */
    8975         [ +  - ]:         76 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    8976                 :         76 :         TruncateSUBTRANS(GetOldestXmin(NULL, PROCARRAY_FLAGS_DEFAULT));
    8977                 :            : 
    8978                 :            :     /* Real work is done, but log and update stats before releasing lock. */
    8979                 :         76 :     LogCheckpointEnd(false);
    8980                 :            : 
    8981                 :         76 :     TRACE_POSTGRESQL_CHECKPOINT_DONE(CheckpointStats.ckpt_bufs_written,
    8982                 :            :                                      NBuffers,
    8983                 :            :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_added,
    8984                 :            :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_removed,
    8985                 :            :                                      CheckpointStats.ckpt_segs_recycled);
    8986                 :            : 
    8987                 :         76 :     LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    8988                 :            : }
    8989                 :            : 
    8990                 :            : /*
    8991                 :            :  * Mark the end of recovery in WAL though without running a full checkpoint.
    8992                 :            :  * We can expect that a restartpoint is likely to be in progress as we
    8993                 :            :  * do this, though we are unwilling to wait for it to complete. So be
    8994                 :            :  * careful to avoid taking the CheckpointLock anywhere here.
    8995                 :            :  *
    8996                 :            :  * CreateRestartPoint() allows for the case where recovery may end before
    8997                 :            :  * the restartpoint completes so there is no concern of concurrent behaviour.
    8998                 :            :  */
    8999                 :            : static void
    9000                 :          0 : CreateEndOfRecoveryRecord(void)
    9001                 :            : {
    9002                 :            :     xl_end_of_recovery xlrec;
    9003                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    9004                 :            : 
    9005                 :            :     /* sanity check */
    9006         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    9007                 :          0 :         elog(ERROR, "can only be used to end recovery");
    9008                 :            : 
    9009                 :          0 :     xlrec.end_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    9010                 :            : 
    9011                 :          0 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9012                 :          0 :     xlrec.ThisTimeLineID = ThisTimeLineID;
    9013                 :          0 :     xlrec.PrevTimeLineID = XLogCtl->PrevTimeLineID;
    9014                 :          0 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    9015                 :            : 
    9016                 :          0 :     LocalSetXLogInsertAllowed();
    9017                 :            : 
    9018                 :          0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    9019                 :            : 
    9020                 :          0 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9021                 :          0 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_end_of_recovery));
    9022                 :          0 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_END_OF_RECOVERY);
    9023                 :            : 
    9024                 :          0 :     XLogFlush(recptr);
    9025                 :            : 
    9026                 :            :     /*
    9027                 :            :      * Update the control file so that crash recovery can follow the timeline
    9028                 :            :      * changes to this point.
    9029                 :            :      */
    9030                 :          0 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9031                 :          0 :     ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    9032                 :          0 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = recptr;
    9033                 :          0 :     ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = ThisTimeLineID;
    9034                 :          0 :     UpdateControlFile();
    9035                 :          0 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9036                 :            : 
    9037                 :          0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    9038                 :            : 
    9039                 :          0 :     LocalXLogInsertAllowed = -1;    /* return to "check" state */
    9040                 :          0 : }
    9041                 :            : 
    9042                 :            : /*
    9043                 :            :  * Flush all data in shared memory to disk, and fsync
    9044                 :            :  *
    9045                 :            :  * This is the common code shared between regular checkpoints and
    9046                 :            :  * recovery restartpoints.
    9047                 :            :  */
    9048                 :            : static void
    9049                 :         76 : CheckPointGuts(XLogRecPtr checkPointRedo, int flags)
    9050                 :            : {
    9051                 :         76 :     CheckPointCLOG();
    9052                 :         76 :     CheckPointCommitTs();
    9053                 :         76 :     CheckPointSUBTRANS();
    9054                 :         76 :     CheckPointMultiXact();
    9055                 :         76 :     CheckPointPredicate();
    9056                 :         76 :     CheckPointRelationMap();
    9057                 :         76 :     CheckPointReplicationSlots();
    9058                 :         76 :     CheckPointSnapBuild();
    9059                 :         76 :     CheckPointLogicalRewriteHeap();
    9060                 :         76 :     CheckPointBuffers(flags);   /* performs all required fsyncs */
    9061                 :         76 :     CheckPointReplicationOrigin();
    9062                 :            :     /* We deliberately delay 2PC checkpointing as long as possible */
    9063                 :         76 :     CheckPointTwoPhase(checkPointRedo);
    9064                 :         76 : }
    9065                 :            : 
    9066                 :            : /*
    9067                 :            :  * Save a checkpoint for recovery restart if appropriate
    9068                 :            :  *
    9069                 :            :  * This function is called each time a checkpoint record is read from XLOG.
    9070                 :            :  * It must determine whether the checkpoint represents a safe restartpoint or
    9071                 :            :  * not.  If so, the checkpoint record is stashed in shared memory so that
    9072                 :            :  * CreateRestartPoint can consult it.  (Note that the latter function is
    9073                 :            :  * executed by the checkpointer, while this one will be executed by the
    9074                 :            :  * startup process.)
    9075                 :            :  */
    9076                 :            : static void
    9077                 :          0 : RecoveryRestartPoint(const CheckPoint *checkPoint)
    9078                 :            : {
    9079                 :            :     /*
    9080                 :            :      * Also refrain from creating a restartpoint if we have seen any
    9081                 :            :      * references to non-existent pages. Restarting recovery from the
    9082                 :            :      * restartpoint would not see the references, so we would lose the
    9083                 :            :      * cross-check that the pages belonged to a relation that was dropped
    9084                 :            :      * later.
    9085                 :            :      */
    9086         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (XLogHaveInvalidPages())
    9087                 :            :     {
    9088                 :          0 :         elog(trace_recovery(DEBUG2),
    9089                 :            :              "could not record restart point at %X/%X because there "
    9090                 :            :              "are unresolved references to invalid pages",
    9091                 :            :              (uint32) (checkPoint->redo >> 32),
    9092                 :            :              (uint32) checkPoint->redo);
    9093                 :          0 :         return;
    9094                 :            :     }
    9095                 :            : 
    9096                 :            :     /*
    9097                 :            :      * Copy the checkpoint record to shared memory, so that checkpointer can
    9098                 :            :      * work out the next time it wants to perform a restartpoint.
    9099                 :            :      */
    9100         [ #  # ]:          0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9101                 :          0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr = ReadRecPtr;
    9102                 :          0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr = EndRecPtr;
    9103                 :          0 :     XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint = *checkPoint;
    9104                 :          0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9105                 :            : }
    9106                 :            : 
    9107                 :            : /*
    9108                 :            :  * Establish a restartpoint if possible.
    9109                 :            :  *
    9110                 :            :  * This is similar to CreateCheckPoint, but is used during WAL recovery
    9111                 :            :  * to establish a point from which recovery can roll forward without
    9112                 :            :  * replaying the entire recovery log.
    9113                 :            :  *
    9114                 :            :  * Returns true if a new restartpoint was established. We can only establish
    9115                 :            :  * a restartpoint if we have replayed a safe checkpoint record since last
    9116                 :            :  * restartpoint.
    9117                 :            :  */
    9118                 :            : bool
    9119                 :          0 : CreateRestartPoint(int flags)
    9120                 :            : {
    9121                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9122                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9123                 :            :     CheckPoint  lastCheckPoint;
    9124                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  PriorRedoPtr;
    9125                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  receivePtr;
    9126                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  replayPtr;
    9127                 :            :     TimeLineID  replayTLI;
    9128                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  endptr;
    9129                 :            :     XLogSegNo   _logSegNo;
    9130                 :            :     TimestampTz xtime;
    9131                 :            : 
    9132                 :            :     /*
    9133                 :            :      * Acquire CheckpointLock to ensure only one restartpoint or checkpoint
    9134                 :            :      * happens at a time.
    9135                 :            :      */
    9136                 :          0 :     LWLockAcquire(CheckpointLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9137                 :            : 
    9138                 :            :     /* Get a local copy of the last safe checkpoint record. */
    9139         [ #  # ]:          0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9140                 :          0 :     lastCheckPointRecPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9141                 :          0 :     lastCheckPointEndPtr = XLogCtl->lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9142                 :          0 :     lastCheckPoint = XLogCtl->lastCheckPoint;
    9143                 :          0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9144                 :            : 
    9145                 :            :     /*
    9146                 :            :      * Check that we're still in recovery mode. It's ok if we exit recovery
    9147                 :            :      * mode after this check, the restart point is valid anyway.
    9148                 :            :      */
    9149         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!RecoveryInProgress())
    9150                 :            :     {
    9151         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    9152                 :            :                 (errmsg("skipping restartpoint, recovery has already ended")));
    9153                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9154                 :          0 :         return false;
    9155                 :            :     }
    9156                 :            : 
    9157                 :            :     /*
    9158                 :            :      * If the last checkpoint record we've replayed is already our last
    9159                 :            :      * restartpoint, we can't perform a new restart point. We still update
    9160                 :            :      * minRecoveryPoint in that case, so that if this is a shutdown restart
    9161                 :            :      * point, we won't start up earlier than before. That's not strictly
    9162                 :            :      * necessary, but when hot standby is enabled, it would be rather weird if
    9163                 :            :      * the database opened up for read-only connections at a point-in-time
    9164                 :            :      * before the last shutdown. Such time travel is still possible in case of
    9165                 :            :      * immediate shutdown, though.
    9166                 :            :      *
    9167                 :            :      * We don't explicitly advance minRecoveryPoint when we do create a
    9168                 :            :      * restartpoint. It's assumed that flushing the buffers will do that as a
    9169                 :            :      * side-effect.
    9170                 :            :      */
    9171 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(lastCheckPointRecPtr) ||
    9172                 :          0 :         lastCheckPoint.redo <= ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo)
    9173                 :            :     {
    9174         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(DEBUG2,
    9175                 :            :                 (errmsg("skipping restartpoint, already performed at %X/%X",
    9176                 :            :                         (uint32) (lastCheckPoint.redo >> 32),
    9177                 :            :                         (uint32) lastCheckPoint.redo)));
    9178                 :            : 
    9179                 :          0 :         UpdateMinRecoveryPoint(InvalidXLogRecPtr, true);
    9180         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)
    9181                 :            :         {
    9182                 :          0 :             LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9183                 :          0 :             ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY;
    9184                 :          0 :             ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    9185                 :          0 :             UpdateControlFile();
    9186                 :          0 :             LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9187                 :            :         }
    9188                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9189                 :          0 :         return false;
    9190                 :            :     }
    9191                 :            : 
    9192                 :            :     /*
    9193                 :            :      * Update the shared RedoRecPtr so that the startup process can calculate
    9194                 :            :      * the number of segments replayed since last restartpoint, and request a
    9195                 :            :      * restartpoint if it exceeds CheckPointSegments.
    9196                 :            :      *
    9197                 :            :      * Like in CreateCheckPoint(), hold off insertions to update it, although
    9198                 :            :      * during recovery this is just pro forma, because no WAL insertions are
    9199                 :            :      * happening.
    9200                 :            :      */
    9201                 :          0 :     WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9202                 :          0 :     RedoRecPtr = XLogCtl->Insert.RedoRecPtr = lastCheckPoint.redo;
    9203                 :          0 :     WALInsertLockRelease();
    9204                 :            : 
    9205                 :            :     /* Also update the info_lck-protected copy */
    9206         [ #  # ]:          0 :     SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9207                 :          0 :     XLogCtl->RedoRecPtr = lastCheckPoint.redo;
    9208                 :          0 :     SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9209                 :            : 
    9210                 :            :     /*
    9211                 :            :      * Prepare to accumulate statistics.
    9212                 :            :      *
    9213                 :            :      * Note: because it is possible for log_checkpoints to change while a
    9214                 :            :      * checkpoint proceeds, we always accumulate stats, even if
    9215                 :            :      * log_checkpoints is currently off.
    9216                 :            :      */
    9217 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     MemSet(&CheckpointStats, 0, sizeof(CheckpointStats));
         [ #  # ][ #  # ]
                 [ #  # ]
    9218                 :          0 :     CheckpointStats.ckpt_start_t = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    9219                 :            : 
    9220         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (log_checkpoints)
    9221                 :          0 :         LogCheckpointStart(flags, true);
    9222                 :            : 
    9223                 :          0 :     CheckPointGuts(lastCheckPoint.redo, flags);
    9224                 :            : 
    9225                 :            :     /*
    9226                 :            :      * Remember the prior checkpoint's redo ptr for
    9227                 :            :      * UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate()
    9228                 :            :      */
    9229                 :          0 :     PriorRedoPtr = ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo;
    9230                 :            : 
    9231                 :            :     /*
    9232                 :            :      * Update pg_control, using current time.  Check that it still shows
    9233                 :            :      * IN_ARCHIVE_RECOVERY state and an older checkpoint, else do nothing;
    9234                 :            :      * this is a quick hack to make sure nothing really bad happens if somehow
    9235                 :            :      * we get here after the end-of-recovery checkpoint.
    9236                 :            :      */
    9237                 :          0 :     LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9238 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (ControlFile->state == DB_IN_ARCHIVE_RECOVERY &&
    9239                 :          0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy.redo < lastCheckPoint.redo)
    9240                 :            :     {
    9241                 :          0 :         ControlFile->checkPoint = lastCheckPointRecPtr;
    9242                 :          0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy = lastCheckPoint;
    9243                 :          0 :         ControlFile->time = (pg_time_t) time(NULL);
    9244                 :            : 
    9245                 :            :         /*
    9246                 :            :          * Ensure minRecoveryPoint is past the checkpoint record.  Normally,
    9247                 :            :          * this will have happened already while writing out dirty buffers,
    9248                 :            :          * but not necessarily - e.g. because no buffers were dirtied.  We do
    9249                 :            :          * this because a non-exclusive base backup uses minRecoveryPoint to
    9250                 :            :          * determine which WAL files must be included in the backup, and the
    9251                 :            :          * file (or files) containing the checkpoint record must be included,
    9252                 :            :          * at a minimum. Note that for an ordinary restart of recovery there's
    9253                 :            :          * no value in having the minimum recovery point any earlier than this
    9254                 :            :          * anyway, because redo will begin just after the checkpoint record.
    9255                 :            :          */
    9256         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint < lastCheckPointEndPtr)
    9257                 :            :         {
    9258                 :          0 :             ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint = lastCheckPointEndPtr;
    9259                 :          0 :             ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI = lastCheckPoint.ThisTimeLineID;
    9260                 :            : 
    9261                 :            :             /* update local copy */
    9262                 :          0 :             minRecoveryPoint = ControlFile->minRecoveryPoint;
    9263                 :          0 :             minRecoveryPointTLI = ControlFile->minRecoveryPointTLI;
    9264                 :            :         }
    9265         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (flags & CHECKPOINT_IS_SHUTDOWN)
    9266                 :          0 :             ControlFile->state = DB_SHUTDOWNED_IN_RECOVERY;
    9267                 :          0 :         UpdateControlFile();
    9268                 :            :     }
    9269                 :          0 :     LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9270                 :            : 
    9271                 :            :     /*
    9272                 :            :      * Update the average distance between checkpoints/restartpoints if the
    9273                 :            :      * prior checkpoint exists.
    9274                 :            :      */
    9275         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (PriorRedoPtr != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    9276                 :          0 :         UpdateCheckPointDistanceEstimate(RedoRecPtr - PriorRedoPtr);
    9277                 :            : 
    9278                 :            :     /*
    9279                 :            :      * Delete old log files, those no longer needed for last restartpoint to
    9280                 :            :      * prevent the disk holding the xlog from growing full.
    9281                 :            :      */
    9282                 :          0 :     XLByteToSeg(RedoRecPtr, _logSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    9283                 :            : 
    9284                 :            :     /*
    9285                 :            :      * Retreat _logSegNo using the current end of xlog replayed or received,
    9286                 :            :      * whichever is later.
    9287                 :            :      */
    9288                 :          0 :     receivePtr = GetWalRcvWriteRecPtr(NULL, NULL);
    9289                 :          0 :     replayPtr = GetXLogReplayRecPtr(&replayTLI);
    9290                 :          0 :     endptr = (receivePtr < replayPtr) ? replayPtr : receivePtr;
    9291                 :          0 :     KeepLogSeg(endptr, &_logSegNo);
    9292                 :          0 :     _logSegNo--;
    9293                 :            : 
    9294                 :            :     /*
    9295                 :            :      * Try to recycle segments on a useful timeline. If we've been promoted
    9296                 :            :      * since the beginning of this restartpoint, use the new timeline chosen
    9297                 :            :      * at end of recovery (RecoveryInProgress() sets ThisTimeLineID in that
    9298                 :            :      * case). If we're still in recovery, use the timeline we're currently
    9299                 :            :      * replaying.
    9300                 :            :      *
    9301                 :            :      * There is no guarantee that the WAL segments will be useful on the
    9302                 :            :      * current timeline; if recovery proceeds to a new timeline right after
    9303                 :            :      * this, the pre-allocated WAL segments on this timeline will not be used,
    9304                 :            :      * and will go wasted until recycled on the next restartpoint. We'll live
    9305                 :            :      * with that.
    9306                 :            :      */
    9307         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    9308                 :          0 :         ThisTimeLineID = replayTLI;
    9309                 :            : 
    9310                 :          0 :     RemoveOldXlogFiles(_logSegNo, RedoRecPtr, endptr);
    9311                 :            : 
    9312                 :            :     /*
    9313                 :            :      * Make more log segments if needed.  (Do this after recycling old log
    9314                 :            :      * segments, since that may supply some of the needed files.)
    9315                 :            :      */
    9316                 :          0 :     PreallocXlogFiles(endptr);
    9317                 :            : 
    9318                 :            :     /*
    9319                 :            :      * ThisTimeLineID is normally not set when we're still in recovery.
    9320                 :            :      * However, recycling/preallocating segments above needed ThisTimeLineID
    9321                 :            :      * to determine which timeline to install the segments on. Reset it now,
    9322                 :            :      * to restore the normal state of affairs for debugging purposes.
    9323                 :            :      */
    9324         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (RecoveryInProgress())
    9325                 :          0 :         ThisTimeLineID = 0;
    9326                 :            : 
    9327                 :            :     /*
    9328                 :            :      * Truncate pg_subtrans if possible.  We can throw away all data before
    9329                 :            :      * the oldest XMIN of any running transaction.  No future transaction will
    9330                 :            :      * attempt to reference any pg_subtrans entry older than that (see Asserts
    9331                 :            :      * in subtrans.c).  When hot standby is disabled, though, we mustn't do
    9332                 :            :      * this because StartupSUBTRANS hasn't been called yet.
    9333                 :            :      */
    9334         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (EnableHotStandby)
    9335                 :          0 :         TruncateSUBTRANS(GetOldestXmin(NULL, PROCARRAY_FLAGS_DEFAULT));
    9336                 :            : 
    9337                 :            :     /* Real work is done, but log and update before releasing lock. */
    9338                 :          0 :     LogCheckpointEnd(true);
    9339                 :            : 
    9340                 :          0 :     xtime = GetLatestXTime();
    9341 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     ereport((log_checkpoints ? LOG : DEBUG2),
                 [ #  # ]
    9342                 :            :             (errmsg("recovery restart point at %X/%X",
    9343                 :            :                     (uint32) (lastCheckPoint.redo >> 32), (uint32) lastCheckPoint.redo),
    9344                 :            :              xtime ? errdetail("Last completed transaction was at log time %s.",
    9345                 :            :                                timestamptz_to_str(xtime)) : 0));
    9346                 :            : 
    9347                 :          0 :     LWLockRelease(CheckpointLock);
    9348                 :            : 
    9349                 :            :     /*
    9350                 :            :      * Finally, execute archive_cleanup_command, if any.
    9351                 :            :      */
    9352 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (archiveCleanupCommand && strcmp(archiveCleanupCommand, "") != 0)
    9353                 :          0 :         ExecuteRecoveryCommand(archiveCleanupCommand,
    9354                 :            :                                "archive_cleanup_command",
    9355                 :            :                                false);
    9356                 :            : 
    9357                 :          0 :     return true;
    9358                 :            : }
    9359                 :            : 
    9360                 :            : /*
    9361                 :            :  * Retreat *logSegNo to the last segment that we need to retain because of
    9362                 :            :  * either wal_keep_segments or replication slots.
    9363                 :            :  *
    9364                 :            :  * This is calculated by subtracting wal_keep_segments from the given xlog
    9365                 :            :  * location, recptr and by making sure that that result is below the
    9366                 :            :  * requirement of replication slots.
    9367                 :            :  */
    9368                 :            : static void
    9369                 :         76 : KeepLogSeg(XLogRecPtr recptr, XLogSegNo *logSegNo)
    9370                 :            : {
    9371                 :            :     XLogSegNo   segno;
    9372                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  keep;
    9373                 :            : 
    9374                 :         76 :     XLByteToSeg(recptr, segno, wal_segment_size);
    9375                 :         76 :     keep = XLogGetReplicationSlotMinimumLSN();
    9376                 :            : 
    9377                 :            :     /* compute limit for wal_keep_segments first */
    9378         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (wal_keep_segments > 0)
    9379                 :            :     {
    9380                 :            :         /* avoid underflow, don't go below 1 */
    9381         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (segno <= wal_keep_segments)
    9382                 :          0 :             segno = 1;
    9383                 :            :         else
    9384                 :          0 :             segno = segno - wal_keep_segments;
    9385                 :            :     }
    9386                 :            : 
    9387                 :            :     /* then check whether slots limit removal further */
    9388 [ +  - ][ -  + ]:         76 :     if (max_replication_slots > 0 && keep != InvalidXLogRecPtr)
    9389                 :            :     {
    9390                 :            :         XLogSegNo   slotSegNo;
    9391                 :            : 
    9392                 :          0 :         XLByteToSeg(keep, slotSegNo, wal_segment_size);
    9393                 :            : 
    9394         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (slotSegNo <= 0)
    9395                 :          0 :             segno = 1;
    9396         [ #  # ]:          0 :         else if (slotSegNo < segno)
    9397                 :          0 :             segno = slotSegNo;
    9398                 :            :     }
    9399                 :            : 
    9400                 :            :     /* don't delete WAL segments newer than the calculated segment */
    9401         [ -  + ]:         76 :     if (segno < *logSegNo)
    9402                 :          0 :         *logSegNo = segno;
    9403                 :         76 : }
    9404                 :            : 
    9405                 :            : /*
    9406                 :            :  * Write a NEXTOID log record
    9407                 :            :  */
    9408                 :            : void
    9409                 :          1 : XLogPutNextOid(Oid nextOid)
    9410                 :            : {
    9411                 :          1 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9412                 :          1 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) (&nextOid), sizeof(Oid));
    9413                 :          1 :     (void) XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_NEXTOID);
    9414                 :            : 
    9415                 :            :     /*
    9416                 :            :      * We need not flush the NEXTOID record immediately, because any of the
    9417                 :            :      * just-allocated OIDs could only reach disk as part of a tuple insert or
    9418                 :            :      * update that would have its own XLOG record that must follow the NEXTOID
    9419                 :            :      * record.  Therefore, the standard buffer LSN interlock applied to those
    9420                 :            :      * records will ensure no such OID reaches disk before the NEXTOID record
    9421                 :            :      * does.
    9422                 :            :      *
    9423                 :            :      * Note, however, that the above statement only covers state "within" the
    9424                 :            :      * database.  When we use a generated OID as a file or directory name, we
    9425                 :            :      * are in a sense violating the basic WAL rule, because that filesystem
    9426                 :            :      * change may reach disk before the NEXTOID WAL record does.  The impact
    9427                 :            :      * of this is that if a database crash occurs immediately afterward, we
    9428                 :            :      * might after restart re-generate the same OID and find that it conflicts
    9429                 :            :      * with the leftover file or directory.  But since for safety's sake we
    9430                 :            :      * always loop until finding a nonconflicting filename, this poses no real
    9431                 :            :      * problem in practice. See pgsql-hackers discussion 27-Sep-2006.
    9432                 :            :      */
    9433                 :          1 : }
    9434                 :            : 
    9435                 :            : /*
    9436                 :            :  * Write an XLOG SWITCH record.
    9437                 :            :  *
    9438                 :            :  * Here we just blindly issue an XLogInsert request for the record.
    9439                 :            :  * All the magic happens inside XLogInsert.
    9440                 :            :  *
    9441                 :            :  * The return value is either the end+1 address of the switch record,
    9442                 :            :  * or the end+1 address of the prior segment if we did not need to
    9443                 :            :  * write a switch record because we are already at segment start.
    9444                 :            :  */
    9445                 :            : XLogRecPtr
    9446                 :          1 : RequestXLogSwitch(bool mark_unimportant)
    9447                 :            : {
    9448                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  RecPtr;
    9449                 :            : 
    9450                 :            :     /* XLOG SWITCH has no data */
    9451                 :          1 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9452                 :            : 
    9453         [ -  + ]:          1 :     if (mark_unimportant)
    9454                 :          0 :         XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_MARK_UNIMPORTANT);
    9455                 :          1 :     RecPtr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_SWITCH);
    9456                 :            : 
    9457                 :          1 :     return RecPtr;
    9458                 :            : }
    9459                 :            : 
    9460                 :            : /*
    9461                 :            :  * Write a RESTORE POINT record
    9462                 :            :  */
    9463                 :            : XLogRecPtr
    9464                 :          0 : XLogRestorePoint(const char *rpName)
    9465                 :            : {
    9466                 :            :     XLogRecPtr  RecPtr;
    9467                 :            :     xl_restore_point xlrec;
    9468                 :            : 
    9469                 :          0 :     xlrec.rp_time = GetCurrentTimestamp();
    9470                 :          0 :     strlcpy(xlrec.rp_name, rpName, MAXFNAMELEN);
    9471                 :            : 
    9472                 :          0 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    9473                 :          0 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xl_restore_point));
    9474                 :            : 
    9475                 :          0 :     RecPtr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_RESTORE_POINT);
    9476                 :            : 
    9477         [ #  # ]:          0 :     ereport(LOG,
    9478                 :            :             (errmsg("restore point \"%s\" created at %X/%X",
    9479                 :            :                     rpName, (uint32) (RecPtr >> 32), (uint32) RecPtr)));
    9480                 :            : 
    9481                 :          0 :     return RecPtr;
    9482                 :            : }
    9483                 :            : 
    9484                 :            : /*
    9485                 :            :  * Check if any of the GUC parameters that are critical for hot standby
    9486                 :            :  * have changed, and update the value in pg_control file if necessary.
    9487                 :            :  */
    9488                 :            : static void
    9489                 :          1 : XLogReportParameters(void)
    9490                 :            : {
    9491 [ +  - ][ +  - ]:          1 :     if (wal_level != ControlFile->wal_level ||
    9492         [ +  - ]:          1 :         wal_log_hints != ControlFile->wal_log_hints ||
    9493         [ +  - ]:          1 :         MaxConnections != ControlFile->MaxConnections ||
    9494         [ +  - ]:          1 :         max_worker_processes != ControlFile->max_worker_processes ||
    9495         [ +  - ]:          1 :         max_wal_senders != ControlFile->max_wal_senders ||
    9496         [ +  - ]:          1 :         max_prepared_xacts != ControlFile->max_prepared_xacts ||
    9497         [ -  + ]:          1 :         max_locks_per_xact != ControlFile->max_locks_per_xact ||
    9498                 :          1 :         track_commit_timestamp != ControlFile->track_commit_timestamp)
    9499                 :            :     {
    9500                 :            :         /*
    9501                 :            :          * The change in number of backend slots doesn't need to be WAL-logged
    9502                 :            :          * if archiving is not enabled, as you can't start archive recovery
    9503                 :            :          * with wal_level=minimal anyway. We don't really care about the
    9504                 :            :          * values in pg_control either if wal_level=minimal, but seems better
    9505                 :            :          * to keep them up-to-date to avoid confusion.
    9506                 :            :          */
    9507 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :         if (wal_level != ControlFile->wal_level || XLogIsNeeded())
    9508                 :            :         {
    9509                 :            :             xl_parameter_change xlrec;
    9510                 :            :             XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    9511                 :            : 
    9512                 :          0 :             xlrec.MaxConnections = MaxConnections;
    9513                 :          0 :             xlrec.max_worker_processes = max_worker_processes;
    9514                 :          0 :             xlrec.max_wal_senders = max_wal_senders;
    9515                 :          0 :             xlrec.max_prepared_xacts = max_prepared_xacts;
    9516                 :          0 :             xlrec.max_locks_per_xact = max_locks_per_xact;
    9517                 :          0 :             xlrec.wal_level = wal_level;
    9518                 :          0 :             xlrec.wal_log_hints = wal_log_hints;
    9519                 :          0 :             xlrec.track_commit_timestamp = track_commit_timestamp;
    9520                 :            : 
    9521                 :          0 :             XLogBeginInsert();
    9522                 :          0 :             XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, sizeof(xlrec));
    9523                 :            : 
    9524                 :          0 :             recptr = XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_PARAMETER_CHANGE);
    9525                 :          0 :             XLogFlush(recptr);
    9526                 :            :         }
    9527                 :            : 
    9528                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9529                 :            : 
    9530                 :          0 :         ControlFile->MaxConnections = MaxConnections;
    9531                 :          0 :         ControlFile->max_worker_processes = max_worker_processes;
    9532                 :          0 :         ControlFile->max_wal_senders = max_wal_senders;
    9533                 :          0 :         ControlFile->max_prepared_xacts = max_prepared_xacts;
    9534                 :          0 :         ControlFile->max_locks_per_xact = max_locks_per_xact;
    9535                 :          0 :         ControlFile->wal_level = wal_level;
    9536                 :          0 :         ControlFile->wal_log_hints = wal_log_hints;
    9537                 :          0 :         ControlFile->track_commit_timestamp = track_commit_timestamp;
    9538                 :          0 :         UpdateControlFile();
    9539                 :            : 
    9540                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9541                 :            :     }
    9542                 :          1 : }
    9543                 :            : 
    9544                 :            : /*
    9545                 :            :  * Update full_page_writes in shared memory, and write an
    9546                 :            :  * XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record if necessary.
    9547                 :            :  *
    9548                 :            :  * Note: this function assumes there is no other process running
    9549                 :            :  * concurrently that could update it.
    9550                 :            :  */
    9551                 :            : void
    9552                 :          2 : UpdateFullPageWrites(void)
    9553                 :            : {
    9554                 :          2 :     XLogCtlInsert *Insert = &XLogCtl->Insert;
    9555                 :            :     bool        recoveryInProgress;
    9556                 :            : 
    9557                 :            :     /*
    9558                 :            :      * Do nothing if full_page_writes has not been changed.
    9559                 :            :      *
    9560                 :            :      * It's safe to check the shared full_page_writes without the lock,
    9561                 :            :      * because we assume that there is no concurrently running process which
    9562                 :            :      * can update it.
    9563                 :            :      */
    9564         [ +  - ]:          2 :     if (fullPageWrites == Insert->fullPageWrites)
    9565                 :          2 :         return;
    9566                 :            : 
    9567                 :            :     /*
    9568                 :            :      * Perform this outside critical section so that the WAL insert
    9569                 :            :      * initialization done by RecoveryInProgress() doesn't trigger an
    9570                 :            :      * assertion failure.
    9571                 :            :      */
    9572                 :          0 :     recoveryInProgress = RecoveryInProgress();
    9573                 :            : 
    9574                 :          0 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    9575                 :            : 
    9576                 :            :     /*
    9577                 :            :      * It's always safe to take full page images, even when not strictly
    9578                 :            :      * required, but not the other round. So if we're setting full_page_writes
    9579                 :            :      * to true, first set it true and then write the WAL record. If we're
    9580                 :            :      * setting it to false, first write the WAL record and then set the global
    9581                 :            :      * flag.
    9582                 :            :      */
    9583         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (fullPageWrites)
    9584                 :            :     {
    9585                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9586                 :          0 :         Insert->fullPageWrites = true;
    9587                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    9588                 :            :     }
    9589                 :            : 
    9590                 :            :     /*
    9591                 :            :      * Write an XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record. This allows us to keep track of
    9592                 :            :      * full_page_writes during archive recovery, if required.
    9593                 :            :      */
    9594 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (XLogStandbyInfoActive() && !recoveryInProgress)
    9595                 :            :     {
    9596                 :          0 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    9597                 :          0 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) (&fullPageWrites), sizeof(bool));
    9598                 :            : 
    9599                 :          0 :         XLogInsert(RM_XLOG_ID, XLOG_FPW_CHANGE);
    9600                 :            :     }
    9601                 :            : 
    9602         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!fullPageWrites)
    9603                 :            :     {
    9604                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockAcquireExclusive();
    9605                 :          0 :         Insert->fullPageWrites = false;
    9606                 :          0 :         WALInsertLockRelease();
    9607                 :            :     }
    9608                 :          0 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    9609                 :            : }
    9610                 :            : 
    9611                 :            : /*
    9612                 :            :  * Check that it's OK to switch to new timeline during recovery.
    9613                 :            :  *
    9614                 :            :  * 'lsn' is the address of the shutdown checkpoint record we're about to
    9615                 :            :  * replay. (Currently, timeline can only change at a shutdown checkpoint).
    9616                 :            :  */
    9617                 :            : static void
    9618                 :          0 : checkTimeLineSwitch(XLogRecPtr lsn, TimeLineID newTLI, TimeLineID prevTLI)
    9619                 :            : {
    9620                 :            :     /* Check that the record agrees on what the current (old) timeline is */
    9621         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (prevTLI != ThisTimeLineID)
    9622         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9623                 :            :                 (errmsg("unexpected previous timeline ID %u (current timeline ID %u) in checkpoint record",
    9624                 :            :                         prevTLI, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9625                 :            : 
    9626                 :            :     /*
    9627                 :            :      * The new timeline better be in the list of timelines we expect to see,
    9628                 :            :      * according to the timeline history. It should also not decrease.
    9629                 :            :      */
    9630 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (newTLI < ThisTimeLineID || !tliInHistory(newTLI, expectedTLEs))
    9631         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9632                 :            :                 (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u (after %u) in checkpoint record",
    9633                 :            :                         newTLI, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9634                 :            : 
    9635                 :            :     /*
    9636                 :            :      * If we have not yet reached min recovery point, and we're about to
    9637                 :            :      * switch to a timeline greater than the timeline of the min recovery
    9638                 :            :      * point: trouble. After switching to the new timeline, we could not
    9639                 :            :      * possibly visit the min recovery point on the correct timeline anymore.
    9640                 :            :      * This can happen if there is a newer timeline in the archive that
    9641                 :            :      * branched before the timeline the min recovery point is on, and you
    9642                 :            :      * attempt to do PITR to the new timeline.
    9643                 :            :      */
    9644 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     if (!XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(minRecoveryPoint) &&
    9645         [ #  # ]:          0 :         lsn < minRecoveryPoint &&
    9646                 :          0 :         newTLI > minRecoveryPointTLI)
    9647         [ #  # ]:          0 :         ereport(PANIC,
    9648                 :            :                 (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u in checkpoint record, before reaching minimum recovery point %X/%X on timeline %u",
    9649                 :            :                         newTLI,
    9650                 :            :                         (uint32) (minRecoveryPoint >> 32),
    9651                 :            :                         (uint32) minRecoveryPoint,
    9652                 :            :                         minRecoveryPointTLI)));
    9653                 :            : 
    9654                 :            :     /* Looks good */
    9655                 :          0 : }
    9656                 :            : 
    9657                 :            : /*
    9658                 :            :  * XLOG resource manager's routines
    9659                 :            :  *
    9660                 :            :  * Definitions of info values are in include/catalog/pg_control.h, though
    9661                 :            :  * not all record types are related to control file updates.
    9662                 :            :  */
    9663                 :            : void
    9664                 :          0 : xlog_redo(XLogReaderState *record)
    9665                 :            : {
    9666                 :          0 :     uint8       info = XLogRecGetInfo(record) & ~XLR_INFO_MASK;
    9667                 :          0 :     XLogRecPtr  lsn = record->EndRecPtr;
    9668                 :            : 
    9669                 :            :     /* in XLOG rmgr, backup blocks are only used by XLOG_FPI records */
    9670                 :            :     Assert(info == XLOG_FPI || info == XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT ||
    9671                 :            :            !XLogRecHasAnyBlockRefs(record));
    9672                 :            : 
    9673         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (info == XLOG_NEXTOID)
    9674                 :            :     {
    9675                 :            :         Oid         nextOid;
    9676                 :            : 
    9677                 :            :         /*
    9678                 :            :          * We used to try to take the maximum of ShmemVariableCache->nextOid
    9679                 :            :          * and the recorded nextOid, but that fails if the OID counter wraps
    9680                 :            :          * around.  Since no OID allocation should be happening during replay
    9681                 :            :          * anyway, better to just believe the record exactly.  We still take
    9682                 :            :          * OidGenLock while setting the variable, just in case.
    9683                 :            :          */
    9684                 :          0 :         memcpy(&nextOid, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(Oid));
    9685                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(OidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9686                 :          0 :         ShmemVariableCache->nextOid = nextOid;
    9687                 :          0 :         ShmemVariableCache->oidCount = 0;
    9688                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(OidGenLock);
    9689                 :            :     }
    9690         [ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_CHECKPOINT_SHUTDOWN)
    9691                 :            :     {
    9692                 :            :         CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    9693                 :            : 
    9694                 :          0 :         memcpy(&checkPoint, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(CheckPoint));
    9695                 :            :         /* In a SHUTDOWN checkpoint, believe the counters exactly */
    9696                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9697                 :          0 :         ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9698                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(XidGenLock);
    9699                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(OidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9700                 :          0 :         ShmemVariableCache->nextOid = checkPoint.nextOid;
    9701                 :          0 :         ShmemVariableCache->oidCount = 0;
    9702                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(OidGenLock);
    9703                 :          0 :         MultiXactSetNextMXact(checkPoint.nextMulti,
    9704                 :            :                               checkPoint.nextMultiOffset);
    9705                 :            : 
    9706                 :          0 :         MultiXactAdvanceOldest(checkPoint.oldestMulti,
    9707                 :            :                                checkPoint.oldestMultiDB);
    9708                 :            : 
    9709                 :            :         /*
    9710                 :            :          * No need to set oldestClogXid here as well; it'll be set when we
    9711                 :            :          * redo an xl_clog_truncate if it changed since initialization.
    9712                 :            :          */
    9713                 :          0 :         SetTransactionIdLimit(checkPoint.oldestXid, checkPoint.oldestXidDB);
    9714                 :            : 
    9715                 :            :         /*
    9716                 :            :          * If we see a shutdown checkpoint while waiting for an end-of-backup
    9717                 :            :          * record, the backup was canceled and the end-of-backup record will
    9718                 :            :          * never arrive.
    9719                 :            :          */
    9720 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :         if (ArchiveRecoveryRequested &&
    9721         [ #  # ]:          0 :             !XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(ControlFile->backupStartPoint) &&
    9722                 :          0 :             XLogRecPtrIsInvalid(ControlFile->backupEndPoint))
    9723         [ #  # ]:          0 :             ereport(PANIC,
    9724                 :            :                     (errmsg("online backup was canceled, recovery cannot continue")));
    9725                 :            : 
    9726                 :            :         /*
    9727                 :            :          * If we see a shutdown checkpoint, we know that nothing was running
    9728                 :            :          * on the master at this point. So fake-up an empty running-xacts
    9729                 :            :          * record and use that here and now. Recover additional standby state
    9730                 :            :          * for prepared transactions.
    9731                 :            :          */
    9732         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (standbyState >= STANDBY_INITIALIZED)
    9733                 :            :         {
    9734                 :            :             TransactionId *xids;
    9735                 :            :             int         nxids;
    9736                 :            :             TransactionId oldestActiveXID;
    9737                 :            :             TransactionId latestCompletedXid;
    9738                 :            :             RunningTransactionsData running;
    9739                 :            : 
    9740                 :          0 :             oldestActiveXID = PrescanPreparedTransactions(&xids, &nxids);
    9741                 :            : 
    9742                 :            :             /*
    9743                 :            :              * Construct a RunningTransactions snapshot representing a shut
    9744                 :            :              * down server, with only prepared transactions still alive. We're
    9745                 :            :              * never overflowed at this point because all subxids are listed
    9746                 :            :              * with their parent prepared transactions.
    9747                 :            :              */
    9748                 :          0 :             running.xcnt = nxids;
    9749                 :          0 :             running.subxcnt = 0;
    9750                 :          0 :             running.subxid_overflow = false;
    9751                 :          0 :             running.nextXid = XidFromFullTransactionId(checkPoint.nextFullXid);
    9752                 :          0 :             running.oldestRunningXid = oldestActiveXID;
    9753                 :          0 :             latestCompletedXid = XidFromFullTransactionId(checkPoint.nextFullXid);
    9754         [ #  # ]:          0 :             TransactionIdRetreat(latestCompletedXid);
    9755                 :            :             Assert(TransactionIdIsNormal(latestCompletedXid));
    9756                 :          0 :             running.latestCompletedXid = latestCompletedXid;
    9757                 :          0 :             running.xids = xids;
    9758                 :            : 
    9759                 :          0 :             ProcArrayApplyRecoveryInfo(&running);
    9760                 :            : 
    9761                 :          0 :             StandbyRecoverPreparedTransactions();
    9762                 :            :         }
    9763                 :            : 
    9764                 :            :         /* ControlFile->checkPointCopy always tracks the latest ckpt XID */
    9765                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9766                 :          0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy.nextFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9767                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9768                 :            : 
    9769                 :            :         /* Update shared-memory copy of checkpoint XID/epoch */
    9770         [ #  # ]:          0 :         SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9771                 :          0 :         XLogCtl->ckptFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9772                 :          0 :         SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9773                 :            : 
    9774                 :            :         /*
    9775                 :            :          * We should've already switched to the new TLI before replaying this
    9776                 :            :          * record.
    9777                 :            :          */
    9778         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (checkPoint.ThisTimeLineID != ThisTimeLineID)
    9779         [ #  # ]:          0 :             ereport(PANIC,
    9780                 :            :                     (errmsg("unexpected timeline ID %u (should be %u) in checkpoint record",
    9781                 :            :                             checkPoint.ThisTimeLineID, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9782                 :            : 
    9783                 :          0 :         RecoveryRestartPoint(&checkPoint);
    9784                 :            :     }
    9785         [ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_CHECKPOINT_ONLINE)
    9786                 :            :     {
    9787                 :            :         CheckPoint  checkPoint;
    9788                 :            : 
    9789                 :          0 :         memcpy(&checkPoint, XLogRecGetData(record), sizeof(CheckPoint));
    9790                 :            :         /* In an ONLINE checkpoint, treat the XID counter as a minimum */
    9791                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(XidGenLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9792         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (FullTransactionIdPrecedes(ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid,
    9793                 :            :                                       checkPoint.nextFullXid))
    9794                 :          0 :             ShmemVariableCache->nextFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9795                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(XidGenLock);
    9796                 :            : 
    9797                 :            :         /*
    9798                 :            :          * We ignore the nextOid counter in an ONLINE checkpoint, preferring
    9799                 :            :          * to track OID assignment through XLOG_NEXTOID records.  The nextOid
    9800                 :            :          * counter is from the start of the checkpoint and might well be stale
    9801                 :            :          * compared to later XLOG_NEXTOID records.  We could try to take the
    9802                 :            :          * maximum of the nextOid counter and our latest value, but since
    9803                 :            :          * there's no particular guarantee about the speed with which the OID
    9804                 :            :          * counter wraps around, that's a risky thing to do.  In any case,
    9805                 :            :          * users of the nextOid counter are required to avoid assignment of
    9806                 :            :          * duplicates, so that a somewhat out-of-date value should be safe.
    9807                 :            :          */
    9808                 :            : 
    9809                 :            :         /* Handle multixact */
    9810                 :          0 :         MultiXactAdvanceNextMXact(checkPoint.nextMulti,
    9811                 :            :                                   checkPoint.nextMultiOffset);
    9812                 :            : 
    9813                 :            :         /*
    9814                 :            :          * NB: This may perform multixact truncation when replaying WAL
    9815                 :            :          * generated by an older primary.
    9816                 :            :          */
    9817                 :          0 :         MultiXactAdvanceOldest(checkPoint.oldestMulti,
    9818                 :            :                                checkPoint.oldestMultiDB);
    9819         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(ShmemVariableCache->oldestXid,
    9820                 :            :                                   checkPoint.oldestXid))
    9821                 :          0 :             SetTransactionIdLimit(checkPoint.oldestXid,
    9822                 :            :                                   checkPoint.oldestXidDB);
    9823                 :            :         /* ControlFile->checkPointCopy always tracks the latest ckpt XID */
    9824                 :          0 :         LWLockAcquire(ControlFileLock, LW_EXCLUSIVE);
    9825                 :          0 :         ControlFile->checkPointCopy.nextFullXid = checkPoint.nextFullXid;
    9826                 :          0 :         LWLockRelease(ControlFileLock);
    9827                 :            :

    9849                 :            :          * but this case is rarer and harder to test, so the benefit doesn't

    9851                 :            :          */
    9852                 :            :

    9857         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (xlrec.ThisTimeLineID != ThisTimeLineID)

    9860                 :            :                             xlrec.ThisTimeLineID, ThisTimeLineID)));
    9861                 :            :     }
    9862         [ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_NOOP)

    9867                 :            :     {

    9869                 :            :     }
    9870         [ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_RESTORE_POINT)
    9871                 :            :     {

    9873                 :            :     }
    9874 [ #  # ][ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_FPI || info == XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT)
    9875                 :            :     {
    9876                 :            :         /*
    9877                 :            :          * Full-page image (FPI) records contain nothing else but a backup
    9878                 :            :          * block (or multiple backup blocks). Every block reference must
    9879                 :            :          * include a full-page image - otherwise there would be no point in
    9880                 :            :          * this record.
    9881                 :            :          *
    9882                 :            :          * No recovery conflicts are generated by these generic records - if a
    9883                 :            :          * resource manager needs to generate conflicts, it has to define a
    9884                 :            :          * separate WAL record type and redo routine.
    9885                 :            :          *
    9886                 :            :          * XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT records are generated when a page needs to be
    9887                 :            :          * WAL- logged because of a hint bit update. They are only generated
    9888                 :            :          * when checksums are enabled. There is no difference in handling
    9889                 :            :          * XLOG_FPI and XLOG_FPI_FOR_HINT records, they use a different info
    9890                 :            :          * code just to distinguish them for statistics purposes.
    9891                 :            :          */
    9892         [ #  # ]:          0 :         for (uint8 block_id = 0; block_id <= record->max_block_id; block_id++)
    9893                 :            :         {
    9894                 :            :             Buffer      buffer;
    9895                 :            :

    9975                 :          0 :         CheckRequiredParameterValues();
    9976                 :            :     }
    9977         [ #  # ]:          0 :     else if (info == XLOG_FPW_CHANGE)
    9978                 :            :     {

    9982                 :            : 
    9983                 :            :         /*
    9984                 :            :          * Update the LSN of the last replayed XLOG_FPW_CHANGE record so that
    9985                 :            :          * do_pg_start_backup() and do_pg_stop_backup() can check whether
    9986                 :            :          * full_page_writes has been disabled during online backup.
    9987                 :            :          */
    9988         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (!fpw)
    9989                 :            :         {
    9990         [ #  # ]:          0 :             SpinLockAcquire(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9991         [ #  # ]:          0 :             if (XLogCtl->lastFpwDisableRecPtr < ReadRecPtr)
    9992                 :          0 :                 XLogCtl->lastFpwDisableRecPtr = ReadRecPtr;
    9993                 :          0 :             SpinLockRelease(&XLogCtl->info_lck);
    9994                 :            :         }
    9995                 :            : 
    9996                 :            :         /* Keep track of full_page_writes */
    9997                 :          0 :         lastFullPageWrites = fpw;
    9998                 :            :     }
    9999                 :          0 : }

   10001                 :            : #ifdef WAL_DEBUG
   10002                 :            : 
   10003                 :            : static void
   10004                 :            : xlog_outrec(StringInfo buf, XLogReaderState *record)
   10005                 :            : {
   10006                 :            :     int         block_id;
   10007                 :            :

   10009                 :            :                      (uint32) (XLogRecGetPrev(record) >> 32),

   10016                 :            :     /* decode block references */
